Five minutes at a time we're introduced to new characters, but it may as well be the same people over and over again, because they somehow manage to say the same thing-- over and over again. Just because people are talking philosophy, doesn't mean they are making any sense, or rather making any actual relevance. For the 'philosophy' these people slate by all the time is usually incredibly useless and theoretical and on top of all that it's far from anything provocative. In fact just about every scene is chock-full of whining where people make blatant observations on everyday life-- moreover, they're observations are hardly anything special.All in all, Waking Life is a highly disappointing movie. The story goes nowhere and in all too long of a time the movie is finally over. If you are considering this movie you might as well watch the trailer, it's probably every bit of the movie shown once without being repeated over for almost 100 minutes. This movie is true showcase of psycho babble from a man stoned out of his gourd, and listening to a stoner talk through his own movie for 100 minutes of borish and anti-climactic cinematics was probably the greatest waste of my time to this day.

reviews.review_title: A must watch movie, beautiful dialogue
reviews.content: I saw this movie for the first time in 2006, I recently watched it again in 2014 and still think I have many more viewings to go.Its just a beautiful story held together with the most amazing interactions and dialogue. This truly is a movie that will open a persons mind and let a little glimpse of something else in. Its very rare for me to actually enjoy a movie these days, everything seems to be over the top special effects and animation with no story.Im happy to say this is refreshingly the other way around... Watch this movie with a joint in hand and good friends... There will be conversation until well after the credits...

One reviewer writes:"With the tools at their fingertips, why didn't the filmmakers show us a dream instead of telling us about it?"Are you sure you're reviewing the right movie???I haven't seen a movie that so effectively simulated the experience of dreaming since "Eraserhead".

reviews.review_title: A Captivating Work of Art & An Achievement in Animation
reviews.content: This film is about dreams. But it's also about life, death, and what comes after. It's about asking questions that may not have answers. Existentialism, purpose, creativity, perspective... it's all there. Told through a trippy, yet effective animation style that puts viewers themselves in a trance-like, dream state, mirroring that of main protagonist's.The film does not contain a traditional plot arc, but rather is carried by its dialogue, its themes, and the questions and ideas it proposes to the main character, and in turn, to the viewer.With that being said, here are many of my favorite takeaway quotes from the film. Minor spoiler warning ahead; considering this film revolves primarily around its dialogue as I mentioned..."They say that dreams are only real as long as they last... Couldn't you say the same thing about life?""There's only one instant, and it's right now. And it's eternity.""The quest is to be liberated from the negative, which is really our own will to nothingness. And, once having said yes to the instant, the affirmation is contagious. It bursts into a chain of affirmations that knows no limit. To say yes to one instant, is to say yes to all of existence.""The trick is to combine your waking rational abilities with the infinite possibilities of your dreams. Because, if you can do that, you can do anything.""The reason why I refuse to take existentialism as just another French fashion or historical curiosity is that I think it has something very important to offer us... I'm afraid were losing the real virtues of living life passionately in the sense of taking responsibility for who you are the ability to make something of yourself and feel good about life. Existentialism is often discussed as if it were a philosophy of despair, but I think the truth is just the opposite. Sartre, once interviewed, said he never felt once minute of despair in his life. One thing that comes out from reading these guys is not a sense of anguish about life so much as a real kind of exuberance, of feeling on top of it, its like your life is yours to create. Ive read the post modernists with some interest, even admiration, but when I read them I always have this awful nagging feeling that something absolutely essential is getting left out. The more you talk about a person as a social construction or as a confluence of forces or as being fragmented of marginalized, what you do is you open up a whole new world of excuses. And when Sartre talks about responsibility, he's not talking about something abstract. He's not talking about the kind of self or souls that theologians would talk about. He's talking about you and me talking, making decisions, doing things, and taking the consequences. It might be true that there are six million people in this world, and counting, but nevertheless - what you do makes a difference. It makes a difference, first of all, in material terms, to other people, and it sets an example. In short, I think the message here is that we should never write ourselves off or see each other as a victim of various forces. It's always our decision who we are.""I haven't seen too many around lately... Things have been tough lately for dreamers. They say dreaming is dead, no one does it anymore. It's not dead it's just that it's been forgotten, removed from our language. Nobody teaches it so nobody knows it exists. The dreamer is banished to obscurity. Well, I'm trying to change all that, and I hope you are too. By dreaming, every day. Dreaming with our hands and dreaming with our minds. Our planet is facing the greatest problems it's ever faced, ever. So whatever you do, don't be bored, this is absolutely the most exciting time we could have possibly hoped to be alive. And things are just starting...""A self-destructive man feels completely alienated, utterly alone. He's an outsider to the human community. He thinks to himself, 'I must be insane.' What he fails to realize is that society has, just as he does, a vested interest in considerable losses and catastrophes. These wars, famines, floods and quakes meet well-defined needs. Man wants chaos. In fact, he has to have it. Depression, strife, riots, murder - all this dread. We're irresistibly drawn to that almost orgiastic state created out of death and destruction. It's in all of us. We revel in it. Sure, the media tries to put a sad face on these things and paints them up as great human tragedies. But we all know the function of the media has never been to eliminate the evils of the world - no! Their job is to persuade us to accept those evils and get used to living with them. The powers that be want us to be passive observers, and they haven't given us any other options outside the occasional, purely symbolic, participatory act of voting. "You want the puppet on the right or the puppet on the left? I feel that the time has come to project my own inadequacies and dissatisfactions into the sociopolitical and scientific schemes, let my own lack of a voice be heard.""There are two kinds of sufferers in this world: those who suffer from a lack of life and those who suffer from an overabundance of life. I've always found myself in the second category. When you come to think of it, almost all human behavior and activity is not essentially any different from animal behavior. The most advanced technologies and craftsmanship bring us, at best, up to the super-chimpanzee level. Actually, the gap between, say, Plato or Nietzsche and the average human is greater than the gap between that chimpanzee and the average human. The realm of the real spirit, the true artist, the saint, the philosopher, is rarely achieved. Why so few? Why is world history and evolution not stories of progress but rather this endless and futile addition of zeroes. No greater values have developed. Hell, the Greeks 3,000 years ago were just as advanced as we are. So what are these barriers that keep people from reaching anywhere near their real potential? The answer to that can be found in another question, and that's this: Which is the most universal human characteristic - fear or laziness?""Do you ever feel that you're observing the world you live in instead of participating in it?""On really romantic evenings of self, I go salsa dancing with my confusion."

"Waking Life" is no ordinary animated feature.  It follows a young man's journey through Austin, Texas, and through his own dreams.  The technique of interpolation used brings a new technological spin on the old animation style of rotoscoping.  And the many different animators give the movie a good abstract look.  The dialogue, though longwinded most of the time, has its interesting points.  It's the animation that keeps it from being boring! With animation, some real flights of fancy could be taken.  Like when the chimpanzee gives a lecture, or when the two men turn into clouds.  You can look at "Waking Life" as food for thought, but it's definitely a feast for the eyes!

reviews.review_title: Philosophy for Dummy comes to life
reviews.content: I think Waking Life is nothing more than a talking (in a monologue style to make things worse) introduction to contemporary philosophy (for dummy I might add).  Anybody with a Masters or even  a B.A in philosophy would have left the theater after 25 minutes, as I did.  The Director managed to go through every single major philosophy, from existentialism to taoism, without even taking a stand or actually try to SAY something.  That movie doesn't make you think ; it forbids thinking by implying that every perspective is o.k, that everything is relative.  It manages to present equally Sartre's existentialism and some New Age theory about universal telepathy, as if the two could ever be equally possible.

reviews.review_title: I knew this would be weird, but...
reviews.content: I never thought it could be this strange. Some parts weren't entirely necessary (the scene in the jail, and the bar scene that ends in two guys getting shot), but everything else worked. The best part is (possibly could ruin the movie up here) they never told you if that main character woke up for real or had another false awakening. Plus, the final images were rather confusing--another plus.The animation was especially good, to where you could think that they hadn't really filmed this in live action at all. (Note: Part of the live action "Waking Life" was shown on the DVD--and it seemed more like a documentary than a normal film.)Go see this unless you have very little idea of how to pay attention to a film.

Trust me. I was as skeptical of "Waking Life" as anyone. When I finally saw it, however, I was impressed. The movie combines trippy animation with philosophical dialogue that mainly concerns life, death, and the possibility that the three are more alike than we think.So  naturally, "Waking Life" is probably not for everyone. It should have appeal for the open-minded, the patient, and the adventurous. I doubt if you've seen anything like it before.

reviews.review_title: Bad drawing and plot puts me off to continue watching this movie!
reviews.content: I just couldn't just watch the whole movie further, the drawings just made me feel nauseous and really dizzy. Animated movies with drawing are rarely bad and this is my second film to admit that it had poor lousy drawing. The first film I have thought had very poor drawing was Kick-Heart, definitely Waking Life and it really resemble one another! I'm not denying it, its just one of the dreadful animated films I've seen!If they provided a better artist, this would make things easier. Especially with the plot. The plot about a man having various dreams because of being a drug addict, makes it just distasteful. I know drug addiction is out there and it is reality, but I felt they were making fun of it and its not really fair tbh since so that's why I give the movie a 1. No questions asked!

reviews.review_title: The story of small people trying to have big thoughts
reviews.content: I like the movie "Waking life," it defies an easy category of either a good or bad movie. If anything this movie could be classified as a "movie of interest." This means one does not watch this film for entertainment or family night but for the personal experience. My opinion is this film is a dark comedy of such a high order that most people will miss the point. The point being, we are small people trying to have big thoughts only to fail miserably. In a way, it is funny if it were not so depressing watching the emptiness each event leaves on the characters after all is said and done (like a 95% incomplete file download over and over). Using animation was a good touch that further flattens or heightens the mostly trivial moments and forces one to listen to the ultimately pointless dialog. Some argue that there is a philosophy of deep meaning embedded in the dialogs but in the end what good comes of it all? It's life with lots of meat and potatoes, with all the meat picked out. If you like interesting movies about the meaning (futility) of life, you will like this one.

*"Waking Life" could not come at a better time. Opening in these sad and fearful days after sept.11, it celebrates a series of intelligent characters who seek out the meaning of their existence and do not have the answers. At a time when madmen think they have the right to kill us because of what they think they know about an afterlife, which is unknowable, those who don't know the answers are the only ones asking sane questions.*The characters walk around passionately discussing ideas, theories, and life. The movie is beautiful in its visual style. This film seems alive, seems vibrating with urgency and excitement. The animation is curiously realistic. The most difficult thing for an animator may be to capture an unplanned movement that expresses personality. By filming real people and then animating them, "Waking Life" captures little moments of real life.****SPOILERS AHEAD****THE PLOTThe film is about a man going from one person to another, trying to wake up from what the film calls a lucid dream. However, is this man dead or is he in a lucid dream? Is anything real or is it a dream?The film talks about philosophy and the meaning of life, but what is the meaning of life? At the end of the film the main character thinks he's awake but then he starts flying to the heavens. Is that a dream or is he dead? Well, near the end the main character talks to yet another character who gives him a detailed account of a dream that he had about the valley of death. Therefore, I associated those two scenes, and maybe when the last character told him to wake up, perhaps he finally stops dreaming and ascends to heaven because he is dead. That's just my theory.Maybe we're dreams, maybe we're memories of a past life, I don't know, but do I know that this is a great film. I recommend this film highly and I give it a 15 out of 10.NOTE:  * These two paragraphs came from Roger Ebert's review.

There has been quite a bit of debate over this flick, both at the time of its release and now online. It was the dichotomy of views that first attracted me to this movie. Anything that stirred people (both the intelligent variety, and otherwise) must be worth at least the matinée prices and the two hours of my life spent watching the movie. Boy was I wrong. I came out of this movie thoroughly unentertained, unenlightened, and unwilling to ever subject myself to the writer/director's work ever again. He did redeem himself with some of his later work, so I eventually relented of my personal boycott of him. But I digress. Waking Life is little more than a self-involved, well-read, mental masturbation fest. Linklater does nothing more than give all of his friends five minutes in front of a camera to narcissistically show off and then attempt (badly) to knit these segments into a movie.On the flip-side, the animation was fantastic, it conveyed the feel and lent itself very effectively to the texture that Linklater was trying for. It's too bad it was wasted on such a lousy script.****************Spoiler Alert*************************For those who haven't seen the movie, here is a quick outline of the entire storylineBlah, blah, blah, Kierkegaard, blah Blah, blah, blah, existentialism, blah

We see the young protagonist at the end of the film trying to figure it out(thanks to the people he found during) if he is dreaming or he is dead o we can compare it(that uncertainty)to a time in our life after we finished school and we don't know what to do ("I have to study I have to work I wanna be an artist or I wanna be rich or just me?"). walking life it's about to become a ` conscious' dreamer.The film is a philosophical search to find  our position in  life(did I start boring you?),a plausible rebellion.There's wonderful outstanding moments in the movie like the young  'self destructive' man that later burned himself!;the anger criminal inside his prison  who pronounce a diatribe and says that we will kill everyone after he is out free(maybe he will never get free anyway) or when the  Director himself (Richard Linklater) appears telling an incredible anecdote to the confusing protagonist about the deja vu of the writer Phillipe Dick. As Calderón de la Barca would title his famous book "life is dream". 8/10

reviews.review_title: Endlessly innovative and engrossing treatise on dreams and reality
reviews.content: Whenever a renowned director experiments with the cinematic form or otherwise strays from the mainstream which helped establish them in the first place, the results are usually varied. Sometimes the director happens upon a batch of genius, a remarkable innovation which in some way impacts the industry around the, but other times the director becomes caught up in their own artistic cunning, making the end result too self-indulgent to be anywhere near effective. Richard Linklater's Waking Life is far more on the side of the spectrum of the former, but its occasional foray into the latter is what prevents it from being as tight and effective a piece as it could have been - but either way, so resoundingly different from almost anything which preceded it that it makes for compelling viewing regardless.To not be taken aback by such a distinctly different vision, the film must be viewed with certain expectations in mind, as well as having dispelled certain preconceptions: contrary to initial belief, there is a narrative and continuing storyline, albeit a very loose and often subtle one, punctuated by academics sounding off on their metaphysical areas of expertise, as superbly named protagonist Wiley Wiggins wanders through the uncertain blurring of his dreams and waking life, attempting to differentiate the two and shake himself out of his predicament. And while it is true that the bulk of the film is a series of talking heads (some real life academics, some actors) spewing out philosophical musings, the underlying thematic links, mainly focusing on the notions of free will, the nature of reality, and "lucid dreaming" or controlling one's subconscious dream state do prove fascinating, and often open up lines of thought seldomly exposed to public consciousness. With that in mind, there is little question that even for the most tenaciously dedicated viewers, the film will perplex, confuse, and likely even completely lose them at certain times, though there remains an underlying suspicion that, due to its subject matter, this may be Linklater's intention. One is left continually wondering if the staggering thematic content is always meant to make sense or be followed entirely - after a series of intense theoretical philosophical monologues, Wiggins, interacting with a friend claims "I had a bunch of weird dreams where people were just sounding off about random whatever", suggesting that to some degree the audience is expected to be lost and that this will not detract from one's experience of the film. Either way, certain threads prove more engaging than others, and it is this intermittent, fluctuating nature that is both the film's greatest strength and most prominent flaw all at once. For every engaging or thought provoking vignette there is the occasional one which either appears so out of place or frustratingly impossible to follow that an inevitable sense of frustration is provoked. Characters drift in and out, often straying entirely from what appears to be the slowly gestating story or point, making the film as a whole feel too patchwork to be anywhere near as effective as it could have been. Again, considering the thematic content of the film there remains a continual unspoken justification for the fluctuating quality of the film ("it might all be a dream and dreams are nonsensical"), but such an excuse becomes tiresomely repetitive and eventually fails to hold up. However, Linklater's rotoscoping effect (animating over live action performances) certainly adds to the disorienting, dream state of the film, but the frequently fluctuating animation styles prove distracting and often uncomfortable to watch (the animation of certain characters wavering to the point of inducing nausea), but overall the novelty fails to wear thin, remaining more compelling than irritating. Similarly, the edgy, bizarre score proves entirely right for a film which exemplifies the above qualities, seeming to transport the viewer to an alternate state of reality. Despite the inevitable criticisms, Waking Life remains a feat of staggering intelligence and creativity, a daring testament to the ability of audiences to concentrate and think instead of simply watching explosions or inane soap opera exchanges. While the patchwork of metaphysical ruminations may waver in quality or effectiveness, the stark originality of Linklater's work makes the film endlessly compelling and captivating, even in the midst of the occasional frustration. Simply put, Waking Life is undoubtedly unlike anything the majority of viewers have ever seen before, and for good or for bad, this fiercely unique vision deserves to be commended.-8/10

"Waking Life" is one of those films that makes you just want to hug and fawn over everyone who was involved in its making. These people have won my respect and admiration for having such incredible creative abilities. They've crafted a truly unique piece of art that is undeniably beautiful to look at and experience. The complex, fascinating journey is that of a one Wiley Wiggins, an everyday, sullen young teenager for whom life is suddenly resembling a string of surreal interactions and observations of various characters. These people range from the mundane and long-winded, to the plucky and thought-provoking, to the absolutely strange and endearing. I found myself perfectly engaged in the sometimes intense discussions for which I collected my own thoughts - sometimes disagreeing, but mostly agreeing. I'm a fairly open-minded person, and as such, I think this was a very pleasant experience, as I really love to see these types of scenes that are less action and more just simple, casual talk. Of course, the hypnotic and fluid animation (filtered over scenes that were originally live-action and shot in digital video) only served to heighten the interest, and keep the attention constantly focused on the issues. I must say, a lot of these opinions were extremely refreshing to hear; Richard Linklater should be given tremendous kudos for being able to write and direct such a rich, philosophical milestone. I can understand some of the more confused and hostile reactions towards such an odd, unconventional picture, but to someone who personally relishes the chances some filmmakers take, this risky venture pays big, BIG dividends. If you're not the type of viewer who enjoys being pummeled with an overload of words and abstract thought, this film probably isn't for you. I'm sure it's one of those things you just have to be in the mood for - a mood to be entertained, AND enlightened.

Arrgh! I missed the euphemism for cartoon (animation) on this website and rented the DVD only to be sorely disappointed to find "Waking Life" was all animation. Okay, my bad. But there's nothing special in the wobblemation, that herky-jerky type of animation which could give someone motion sickness. Because I fast forwarded through it, I can't talk about the quality of the story or the drama, etc. Just know, this is a CARTOON before you commit to watching it.

reviews.review_title: Like no experience you will ever have watching a movie.
reviews.content: As stunning visually with its revolutionary and surprisingly low budget animation, as its intelecual value this is the film that most lyrically puts the mind frame of the year 2001 into a visual and smooth work of art. Films, dreams, and well, life are discussed in a manner like none other; part quasi-documentary, and part Spike Lee feel, this is a time capsule, a film to be watched, and treasured for the ages.

It is rare that a filmmaker can immerse his audience in an exceedingly unique and gripping atmosphere (the last times this happened was with U-Turn, Element of Crime, and Mystery Train) and it is even rarer that a filmmaker can accomplish something miraculous in such an atmosphere. Richard Linklater's Waking Life is that kind of achievement. It was filmed in Austin with live actors and then the footage was digitally animated on Mac Computers. As a result, each image is wildly alive giving the film a dizzying waviness and vibrancy. Describing the effect of this visual style is impossible but what is quite remarkable is that the film is stylized this way for a reason: It is about a young man (Wiley Wiggins) stuck in a dream world (or some sort of alternate reality) meeting dozens over dozens of people on the city streets. These characters talk and talk about fascinating concepts involving philosophy, sociology, exobiology, and, as the movie progresses and our nameless protagonist realizes that he is in a dream, lucid dreaming (the ability to realize that you are in a dream) is discussed more and more. Wiley Wiggins is one of the most underrated actors (his performance in Dazed and Confused is impossible to forget). It is surprising that he can evoke such a complex character when he is not allowed to have any character development in the story; he gives delicate vibes of social awkwardness, fear, and desperation. His lucid dream soon (I'd hate to use this cliché but) becomes a nightmare from which he is unable to awaken. In the end of the film, as he flies off into the sky, the tone is bittersweet: he may never be able to wake up but what is better than being trapped in one's endless curiosity? That is the point of the film: it is an exquisite ode to curiosity and what happens when a film encourages curiosity? It is slapped as being pretentious, of course. Some obnoxious critics of the film encourage one to read the philosophies that these characters talk about rather than wasting time watching them talk about these philosophies. What these dunces don't realize is that this film is meant to appeal to a mainstream audience (or at least someone who isn't a philosophy major). Linklater does not dumb-down these philosophies; instead they are filtered through slackers with an extreme amount of love for the material that they talk about. (As for the actors, in the tradition of Slacker, most of them are just interesting Austin locals. Linklater has always believed that what counts in movies is personality rather than multifaceted acting technique. While most of the actors are interesting here, a few of them deliver their dialogue in a horridly lifeless tone of voice that was absent in Slacker.) What could be more fun than a journey like this?

I had high hopes for this Linklater film, but obviously more than my hopes had to be high to enjoy this pretentious dog. The ideas are lazy and sophomoric. (I saw Sliding Doors, which covered the same territory with a charming story, rather than just lecturing me.)The animation was sick-making (literally). The only movie I've walked out of in 20 years. And I sat through the equally nauseating and pretentious Breaking the Waves.

Waking Life contains ideas and theories that make you think deeper than the average film. Richard Linkletter is an incredible director of many films, each one containing fresh and intriguing ideas . Waking Life is eye-opening with its compelling and sensical ideology. The fusion between entertainment and philosophy is one-in-a-million. I highly recommend this gem for deep thinkers, anyone interested in philosophy or for simple entertainment enjoyment.

reviews.review_title: disparate philosophical ramblings from every branch, knot and sodden hole of academia
reviews.content: An hour and a half of constant, disparate philosophical ramblings from every branch, knot and sodden hole of academia doesn't sound like a barrel of laughs. For the first twenty minutes you'll probably find yourself thinking you're watching a student's naval gazing graduation piece, or some god awful Sixties 'trip'. But once the faint hints of a story start drifting in through the swaying animation of the dreamscape, you start to get in on the joke. The film scoffs as much as it expounds; which of the many views you laugh at, which you nod in agreement to and which you blink confused at will depend on you. A lot of the talk is intentionally too deep to make much sense of; other times it's too simple to take seriously. The main draw of this movie is unquestionably it's shimmering, unique and (presumably) painstaking animation, but the style is necessitated by the content. This is a wonderful drunken conversation of a film.

reviews.review_title: This just became my favourite film of all time.
reviews.content: I'm not sophisticated, nor intellectual, but I do have an appreciation for fine film. This is one of them. Amazing is the only word I could use to describe this. I have shown my peers/friends this film only to see the exact same result to mine... absolute dumb founded appreciation of its brilliance. I will die a happy man knowing that not only I may dream for up-to 16 minutes, but I may live forever in a dream state. This film is like the message of Bill Hicks in 138 minutes. Please view this film, for it contains the message that every human needs to hear. Further more, I need to add ten lines to my review to enable me to post it on this site.

reviews.review_title: much more than meets the eye..
reviews.content: A beautiful movie and also thought provoking. The paint-like animation alone makes it worthwhile.  The conceptual and spiritual framework make it extra special.  It does get a little preachy at times, but its easy to take.  And it might, just might, make you think a little more about the live you are living :) Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: "It's like I'm being prepared for something..."
reviews.content: ...probably the awakening of my cell brains ( or what's left of them)... I don't really know. All I know that this movie got to me . made me ask myself a lot of questions. too many, and too painful. kicked me hard in the ass, time to run to the library and hit those philosophy books. start with the ABC's, as I'm rather ignorant in this respect. it's not the first impulse, other certain movies and books pointed me the direction. but "waking Life" made the difference. it is the final stroke. so, maybe it's a pretentious BS, as some posters called it. maybe it's a masterpiece, as others wrote. it doesn't really matter to me. what matters is that it changed my perceptions, it made me seek answers. was this in fact the director's intention ? I wouldn't know. But I thank him for waking me up.

reviews.review_title: It can be either a complete waste of time or an enlightening and spiritual journey - just don't tell me you like it for the visuals.
reviews.content: Don't let the animation fool you, I didn't. Waking Life is a film that contains everything you'd want in a film that might make someone think they're watching something really smart but it is nothing remotely special; mainly due to the fact it has nothing of its own to actually offer. Yes, the animation produced through an Apple Mac. of its time is very impressive and yes, the aesthetical quality of realism mixed in with fiction/non-fiction is a different and alternate route for an American film to go down but try as he might, I think director Linklater just about fails here.Throughout the duration of the film, shot on digital video and then rendered into animation, we will visit several people in several different locations and hear what they have to say on life, the universe and everything. The film likes to think it has this primary strand revolving around the idea of dreams and what they mean running throughout but that is only tacked on at the end after several interviews, some laborious and some interesting, have graced the screen. I think it is the structure that is the biggest problem here as well as the visuals that so obviously take precedence over the themes. When the director and everyone else sat down to plan the film, you get the feeling everything regarding the themes and ideas were sort of secondary to how Linklater wanted the visuals and animation to look.We follow a young boy who might be asleep and dreaming; awake and dreaming or who might well have just taken too many drugs – I pray it isn't the third theory as it will only encourage drug use in fact I'm sure some people will have watched this film under the influence anyway. Throughout the journey we will follow the boy known only as 'Main Character' as he visits a number of people without motivation. All of these people will talk and talk about numerous different subjects to do with elitist theory and other such subjects, blurring whether this is a documentary or a fiction film. The trouble is, everything that these people talk about are either out of context or are already available out there in books anyway. We will cover topics such as 'Contemporary Physical Theory'; we'll engage in a 'Freedom to Live' speech as told by someone else and a young couple will have the old 'Reincarnation' debate upon waking up – a bizarre and out of sorts place to talk about such a subject in a scene that can only be viewed as an excuse to get Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke in bed together in a Richard Linklater film (Before Sunrise, anyone?) The trouble is, all these arguments are opinionated through the film by people but are they real experts or actors playing out a role and reading a script? Secondly, all these subjects have been written about and debated in previous texts such as books – you want to know why I don't know anything about 'Contemporary Physical Theory?' because I have no interest in it, as evident because I haven't actively tracked down any books in the past and studied it. So when I get someone talking to the camera (ie; myself) about it, making me feel smaller and less intelligent than they are, I am wasting my time and feeling small in the process. This sensation is evident at least for me, I am sure because during one such segment in which the camera tracks in on an animated cinema screen featuring two people, a new debate opens up. This debate was all about the point of view when watching a film and how the camera directs the eye and the audience watch the action through another means of watching. I recognised this work as Andre Bazin's and sure enough; the character on the right talking notes the work as Bazin's. The point here is that I have tracked down this writing and read it so when I receive this segment, I get something out of it and it feels good – do those that like this film actually understand every single piece to camera the film offers? I doubt it. I only liked what I understood/have an interest in, most others are probably kidding themselves.I also find the scene in which a browned out author writing in a café talking about things a little silly. I feel this is writer/director Linklater himself in another form. The author sits there and tells us about a piece that is disconnected and has everyone floating in and out of everything else – this is clearly Linklater telling (or perhaps reminding) us through a character what his idea for the film is; he is telling us what structure we're literally seeing just in case we're not sure in what can only be labelled as a failsafe attempt to cover up if the film failed. When such an audacious film is made, there is very chance it might fail and this was a silly inclusion that had no place.Waking Life is a film that would have a long haired stoner-buddy talk in depth and at length about dreams and realities etc. It's film in which a young couple would talk about the age old debate to do with reincarnation – upon waking up. Waking Life relies on its animation to visually get across its 'wow' factor. Much like Shrek, good animation but if anybody over a certain level actually admits to liking it then they are either kidding themselves or have some serious maturing to do. The film is a triumph in its attempt to be a breakaway, artistic experiment but take away the gimmick and it is merely several 'piece to camera' scenes revolving predominantly around subjects you might not usually give ten seconds of your time to.

this was i great movie and i don't now why no one wouldn't like it...........the animation was really cool,and I've never seen anything quite like it, but id like to,kinda makes you sick sometimes, but still really cool, and the story is great too........................................its about a guy and his dream, that he cant seem to wake up from, meeting lots of strange unique characters, discussing strange but interesting things about life and everything around them may be a little boring sometimes but still amazing, i strongly recommend it!!

reviews.review_title: 'toons and philosophical enquiries meld surprisingly well
reviews.content: Where to start with this one? First of all, it's visually impressive (though not absolutely mind-blowing as some have said...if you've seen a lot of animation, you've probably seen plenty of stuff this inventive), making the best use of rotoscoping (animated tracing over live-action figures, with animated backgrounds) that I've seen in a feature; it's got a fairly ambitious intellectual conceit (a man who may or may not be on the verge of death throughout the film dreams in a lucid way about what the nature of reality, consciousness, free will, etc really are); it's got great music (by Glover Gill)...what more could you want? Well, for starters, it works out to be not much more than philosophical ramblings, and I think to some extent it wears out its welcome. Now, if you knew me you'd know I often like long movies...I have no problem with a lot of work that a lot of people call "slow"; but this was to me too much of the same thing. And some of the observations are facile in a druggy-stoner way that just made me think, who cares? Still, adding it up, I'm thinking about it quite a lot since I watched the excellent, feature-packed DVD a couple of years ago. Another aspect I really liked was the self-referentiality: the film as a whole is very reminiscent of the director's first feature, "Slacker", it contains a short scene with Jesse and Celine, the characters from the previous "Before Sunrise" that also obviously looks forward to "Before Sunset"; the technique used and some of the more fantastic imagery seems now a tryout for last year's rotoscoped Philip K Dick adaptation, "A Scanner Darkly", and both Linklater and his good friend (and fellow experimental-at-times filmmaker) Steven Soderbergh make appearances. And there's a scene or two late in the film that is reminiscent of the work of another extremely self-referential artist, the experimental American SF writer Samuel R. Delany (specificially, his 1000-page Joycean "Dhalgren").I need to see it again; reading some pretty intelligent reviews this afternoon leads me to believe that a deeper reading would be more rewarding. Despite many reservations, I'm giving it high marks simply for attempting subject matter and film techniques that nobody else in America seems interested in. Linklater has proved himself a great disciple of European art cinema, not just the usual Scorsese-Coppola-DePalma stuff, and that's all to the good.

I had never seen a film like this. The imagining of the film was very original. This is an exploration of consciousness. While watching the film it was as though I was dreaming. I could not really process the film but I let it just slide all over me and then later I thought about the implications of the film. How can we know whether we are dreaming? Are our lives real? If we were dreaming, would we know? One observation by the character who I believe was dressed in the manner of an everyday kind of guy, maybe he was a musician too; I remember he was sitting in a big, spacious room and I think there were a couple of other older guys in the room. Anyway, the character said that if you can control your dreams, that's progress in controlling your dream state. In which case, it would be recognition that you are dreaming. And I'm sure that many of us have done that. I know I have, particularly if a hot woman was involved in the dream :) Anyway, this was obviously a labor of love for Linklater. He employs some of his regular actors and as a former resident of the great city of Austin, it was great to recognize many of the locations where he shot. Linklater is an American original; maybe not of Jarmusch's stature yet; well, definitely not, but his films are always worth checking out; whether you like them or not, he's an original. This is strikingly original, visually, and a thought-provoking film unlike any you've ever seen, I'd hazard a guess. Sort of like Austin actually.

Have you ever wondered about the quotes that run with movie ads, touting them as `Mesmerizing!'  `Revolutionary!!' or `One of the Year's Best!' when you know the films are dogs? A scandal this past summer (in which an overzealous marketer made up several glowing reviews for a below average film), revealed the existence, of the `Quote Whores'.  These are reviewers who will write a good review for a film and may then get favorable treatment from the studio in the future (private screenings, etc).  While it may not be illegal (smells like payola to me), it definitely borders on immoral and certainly triggers the cynic in me when I come across a glowing review. 
Watching a film at 10:00 am is tough enough (I am not a morning person), but a lousy night's sleep, makes it far more challenging.  As it turns out, I was in the ideal state of mind for the screening at hand.  `Waking Life' is an unconventional film with only the barest bones of a plot  the main character is asleep and can't seem to wake up.  In his journey to reenter a waking state, he floats from dream to dream, hoping that the next segue will relieve him.  Filmed as live action, each dream sequence was then animated by one of the thirty animators on the project, some with vastly differing styles.  Unconventional doesn't necessarily mean better.The animation techniques range from simple tracings of the cells in which the characters are easily identifiable (the sequence with Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy has barely been altered) to surrealist fantasies that make you wonder if the creator had some hallucinogenic inducements.  The dynamic styling of the sequences is visually stimulating, sometimes bordering on overwhelming, but your attention is constantly drawn to the screen.   Had they chosen to run these images with an equally bombastic soundtrack this film would be absolutely riveting.  At least it would have drowned out the dialogue.Each `dream' is discussion between new characters that try to divine the meaning of dreams.  The discussions touch on myriad esoteric topics ranging from existentialism, cosmology, freewill, determinism, to Gnosticism.  Very cerebral stuff, and interesting  to some.  I was caught up in several of the conversations, such as the concept of lucid dreaming, where one character mentions that you know you're in a dream when you can't adjust the lighting levels (something I've been trying without success).  Other discussions however prove to be so abstruse that the most fervent philosophy student would run screaming for the exits, or slip into their own dream states. Waking Life is an adventurous film that will draw the art house/Mensa crowd wherever it plays and should elicit deserved `oohs' and `aahs' for its visual imagery.  The film may even spark some discussion at the coffee houses afterwards.   Note, however, if you're looking for light entertainment, action, repeating characters or a plot, this is not the film for you.

Ever come across a person at coffee shop, or party that is just so far from being clued in that it is upsetting. Your know the one that I'm talking about, the dreamer. ..but not the educated dreamer, you know like Einstein or Teslabut the one that took a couple of psychiatry classes at some community college, or even worse, some much bigger pretentious college or university and he or she thinks that they 'know so much', or 'knows what life is all about'. I'm talking about the conceited 'pot-head' psycho babble. Damn is that annoying, and so counter productive. Man, just thinking about it is pissing me off. Anywho, try sitting down and watching some crappy animation (crappy because it was done just to do it.come on guys, that's not art) with the characters talking just to hear themselves talk. This was the biggest waste of time that I have had in my life outside of the DMV. Makes you wish that mercy-killings were allowed. Go get a root canal instead, it will be much more fun.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Great Films Of Our Decade
reviews.content: Man wakes up in a dream, and then into another, and then another, etc. One of the few movies, I have watched, then sat for 10 minutes, then watched immediately again. The narrative is made up of conversations and lectures from real people(often actors playing actors and professors playing professors, etc), who were then animated over, in technology developed specifically for this film(now being seen advertisements). The subject of these dream discussions include identity, free will, evolution, language, rebellion, apathy, conversation, sex, film, God, death, dreams, memories, etc. Some vignettes are funny, some disturbing, some pretentious, some relaxed engaging, some didactic, some inquisitive, and others more like poems aborted mid-stream. This is not a plot driven film, it's a series of vignettes not unlike an earlier Linklater film "Slacker"(if you liked this movie, Slacker is the 90's no-budget equivalent). If you enjoy thinking for thinking's sake, putting ideas together and then taking them apart like building blocks, you will enjoy this movie. Few films have had quite the impact on me that this did the first time around, I showed it to just about everyone I knew, and while a few gave me the standard "What the f*&k is this, s*&t's weird", more than a few were left just as blown away as I was. Cynics will of course associate this film with a coffee shop, no attention span culture, jittering pretentious ideas being typed a mile a minute by spectacled hipsters, etc. However this is an unfortunate reduction of a film, that has generated more interesting ideas in it's first 15 minutes alone than most film's do after years of academic discussion. Watching this movie made me feel aware for the first time, that I was no longer living in the 20th century, that things were and could be different, and that new languages and systems would have to be made to describe and implement new experiences and new ways of doing things, this movie was the beginning... perhaps I was getting a bit ahead of myself, but that's what I liked about this movie, it's own grandeur, ridiculousness, and ambition are infectious and life affirming, where often films of this artistic caliber can be obtuse or de-humanizing. There are no characters to empathize here with, just ideas and beautiful visuals(from dozens of animators with varying styles), so if your not to interested in the discussion you can always just tune out and watch the colors dance, it's as much a treat for the eyes as it is a delight for the brain, as well as ears, the "Tosca Tango Orchestra" perform the music, which keeps everything swirling at a nice pace. I could go on like this forever, it's a good movie see it, if not see something else.

reviews.review_title: This movie ties in beautifully with the direction the world is going in...
reviews.content: I feel that the point of this movie about lucid dreaming is that we can achieve almost anything, when we learn to be conscious within our dreams. That's when we can start to create our own life, cause life starts in our mind.The visuals in the movie are quite inspirational and extremely well done. And the views in the movie are brought to us in layman's terms so that we can all enjoy old and new philosophy's alike and hopefully use them to our advantage.I'm just glad that someone's finally addressed the issue of dreaming versus creation and done it in such a genius way too.If you can dream it, you can do it!

When I first began watching this, I said to myself, (this thing better not be animated all the way through). But it is, and what a pleasant surprise! The very beginning is adorable with the little girl asking him to pick a color, any color.  From that point on the movie grows into a voyage for the meaning of life.  The main character is often confused of how and why the subjects enter his world, but each end up offering valuable lessons with penetrating and burning impressions.  This is one movie you can watch over and over each time discovering something different.  It's a masterpiece!

reviews.review_title: Made me think about the things that go on around me.
reviews.content: I did not really get into the dream/waking part as much as what each of the people he encountered said.  The evolution guy made so much sense and just opened my eyes to realize a few things that are going on around me.  I also really enjoyed the 2 women in the coffee shop talking about the baby photo, and how we have to tell a story to make ourselves link to that photo.  I know I do this all of the time when explaining pictures to people, but I never really thought of it like that.  "That guy's all action and no theory, we're all theory but no action."  One of the many great lines from that movie.  I want to watch the movie all over again with a pad and pen to write down all of the amazing quotes.  I did not agree with what everyone said in the movie, like the guy in jail, but I know someone out there related to that scene.

This film is one of the most masterful successes of independent cinema. The scenes move from one to the other in a work of art. The ramblings in the dialogue represents a passion in all existence and their struggle to figure things out.Why am I here? What am I doing? Who will I find? The answer is nobody really knows and there are infinitely many amounts of reasons for why people exist in a certain place and a certain time. Never has a film empowered me by its curiosity and direct dialogue that makes you feel like a part of this "dream" that is someone's life in his dying hours, or his awakening. Existence is eternal.9/10 for the reason that its complex and constant dialogue weighs down the movie midway.

This movie is a feast for the eyes. It is sumptuously designed and choreographed to move like a living painting, to show how the realism can be surrealism. By having Waking Life open these doors, the possibilities are unlimited. But instead of really transporting the audience the way that 2001: A Space Odyssey did in 1968, the overall effect feels like a 500-level college philosophy lecture class.That is the main problem with this film, it starts out by displaying an unconventional and revolutionary method of film animation that hasn't been attempted before and starting the audience off with the phrase: "Dream is Destiny." Okay, so we're in for a surrealistic journey, cool. But then we're introduced to the conventional way of opening up a film with a journey by having the main character be picked up in a boat/car and dropped off "where he needs to be." From there, the main character is hit by a car and wakes up to have people lecturing to him in long and drawn out monologues. By this point, the film has see-sawed from unconventional to conventional back to being unconventional, never deciding if it wants to have a direction, or play like and animated documentary. The audience isn't interacted with, it's talked down to from a vacuous script posing as intellectualism.Fine, so you want to be a lecture film. What will the lecture be? Pretty much, simple stuff that anyone with half a mind and an open ear had heard before. So where does this "experience" of a film take us? Really nowhere. The film seems to want the audience to make up their own mind about what was "lectured" to them (as if the people who generally make up the audience for these type of empty existential indie flicks have never sat through a long and drawn out philosophy discussion before). But as for the character whose journey we are supposed to follow, he comes to no realization or achieves any kind of catharsis, he simply "floats away." Overall, "Waking Life" is ingeniously designed, but overall an empty experience that plays as if someone animated an adaptation of a philosophy book that has already been covered. So this film gets my Zyrtek Indie Film Award, which is handed out to filmmakers with good concepts, but turn out to be self-proclaimed indie geniuses who mourn the fact that they are in a position that millions of film students wish they were in. These "artists" seem to enjoy writing movies about figuring life out when they seem to hardly grasp it themselves and instead sink into a quagmire of frustration, disillusionment, self-loathing which leads to self-praise (a cycle which seems endless for them) which overall leads to their clinical depression. Previous recipients of this award include Wes Anderson (Rushmore) and Lars von Trier (Dancer in the Dark). But a three out of four star film nonetheless, if only for the well-designed and well-meaning animation.

"Super perfundo on the early eve of your day." We get what we want out of most movies; we get good guys and bad guys, lines of dialogue that make us think, romantic playfulness, maybe some laughs and/or tears, and we walk away feeling as though we have experienced some sides of life that we wish that we had more time to explore in our own. We also, of course get some stuff that we don't want, like bad acting that distracts us, overwrought plots that deceive us, characters that we think we could either have gone without or wish that we could take home with us. Nonetheless, movies are our escape and as much as we dislike admission that we see a lot (maybe too many), sometimes it's exactly what we need.So, with that being said about the art of drama, we can now also look at the other side of film-making. The documentary has been another element in film, that has existed since the invention of the camera. The early part of the 20th century, for example was filled with propaganda pieces as well as informational and exploratory films. Fact, as opposed to fiction, has the mirror effect of education in the movie-making business. Here, we see that although a broad brush has painted film as an escape, another canvas has exposed a return to reality. Important to note, of course, is that there aren't a substantial amount of documentaries that attempt to encompass the entirety of human existence. Documentaries, instead, tend to focus on a particular area of study, compiling both facts and opinions that are intended to give us glimpses of those parts of life that we can be unconsciously overlooking in our daily routines.In not only providing the audience with entertainment in realistic ways, but letting the same audience come to points of interest at their own pace and retain their abilities of judgment and thought, you might wonder how much of an escape is actually being given to people in need of such. Especially in a time of world disaster, poverty, repression, and terrorism, you might expect that we'd be seeing the better part of ourselves wanting to forget, to regret mistakes, to live in an alternate dimension of purity in wholesome rehabilitation.However, we have gotten somewhat of a different reaction from a variety of places."It's up to each and every one of us to turn loose of just some of the greed, the hatred, the envy, and yes, the insecurities, because that is the central mode of control, make us feel pathetic, small, so we'll willingly give up our sovereignty, our liberty, our destiny.""Waking Life", points out that there is no need to seek truth, when subjectivity will ultimately confuse our relations. It takes a seldom traveled path, where we accept that we will meet people whose ideas may have evidence but whom we will never be able to share even what amounts to a single shared experience in life. It's not because they don't intrigue us, or that the concepts they speak about don't ring bells. Only because we have the understanding that life is temporal do we learn to move on.Through the idea that we have the ability to lucid dream in a state of unconsciousness, we can learn without processing thoughts or having recognition of natural instinct and rely on intuition alone. Often we have dreams with themes, some so progressed that they will reappear. This film exhibits the message that as a consequence of us contrasting existence with existentialist thought, it will undoubtedly result with conflicting viewpoints, in the way it was translated onto video, alone. Taken from an actual film crew with camera equipment, and then given to the hands of enhanced creative animation illustrators. The improvised yet informed and intellectual conversations become rhythmic with personal impressions whose sole works are our personal complexities inherited through time itself. However, we never lose sight of the fact that pedestrians exist if only as members of an eternal connection who can perceive the emotion.It is with this film that instead of unwarranted commitment and loyalty we are assisted with the inward reflection of values, and learn the virtuous curiosity which accompanies the purpose of change through life, and ultimately the afterlife. We learn that the quest is what with as complete authenticity as the dream of life, under the constant conditions of time and truth, personifies the undefined belief system. There have been multiple instances of generation, yet the eternal beginning is enough that we have experience of the essence of life long before we even have science or reference.This is the interpretation that I choose, that many critics have overlooked. I propose that the theme of this movie is more about birth than death. "Waking Life", although based on the extremity of uncertainties, is in my eye, less than guaranteeing the prophecy of the end to our human spirit. It isn't even guessing that you'll die without knowing the grandness of our universe. It is quite simply telling you that you'll always be positive of your soul's origin, everything that will happen to you is a prescription of morality, with decreasing potency as distance increases, until the inevitably and infinitely mysterious unforeseeable end of action. The film, in my opinion, implies that we are witnessing the poetic birth of a soul into the sphere of life.All in all, Linklater has broken the mold of film production. His reminiscent air of nostalgia for the loss of time as golden as spent, does justice to the robbers of the human spirit, as the emotional outlook that captures us all when we look into the eyes of a photo album and feel the burden of a succession of guilt over the advancement of dreams."Dream is destiny." "Waking Life" (2001) 10/10

reviews.review_title: The talking heads of a stunted generation
reviews.content: A negative review writes itself. Oft penned by Philosophy graduates whom couldn't bear another lecture. But for serious cinefiles and owners of the Slacker Criterion DVD, Waking Life is off for a different reason. DVD supplemental outtakes from all of Richard Linklater's films drawn out to feature length and animated. With the director's tag "an experimental film told in an experimental way". It is neither. Starting with technique: The program used was not far removed from Adobe Flash, which over the last 7 years has revolutionised animation. Enabling anyone with a computer to animate professional quality shorts and have them seen on the world stage through the internet. Linklater shot the "film" on a bog-standard 'baby's first steps/wedding video' DV camera, and left the animating to a rather large consort of animators (par for the course for any animation student). Some knew the program layout and limitations, but showed rudimentary animation skills, whilst the opposite is obvious of others. In one scene eyes move independently of the head, background elements like cars are rendered as blue and red blobs, and the constant motion of things will make you seasick. The individual stamp of each animator it not evident when the majority were simply tracing around the lines out of inexperience. Some animators used the format to animate the philosophies and give life to an otherwise bland lecture, which is only really successful in two scenes. Linklater and crew were so keen to be first out of the gate that they didn't tie their laces, running a production that was unfolding as it went along had them tripping over each other.It wasn't uncommon for animation students to film a day in their mundane lives, tack on existentialism and obscure music, spend a few weeks rotoscoping and present the finished short as an end of year project a few years before this "film's" release. In keeping with all of Linklater's work, it can not help feeling like an overblown student project. Like The Matrix, it was new-ish technique exacerbated in a feature trying to justify its own existence. Smoke and mirrors.The philosophies and theories are presented at elementary level. Some by professors, others by obnoxious left-wing radio DJs and actors. This isn't "pretentious", it's patronising. Cut from a balding Prof. to a deleted scene from Slacker or Before Sunrise. Going from a man who's put in years of study to a glib actor reciting Linklater's own half-baked drivel. Wiley Wiggins plays the gormless stoned adolescent "Wh..Wha?" As surrogate audience member he is perfect. It is hard to imagine anyone over nineteen wanting to see a repackaging of Slacker (without the charm of 90's zeitgeist to carry it). That aside, Waking Life isn't memorable. You won't quote it, you won't question or evaluate its philosophies or be moved by the flat ending.Richard Linklater, like his fanboy Kevin Smith, comes from a generation of stunted growth. Just as Smith never grew out of prepubescence, Linklater never grew out of first-year college enthusiasm. A never ending headache of quotes out of context, glib sound bites said in a monotone desperately searching for pitch. At his age, it is embarrassing to witness.

reviews.review_title: Fodder for Pseudo-Intellectual Types, but Still Amazing

With this film, Linklater is basically reminding us not to take life too seriously (hence the use of children, construction paper in this scene), because we know nothing more of it than that which we can understand of our own inscrutable dreams.

reviews.review_title: Slacker II, Kant's Dialectics and Rotoscope
reviews.content: Richard Linklater's Waking Life is a lengthy series of strung-together monologues and other scenes featuring pop philosophy and Reader's Digest versions of several age-old metaphysical and epistemological ideas about the nature of reality. The film centers, perhaps, on the protagonist's main dilemma - that he believes himself to be caught in a multi-layered dream and can not wake up. His attempts to seek help result in the lengthy, quasi-intellectual discourses that comprise the bulk of the film.These discourses could have been lifted from Linklater's first film, the excellent "Slacker". Many of the scenes, despite the rotoscope animation technique, are paced, scripted and filmed exactly as Slacker was, and some even involve actors which appeared in Slacker. The major differences between Slacker and Waking Life are the fact that Waking Life has an identifiable theme which serves as a loosely arranged plot, and Slacker is not animated. Slacker functions best as an introduction to the postmodern, anti-responsibility ethic permeating intellectual life around the University of Texas at Austin. Like the dream-state of Waking Life's main character, Linklater does not seem able to fully extricate himself from this cultural milieu.The rotoscope animation technique is interesting and adds a lot of visual interest to the film. The acting is terrific, but the script bases character development on the philosophical content of the soliloquies, leaving out most non-verbal communication and giving each character essentially the same discursive style, delivery and pacing. Only two characters are actually developed - "Main Character" (Wiley Wiggins) and "others" (everybody else in the film). Ultimately, it is not easy to care a great deal about what happens in the film because, throughout it, the main character's dream-state may result in a radical revision of everything at any given moment.Waking Life could have been the great, innovative film that many believe it to be. Unfortunately, the script's monotony and overemphasis on pretentious, pop-philosophical epistemological exposition detract from the film's artistry. Linklater should have, at least, collaborated on this script. He needed many more than one voice, and a lot more than a few forms of delivery to get this set of messages across.

Waking Life is a stirring film, made in an attempt to better allow fellow humans to understand their reality and what they perceive by being exposed to as many varying degrees of philosophy as possible.  Though centered around a young man who is unable to wake from what he perceives to be his dream state, the real meaning and true essence of the film is exhibited by the distinctly, and at times opposing, varying philosophies attempting to explain why we perceive things the way that we do.  Sometimes they use science, while others use religion; as the young man continues his journey through his own mind.  Leaning a great deal towards the stranger side of philosophy, this film isn't for everyone, I highly enjoyed the animation that appeared in the film because I felt like it added a great deal to the ambience and helped better explain the feel of the young man's endless waking; however some people found it to be a big distraction.  If you are some how put off at all by the idea that they filmed this movie and then had people animate it, then I would recommend that you don't even try to sit through this because the camera work and constantly shifting art styles will not amuse you.  Anyone into experimental art should really enjoy his film, the art work is at times exquisite and at others' poignantly shaky and sloppy.  The artwork is perfectly suited for the film and I think that they did a really excellent job casting the roles for this movie, because you can make out a couple of people but they don't really look like themselves so you never get that feeling of watching a movie with actors in it, making the message that much more guided and inevitable.

reviews.review_title: Gets me where I get gotten

I woke up the next morning feeling fresh as a daisy!I read some reviews and want to naysay one reviewer's claim that the various diatribes/raps/theses rolled out by the characters were repetitious; as though once you'd heard one of them, you'd heard them all.  I can't imagine what that person was thinking.  If there was any commonality between the segments, it was in the hint that even this barreling freight train litany of tabletop metaphysics represents only a handful of glimmering natural treasures lifted from an infinite beach of unlimited wonder.  This movie is an open invitation to really wake up/really go to sleep and start living our waking/dreaming lives.I can't say whether *you'd* like this movie.  I can see why some people might not feel as I do about stuff of this nature.  If you like it, you like it:  If you don't, you don't.  It's worth renting, on a lark.  It reminds me of how my wife and I *loved* "Slacker."  We heartily recommended it to some film-loving neighbors.  They rented it and found it utterly senseless; but they found out something about themselves!But--hey!--the animation is great!  My only reservation here is that, while it bothered me none, I intuitively "felt" for viewers whom I feared might succumb to seasickness; everything is constantly shimmying and swimming all over the place.  A conscious or unconscious paeon to Sartre's "La Nausée", mayhaps?

Filmed as an indie quickie before going through its arduous and peculiar rotoscoping process in post, Waking Life is Richard Linklater's 2001 ode to the existential. Wiley Wiggins plays... well, who-knows-who, a young man drifting through a series of encounters with a range of characters (played by various actors including Linklater regulars Ethan Hawke, Julie Delpy and Adam Goldberg), all delivering unto him dense philosophical monologues or dialogues. The plot is as faint as a half-remembered dream; although it is implied that Wiggins' protagonist is killed by a car at the start, and I got the sense that in that terminal moment he is recalling a series of profound human moments throughout his life. If nothing else, the wispily connected scenes provide an accessible introduction to modern philosophy, covering topics such as free will, human potential, neuroscience, time, and the self. The only vaguely mainstream movie I can think of which is comparatively philosophically dense would be Cosmopolis, although Linklater's film doesn't have the emotional payoff of Cronenberg's. Fans of A Scanner Darkly (Linklater's 2006 Philip K Dick adaptation) will be familiar with the art technique he uses here. Sometimes it appears to be a simple case of watercolour-style painting over filmed imagery, but as the narrative progresses the pictures become more surreal and nightmarish; so, we're left with a range of styles from impressionist to minimalist to Gilliam-esque animated madness. Obviously Waking Life is hugely indulgent (Linklater even gives himself the climactic speech) but I don't see this as a criticism. The script comes across like a desk drawer full of scribbled ideas because it probably was. But what ideas they are, interrogating notions of memory, identity, and dream logic with skill and clarity. Only on occasions does the writing stray into condescending territory – the suggestion, for example, that we're all sleepwalkers who'll "sell our souls for minimum wage" is clichéd. More often than not, though, the words make us think. Crucially, they make us think for ourselves. Waking Life was made prior to 11 September 2001, yet released in October. "A new world is possible," one character says, oblivious to the cynical new world that was to come. I find there is a sadness in Waking Life's hopefulness about human potential. Toward the end it puts forward the idea that life may be but a dream after death – a moving metaphysical thought that seems somehow too abstract for a post-9/11 world; a world which has seen the Dream turned sour.

reviews.review_title: 7/10 Amazing. Totally captivating. Maybe a bit pretentious. Very wordy and slow and deep.
reviews.content: This was truly an amazing work. I don't know if there was original camera work done and then animation on top of it, but the movement and expression of the body was so complete that it made me wonder, because I've never seen any animation capture people so completely. The plot, if it has one, was workable, but it's not really the kind of movie that needs a plot since it's just a man searching for understanding. The movie is very very wordy. It's all words. At some point I started to feel it was pretentious, but because it was such a movie to behold, I was happy to keep going. I even lost track of the time. My only real beef is that they do so much talking that seems so deeply theoretical that there is no effort made to make it easier to digest or summarize. That was probably intentional though; an effort to be 'uncompromizing' in its intellectual offerings to the viewer. The broad cast of characters offers so much to see and hear. Anyway, I loved it, but at some point I felt bored with the relentless talking and captivated with everything else. 7/10

reviews.review_title: Astonishing...simply put, it blows your mind!
reviews.content: I read a book that called "The Matrix" the most philosophical movie ever made...clearly, they haven't seen this.  The plot of "Waking Life" is exactly the opposite of its title: a character exploring his dreams...or is it a dream?  Are 'dreams' really our waking state and are we just dreaming what we think is our waking state?  One of the many question posed in this brilliant blend of philosophy, science, theories, fantasy, music, drama and animation.First I'd just like to say that I don't know if I'd label this movie as an animated one, or at least a cartoon.  After all, movies like "The Lord of the Rings" and "The Matrix" that are filmed almost entirely on green screen aren't labeled as animated flicks because computers were used just to create the locations.  The same goes with this film, seeing that it takes place in a dream, computers were used to effectively create a dream world.Anyway, that's not really important.  This, in nature, is a truly episodic film.  It follows Wiley Wiggins as he explores his dream life, meeting character after character, them speaking about things like the meaning of life, creationism, evolution, politics, reincarnation, the media, and so much more.  He talks to a woman who thinks humans are like ants, a woman who thinks creationism was invented because of feelings humans are unable to express through words, etc.  And it doesn't just lightly touch on these topics, it goes deep - really deep into them.Because of the mix of animation, fantastical elements, some plain weird characters and some great settings, when the ninety-nine minutes are over it feels like you just woke up from a dream.  What's also notable is how writer-director Linklater is so focused on keeping his movie like a dream, exactly like a dream.  There are some segments where Wiley isn't even present - just like how in our dreams we may feel we're not there.This is an amazing film on all accounts.  When you think about all the dialogue Linklater wrote, all the actors who had to memorize it, Linklater's direction with a digital camera, all the animators who had to perfect that. There is not a single aspect that isn't touched with completeness and detail.An amazing, astounding film that makes you think more than any other, 8.5/10.

reviews.review_title: understandable why people dont like it
reviews.content: *spoilers herein*anybody who has problems with this film is angry that they didn't understand it completely.  another comment said "eye-candy for stoners" quite true, quite, quite true i have never seen a more thought provoking movie in my life. this movie made me think, REALLY think, the theories thrown out were gold, and the animation would only be irritating to anyone who hated the blair witch, in all her glory. particularly the opening scene, the public phone was brilliant, and the way the man screaming his views out in the car's face changed colour to symbolize how his emotions changed.  they, were good. also, the dialogue.  among the most complicated pieces of scripting ever heard, but terrifyingly astounding if really, really HEARD, not just listened to, and above all, understood.  and as for those who need a distinguishable plot, if you had ACTUALLY SEEN-AND EXPERIENCED this film, you'd know it doesn't matter.

reviews.review_title: Amazing does not begin to describe it.
reviews.content: I will have to obtain a copy of this film because I'm sure I'll need to view it ten times to get the maximum out of it. In two hours, it deals with every philosophical and metaphysical idea I can think of, off the top of my head. In a way, it reminded me of My Dinner With Andre because Andre's stories are so far out there that we process them subconsciously as dream stories, until Wally wakes us up.In addition to the incredibly thoughtful and clever script, the acting totally knocks me out. I find it impossible to accept that these are not real people recorded having real conversations. There is a lot of subtle humor and irony woven into the film, like first the "boat captain" denying he had met the main character before, with the main character getting frustrated in his low-key way, and then later the main character denying he had seen the amorous girl before, when WE certainly can't forget that intense but wordless encounter.Among all the literary and quotation references peppered throughout the film, I was surprised the famous Poe poem, Dream Within a Dream, received no mention. After all, the umbrella theme of the film is an attempt to answer Poe's question.I shall now seek out all the rest of Linklater's films.

Richard Linklater figures out how to get his philosophical interests--heretofore displayed in the maddeningly talky, self-serious `Before Sunrise'--onto the big screen in a novel, entertaining fashion by animating the proceedings. Linklater uses a multitude of animators (about thirty) and they lend fascinating perspectives to the talk (again, all talk) that alternately illuminate and parody the conversations; the result is about as entertaining a presentation of various philosophies as you can get. This time, the ideas are abstract--only a couple of conversations are based on experience--but Linklater sets them in a lucid order, ranging from existentialism to evolutionary theory to finally the conclusion that life and death are an indistinguishable dream state that ultimately provides individual freedom. It's true there's a lot of pretension mixed with the profundity but there's also a refreshing humor provided by the animators that allows a certain relief from the earnestnestness and even Linklater allows a certain winking irony. (One of his characters admits `we're all theory and no action.') It's a film that requires multiple viewings in order to get comfortable with it but the effort is well worth it: this is a vital blend of creativity in a variety of arts (including Glover Gill's delightfully experimental tango score) mixed with some of the more rigorous thinking to be presented in a film.

No character interaction, no story, no nuthin' but endless droning.Ebert: 4 stars EW:    Abobdude2: 4 yawns - save your dough

I felt as if I sat in another Philosophy lecture class, and Linklater was the boring Professor who was summarizing "What is it to be human?" through many old philosophers theories.
