I didn't feel that he actually had a point within this "dream-state" movie.The animation was definately different, but I wouldn't recommend this movie to people who suffer from motion sickness. Even I found that the animation (through its liquid nature) gave me a headache. However, its content was good, but it was poorly formed on film. If you are going to watch this movie, please bring lots of attention, and don't expect it to be another "escape" movie.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie I have ever seen
reviews.content: I found the variety of animation styles quite jarring and they gave me a headache, literally. The subject matter, unfortunately did not give an respite from the visual onslaught, is a terrible mix of half baked philosophy and clichés. The structure, of using a person walking through different styles to represent different philosophies is clever, but only for about 5 minutes and after that just becomes annoying.At least the hard to watch animation was well suited to the hard to listen to script. My wife and I sat through the whole movie only to find out afterwords that both of us hated it.Buy yourself a bluffers guide to philosophy, you will learn a lot more and not have to suffer the headache.

I haven't watched so much BC compressed into 100 minutes of film. I found some ideas discussed in the film are very interesting, other ideas aren't, just silly. Overall, this is a very impressive accomplishment.One common fallacy that I have observed in several of these philosophical films is the argument that physical determinism undermines free will, such an argument is fallacious because free will means that an individual can make decisions based on his own mind, his mind operates according to physical laws so, in principle, in a deterministic universe we could predict the decisions made by individuals before they make these decisions but that's not a proof of inexistence of free will. Also, quantum mechanics do not mean that the universe is not deterministic since the probability distributions follow deterministic laws: quantum mechanics is just an extension of the deterministic view of the universe to the quantum level. Free will has nothing to do with quantum mechanics.Well, at least this movie made me think about those subjects, that is quite interesting. An intellectually stimulating film full of interesting nonsense.

It amazes me how writer-director Richard Linklater writes these great films of pure dialogue and true human stories and still makes them interesting to the average movie-going audience.Such is in the case of "Waking Life", a visionary tale of a man who is stuck in a continous dream of which he cannot wake from.  In each of  these dreams, the man finds himself in conversation with or looking in on a variety of deep thoughted people who have perspectives on life, death and why we're really here.Wiley Wiggins (Mitch Kramer from "Dazed and Confused") gives a good performance as the dream-woven main character.  There are also several brief but very good perfomances in the movie, including Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy in an update on what happened two their characters Jesse and Celine in "Before Sunrise".  The animation (shot on regular film and then animated over) offers a beautiful dreamlike feel while you're watching it, as does Linklater's always great scenes of dialogue and direction.If you're in the mood for a really thought provoking film or you're just a big Richard Linklater buff, I highly recommend "Waking Life".

A minor acheivement.  The main problem, however, is that the strengths of the film become ponderous as it nears the end as the crafty animation becomes distracting and the thought-provoking dialouge begins to wax metanarrative.  Overall I liked it, but then in my everyday life I have little chance to discuss any of the concepts presented here, that interest me so much, and it was refreshing just to hear them communicated even if at times in a ramble.

reviews.review_title: Worn-out Philosophy packaged as Deep Thought
reviews.content: I was got this DVD as a gift and was interested in seeing it as I'd read how brilliant and thought provoking it was.I thought the animation, though used in an interesting way, was sub par in execution which made me think that this film was originally meant to be shown as live action but then changed to an animated feature as a last ditch way to make this film releasable. As a live action movie this would be unwatchable.The main point of this film seems to be to show the audience these amazing philosophical theories that will blow their minds and change their life. But there were no new or interesting observations made in this movie; to me it reminded me of sitting up, stoned, late at night with a bunch of friends... The inhibitions get loose, and the tongues start to wag, and you think that everything you're saying and hearing are the most amazing things you've ever heard.The problem is, when you wake up in the morning, you realize it was all just tripe.So Waking Life is just the opposite... it's the stoned ramblings of the night before.

reviews.review_title: Beautifully animated attempt to explain the word "Philosophy" to people who can't think for themselves
reviews.content: I don't know much about the director, and I am surprised that it seems to be so important for so many. Who cares about the director or his other movies? The reviews should be about THE MOVIE, not attempts to convince anyone of the quality of the movie based on the persona of the director.So, what kind of movie is this? For me it is a movie that is supposed to make you think, using extensive philosophical dialog and great innovative animation techniques. (Yeah, yeah, I know that they filmed this movie with a real camera and then edited it digitally, but who cares? The result is an animated movie, period.) The animation is great. It is innovative, memorable, and the original idea itself is implemented really well. The animation has a great effect on the perception on the reality of the movie, because on one hand, the eye sees that everything is drawn, but on the other hand, every scene seems very real because of the specific way the images move around each other. It is kind of like old memories: you remember approximately what has happened, but all the sharp details are gone of course, and what you have left are silhouettes of objects that move around in almost the same way as they do in Waking Life.This effect is especially appreciated when one of the films themes are dreaming, reality and how we can tell the difference.Now, the movie's philosophical message is told through numerous ideas, monologues of different people, kind of like every person's view of the world. And I can even understand what the filmmakers were trying to do with having so many different small ideas presented: the movie itself is kind of like a dream, with many small peaces that supposedly only the subconscious mind can piece together to make a deep philosophical impression. Great idea! But the biggest problem of this film is that ideas themselves are stupid! Not because I don't understand them, but because as a normal thinking person that talks to other people, I have thought through most of the ideas presented myself, and in much more deep way than they are presented in the movie. It is like if you would come up to a priest and ask him “hey, have you ever thought that there can be some supernatural force that governs all of the world?”. So those of you who write here that this movie has changed your lives and you started thinking in other ways, it simply means that you haven't spent a single second in your past thinking about anything philosophical. I don't think the ideas are stupid because I don't understand them, I think they are stupid because they are so basic, that a 12-year old could comprehend them in a second.Plus, some ideas are plainly stupid, incomplete and are based on faulty assumptions: The guy driving around, megaphoning about the society –-- I guess he never studied any history and I hope for him to go back to the anarchy of feudal times and finally understand what good does the society give us.Ethan Hawke + a girl talking about how believing in reincarnations means that only one in 6 people should technically be able to have been reincarnated from someone else in the past –-- not everyone in the world claims that they have been reincarnated, much less than a sixth of the population, so they could as well be that sixth part of the population that actually have been someone else in the past.“There is no difference between dreaming a perception and actually the waking perception of an action” --- Seriously, who hasn't thought of that? I was hoping the guy would expand it but he never did.The guy talking about humans being deterministic clockworks and that there is no free will –-- the idea is as old as the scientific paradigm and one could still argue that a complicated deterministic design does not mean that there is no free will.“Words are inert and much of our perceptions are unspeakable, and we don't know if we really understand anyone else” --- well, yeah, and also, a shocking news, the whole world can be in your imagination, you could be the only person alive, and you could never tell because your perceptions are the only thing you have access to.And yes, I am aware of the fact the movie does not tell us that every idea it presents is true, valid or even appropriate, it just gives us some different points of view of different people, leaving it to us to piece everything together, and it makes it a little better, but still, when you hear such nonsense ideas, it is difficult to like the movie.Overall, there are some good ideas, the graphical representation is original and well performed, but this movie is a little too simple for me. Although it is not a 1/10 as many others may say, some of the things I must give credit for. There is no plot or action, but one could make a decent movie without them.The only thing I couldn't really place was why the movie constantly presented us with points of view of general “losers”, drunks, junkies, people that seem unemployed and without any particular meaning in life, and so on. Not only does the movie present those people, it emphasizes on them. Was it a try to make ordinary people identify with the movie? Is it a Nietzsche-like message about how most people live like animals and never achieve to anything? Or does is it a way to question if the values the society is trying to teach everyone aren't as valid as we think? Even thou I have some theories about that, for me it just seems weird and misplaced.

reviews.review_title: You still alive? Or already dreaming? Or was it the other way round?
reviews.content: And now for something completely different. For your consideration: Richard Linklater's "Waking Life", it easily fits the bill. The apparent stand-out of this rather, let's say, eccentric and off-key movie is rotoscoping animation where a team of artists drew stylized lines and colors over each frame of the digitally filmed material. This lends the film an entirely fresh imagery, one might name it "aura", which is real and unreal at the same time. And what better technique would fit to a movie about the nature of dreams, consciousness and the existential questions that are asked in between? There's no distinguishable plot to be found here, only people discussing their diverging philosophical, scientific or just practical approaches on the matter of being awake and/or dreaming - but don't expect any conclusions. For the receptive mind Linklater's film for sure is an engrossing, sometimes also dizzying trip through a lucid dream world, a journey to be savored, and especially the visuals are whole adventures in themselves.The film however lacks the dynamic which its trailer suggests, and neither is there any Iggy Pop in it. More accessibility and less focus on sophisticated arguments could have made "Walking Life" into a cult movie, but as it is it's at least a must-see for those regularly walking the fine line between dream and reality.

This is by far the most excruciatingly boring movie I have EVER seen! I couldn't wait to see it for the art over film- but I wanted to hang myself about 10 minutes into the movie. It is so pretentious. It watches like a psychology text book- so if you're into that kind of thing you'll probably love it. I went into the restroom because I needed a break mid-movie and there were people loitering to avoid this movie. I have flashbacks of seeing Waking Life and I start sweating. It's a horrible rambling dialog, acting as if it is so much smarter than the audience. Don't put yourself through it if possible for your own sanity. There a so many better things to do with that time-

This is one of the worst movies that I have ever seen, if not indeed the worst. It is computer processing run amok, on top of some of the worst pseudo-philosophical drivel that one could possibly imagine. Avoid this one. There are only three or four movies that I would give only one star out of ten, and this is the worst of the lot. (If you want philosophical chatter, opt instead for My Dinner With Andre, which is certainly more interesting.) Waking Life could be appreciated best by one type of person: one who is deaf, blind, and stupid. Whatever functional capacity you have as a human being will be irritated by this exercise in Adobe Premiere.

reviews.review_title: Worth seeing, not worth listening to.
reviews.content: The animation in Waking Life is unique and compelling, and thankfully distracts from the bland "philosophical" meanderings of the dialogue.  The ideas presented here are neither new nor particularly interesting, unless one is in high school, smoking up, or both.  This film takes the concept of lucid dreams and turns it into a mess of name-dropping and pseudo-intellectual drivel, which is a shame considering the apparent talent and potential of the filmmakers.

reviews.review_title: One of the most important works of art in the history of man :)
reviews.content: Having first seen this on VHS tape when it was released, I was astounded and like a bucket of ice cold water thrown on my psyche I awakend.This movie crushed my perspectives and vibrated so many long dormant truth chords I felt reborn! This movie came out pre-9/11 world, computers barely functioning, ignorance and bigotry rampant...We as a society and a nation were so in the dark.It would be 6 years before the loud red faced guy in the car (alex jones) shouting about system would become known to me...But, 12 years later Waking Life haunts me. It's philosophic bend all the more endearing...It's not new thoughts or ideas but rather a focused concentration of life explaining ideals so profound as to be almost irrefutable...It is not for the person who can't sit still for a couple hours and is not introspective.

Waking Life is a brilliant, must see movie for those who search for meaning and purpose wrapped up in their entertainment.  Colorful, bouncy and seemingly alive, it dances across the screen with hidden messages, floats through your psyche with philosophical brilliance and pulls you in through human intrigue.I truly loved this movie, if not for the mere art of it all, for the bravery of Linklater to throw a film out there without a plot.  Yep, that's right, no plot to be found, but a wonderful few days (or dreams) in the life of the main character (Wiley Wiggins) who spends his days walking around talking to interesting characters and having unique experiences (like driving down the road in a boat).  Eventually Wiggins realizes that he's dreaming, only to later realize that he can't wake up.  I'm also impressed with Linklater's ability to find a way to make it all feel dreamy and surreal, while wrapping the message up in a spiritual/lucid dreaming/philosophical sandwich.There aren't many movies that I love.  There aren't many ideas out there that are new, or at least presented in new and interesting ways.  This movie isn't for everyone, but is a great and rare find for those who dabble in self-exploration, new-age ideas, philosophical enjoyment, dreaming, reality or any of the pressing human mysteries.  Plot or no plot, there is plenty of meaning to be found in this flick.
Trippy, insightful, and thoroughly enjoyable. The animation is very unique and gives the movie that dreamy feel it was going for. Definitely a must see if you are an active thinker.

reviews.review_title: NOT hippster coffee shop blathering(with beautiful animation)
reviews.content: i don't think this movie is pretenscious.  i think it's a very honest and open movie.  and some people will be annoyed by that.  the movie overall is a bunch of people speaking their minds.  and it isn't like the director/writer speaking his mind on some topic.  but it's like a lot of different people speaking their minds (and the director shows what he wants but i think there is something for everyone if you give it a chance).  and they all have interesting takes on what they are talking about.  and you will agree with some people and disagree with others (not that it's a right wing-left wing debate type movie).  i don't think the movie is about what they are talking about anyways.  it is in someway but i'm not sure in what way.  and i probably should know but i think it's fine if you don't.  you can still really enjoy this film.  and by the way the art to me is undeniably interesting and pleasing.  even still there is least one thing that the people are talking about in the movie that they are trying to get to the bottom of.  one theme that does end up coming up a lot.  and the movie's take on "this" is very interesting as what final thought they seem to have on the matter is interesting as well.  and this movie does end up having enough of a story (with an end).  so basically the movie is a clear story that is mixed with unclear points on the side.  and the clear story doesn't really come above the unclear parts until past the half-way point of the movie.  but it's there.  it's not your typical early ninties coffee shop blathering to me.  it seems to be from a lot of different people other than late 20's hippsters.  older crazy men.  middle aged over the top men.  old women.  old men.  older 20 something women and men.  one "black" person (so i guess it's not all that diverse).  and the things they talk about are all over the place.  and even though i think it's a pre 2000 movie.  it's not dated or all about the end of the century.  it's about very general things about all types of problems and questions.  and you may think that they are way off if you are a really radical thinker.  but most people will probably be into what they are talking about.  and it's still beautiful and interesting.  the people and their ideas.  and the art(animation).

reviews.review_title: As intellectually stimulating as it is visually.
reviews.content: Very interesting concept: painting over live-action movie...  This movie is like a dream, but much more interesting, philosophically.  Finally, a movie which does not neccessarily conform to normal narrative.  It's just about a guy who wanders around in his dreams, but it's great.  There are all sorts of questions posed in this movie, and I'm sure you've all thought of these things...  we all do.  I'd hope.  Anyways... I reccomend this to anyone who wants to see something a little different.  I think it would be a good trip too.  :)Enjoy.

First off:  I love moviesSecond:  Movies love meThird:  I rented this movie the first chance I got.  (Mainly to check out the animation technique).  During that three-day period I watched this flick about six or seven times.  It gets better each time you watch it.

Again, to all those who like their movie experiences to stop at summer stock like Big Boom II or Gross-Out Comedy: The Porcelain Journeys, you may have trouble accepting a film like Waking Life. It's a hauntingly beautiful mix of cutting edge animation, philosophy, and eerie, almost spooky atmosphere. There is no story outside of the main character going to many strange people and discussing the origins of dreams and what they mean in today's world. I enjoyed the slow pace, the quirky characters, and many of the ideas that are presented. Some theories are complex, but after a couple more viewings I started to understand what some of the characters were talking about. Also, you can't beat Waking Life when it comes to art. They shot the entire thing in live action, then went back with computers to 'paint' over the actors. The whole thing looks like a swirly, blobby, insanely psycadelic painting, and really adds to the whole dream thing. You can actually be hypnotized by the visuals of this film, getting drowzy while not wanting to miss any of it. Also, the music is very memorable. Usually I don't enjoy orchestral soundtracks, but after watching WL I really want to hear its symphonic tunes again and again. You may have a hard time finding this, but if you really have an obsession involved with animation or enjoy debating over life, death, and whatnot, then do yourself a huge favor and rent (then buy) Waking Life. It's not one to miss. ****/****

I was in high school when I first saw this movie. Personally, I think that is the perfect time to first view it. I feel at that age, people really start to become intrigued with philosophy and new ideas that they are a bit too young to get taught in school. I have seen this movie a few times and every time I see it I'm surprised at how much I still enjoy it and am fascinated with some ideas that are addressed. Each character is unique and interesting. Many are over the top and done intentionally. The animation of the movie gives it the ability to surpass what can be accomplished with live action only. Speaking of the animation, it is the first time that I had seen a film done in that way. It was very interesting and new to me at the time. I really like the way that everything is intertwined through the movie. I guess a case could be made that it is more random than a flowing arc, but I feel that it can be perceived in whichever flow the audience desires to view it in. I think a lot of people can be harsh on this movie because they think the filmmakers were holding a "look at us, we're smart and making a movie about philosophy" mentality, which I feel is really a shame. If everyone gave this a fair chance I feel very few would not enjoy it.

Masterpiece capturing and demonstrating the principles of life, the eternal journey and the constant arrival. Freedom to develop our personality beyond social norms and stereotypes. Movie that I watch for the sixth time, and whose poster stood instead my profile picture on Facebook. The film, which gave me to understand that I am finally on way that is meant only for me.Facing different approaches to life, it is embodiment of different possible lives. Showing the action in a unique innovative technology (and yet every place and every character is absolutely true). The action runs! as a sleep. Definitely a philosophical approach.Convergent themes of responsibility, creativity, language, communication, evolution, revolution, politics, loneliness, revenge, fate, science, dreams and cinema. Protesting against depersonalization and turning others into foreigners. Looking for the other as unique person and treating him in a respectful way.In general it laid the foundations to answer the questions of who we are, and who I am. Is it everything real or not, am I waking up to the sobriety of thinking? Am I saying yes to life, while many people refuse to do so? And when they finally decide to say yes, life tells them his no, which is the final no of death (as in Kafka's Before the Law).Somehow studental, surreal, unconventional and yet very interesting. After three years I will most likely watch it for the seventh time.http://vihrenmitevmovies.blogspot.com/

Something crucial with this film is the following: It is not the plot that is important, it is the message. Everyone open-minded can in one way or another can take part of this message. At first glance, it seems that the film doesn't really have a plot, the animation is widely disappointing and nothing ever happens. But when the credits start to roll, you realize that the plot is amazing, and every little detail in the animation serves its purpose. I cannot justify this film in words, it has to be experienced. All of you who don't like "talk"-films or/and philosophical nonsense, do not bother watching this film, because you will be hugely disappointed. Everyone else will definitely get something out of this film. And it will surely make you wonder if you're awake....10/10

reviews.review_title: Not a film for slow-witted stiffs
reviews.content: I think reactionary critics of this film are overly cynical drones. Can't they even see that dreams tend to BE about heavy concepts? Perhaps the critics can't fathom anything beyond mundane reality, and hate to be dragged out of that zone (which this film does throughout). I can't see low-brow conservatives getting much out of it.I found only a fraction of the material the least bit dull; the parts that veered too much into speculation and supernatural elements. The scene with the couple in bed had one of those moments. The "puzzle" story seemed too far out to be true (as it was implied). I don't think philosophy needs to exceed the laws of nature.The only thing I really didn't like was the excessively wavy animation in some sequences (the people and backgrounds rarely stand still). Some of the floating layers and shifting lines led to dizziness and distracted from the content. They could have toned down the overall shakiness about 30% and still maintained the dream-state look. How they pulled off the animation (technically) was itself part of the interest."Waking Life" is definitely worth seeing, and one of few films I'd want to watch more than once in short order to figure it out better. It gives the impression of hidden clues that can help make sense of the ending and/or the beginning.

Ok... if you can get beyond the nauseas feeling the animation gives you, the movie in itself is a catastrophic, tiring... ummm... thing.  At first, I thought it was very deep... then I fell asleep.  I mean, I'm college educated and all.  Had plenty of intellectual conversations (many much better than this movie)... but this is not a fun or informative night out at the movies.  Definitely don't take a date to this one, but if you feel like trying to make yourself feel like you're an intellectual, go see this then tell everyone who it spoke to you and it was deep and meaningful.

reviews.review_title: Definitely a movie only to be seen when one is in certain moods...
reviews.content: Well this one definitely defines the phrase "acquired taste".An interesting and at times deeply moving film, with amazing technical graphics and animation. However, the main reason for the latter seems to be to disguise the fact that this movie really has little or no script...Filled with typical long monologues on the meaning of life, etc., as typical with Linklater (even including an Ethan Hawke/Julie Delpy scene that is a direct throwback and reiteration of an earlier movie of his), it does seem a little too deep and smug at times, and certainly does outstay its welcome.Best watched at home on video or DVD, with a remote and a PAUSE button handy, and no doubt very interesting to watch if stoned... Also, if you're in a reflective mood on life, its origins, where your life is going, then it's certainly a fun little seminar to attend. Otherwise, you may find it dreary, pretentious and boring.

Funny.  Intruiging.  Weird.  Thought-provoking.  Perfectly written. Everybody's rants take you away, make you laugh, and make you think.  The movie's take on life and death is just...perfect. A+, 10/10

Went to see this film last night and I have to say the subject matter and style of this film is first class.  I was totally blown away by the writing and the animation.  Having said that, I also have to tell you that this film is almost physically impossible to watch to the end.  You will find yourself moving all about in your seat.  It is just too long for what it is.  It should have ended a lot sooner.  It seemed to me a shame that a film that has so many good things going for it would become so self serving and pretentious that you could no longer stand to watch it.  Or maybe they were just trying to make me feel like I was dreaming the whole thing. Go see it for yourself and you will see what I mean.

reviews.review_title: Great to watch, awful to listen to
reviews.content: While the visuals of this movie were spectacular, I got steadily more annoyed by the constant freshman-college-dorm style amateur philosophizing. If I go to see this movie again, I will assuredly bring my ear muffs with me so that I can focus on what was good about it:  the animation.,

reviews.review_title: Depends on what you want to take away
reviews.content:
I have to say that the movie is easily intolerable if you're actually angry, active, enjoying time with loved ones, or determined to get something done.  God knows nothing can rankle me more than doped-up caffeinated rich brownnosing snobs speaking about Nieztsche and Heidegger over lattes. Actually, my father says Plato had advised students not to take philosophy until they were over 30, because they hadn't really lived yet.  It seems to show in the ecstasy of the older men waxing philosophical vs. the zombie-like incantations of the young ones in discussing philosophy.
   I went to an extremely intellectual college out near Philly, and there were many times I loved the brand of late-night questioning involved in this movie.  (You can actually enjoy this stuff sober and straight if you're in the right mood.)  I in fact read the Philip K. Dick novel five years ago, "Flow my Tears the Policeman Said" and loved it.  However, after my father got fired from his job and my mother get stressed from her work, and given some time abroad in South America, and a bad breakup, I became really impatient with philosophy.  Even scientific curiosity in general.  To some degree, I continue to be.  I wish some people spent half as much time volunteering as they did wasting their lives away wondering what they ought to do for self-fulfillment.
   There are some comforting things to be found though in "Waking Life."  In addition to some very well-played monologues, like the red-faced prisoner, the diatribe of the man in the car, the dream-masters, the "ant" encounter, the weirdo on the bridge, there emerges a very real panic by the narrator about whether or not he can wake up from his drifting.  This theme emerges constantly in films these days, The Matrix, Truman Show, American Beauty, Fight Club, in Americans who are just numb, passive, drifting, or locked into habits that they just can't seem to snap out of.  I liked the way the drifter increasingly starts looking for a way to wake up, how he questions if he's perhaps died.
   I think a lot of us feel stuck, frustrated these days, especially those of us being laid off, or wondering what kind of direction the country's taken.  I don't think philosophy is necessarily the wrong place to look for comfort.  It's the intellectually masturbatory tendency we have in discussing philosophy that disgusts me, not the ideas themselves.  So, given the thrust of the film seems to be in favor of waking up and taking action, I recommend it.  As the fellow dreamer says, "Just don't get bored.  This is perhaps one of the most exciting times to be alive."  Given that message, along with a marvelous range of artistry in the animation effects, "Waking Life" is worth checking out.

reviews.review_title: A dream-like film essay about dreams
reviews.content: Intriguing potpourri of thoughts, imaginations and scientific insights into the world of dreams. More of a documentary and poetic nature than fiction. I will probably need to see it again to process all of this information. But very well done.

The argument against this movie would be that the movie doesn't truly explore existentialism and instead uses predetermined idealistic logic to draw in the audience. A fair critique would be that the movie didn't take the chance that it was given to educate the viewers in any way about the sophisticated topic of existentialism that the main plot points of the movie seemed to be attempting to surround itself in.However I think what people forget about waking life is that it is less so an exploration of human ideas but more so an exploration of the human mind and specifically the sub conscious of an adolescent.Linklater's goal in this firm wasn't to show growth of a character or try to portray an ideology. Linklater was more so trying to hit the point of the movie by expressing to the audience that the sub conscious is a place that doesn't always coherently go along in a narrative like fashion. Rather it is a place where the bounds of time seem not to exist and flow in a way that seems counter intuitive to the rest of life- he shows this ironically through the incoherence of the film and the dispersed idealogy that stretches and reaches something beyond the dreamer or us as observers . Therefore the movie actually does a great job at what it was trying to explore and invoke in the minds of the audience- the perspective of the protagonist or the boy. If people think that the movie was for their own knowledge they're missing the point of the movie and what is liberating about it, they are missing the lesson. The lesson and part of the movie that is innovative- is the fact that we are an observer of a boy's subconscious who in a lot of ways is also an observer since he's exploring his own sub conscious as well as the ideas of the people who live inside it. In this way the movie is a beautiful symbolic representation of the network of human minds that works together to support that of human ideas and imagination- that of which gives importance to our lives. Therefore the movie touches upon an powerful idea- a idea that we are just merely observers in our own story as much as others. And we like the dreamer are wandering- constantly being effected by external events that don't serve any meaning or purpose necessarily but just show up in our sub conscious and how from there we are forced to make sense of it and pick up the pieces.

I'm sorry, but this film is not the brilliant opus that many are making it out to be.  Rather, it is a plotless, aimless 90-minute lecture on philosophy, acted out by wavy animated figures.  The animation is SO shaky and wavy that I actually felt motion sickness during certain scenes (notably, the scene with the fluctuating biology professor) and had to look away from the screen.  Other scenes work beautifully however, with both understated dialogue and animation style making the message of the film attractive, enjoyable, and occasionally funny.  Sadly, these scenes are in the minority: most of the disjointed scenes consist of 5- to 15-minute onscreen lectures (NOT dialogues or conversations).  These lectures aren't brilliant or especially insightful--they're the kind of stuff that you stayed up until 4 am talking to college roommates about.  Great stuff when you're 18, but pure boredom and naivete when you're a responsible adult.If this movie didn't have the gimmick of being "animated," it would just be another throw-away art house flick made at the level of a college film studies student with an 8 mm camera.  Perhaps if the film had been about 30 minutes shorter, I would have taken all the lecturing a little better. But choppy, nausea-inducing animation, and equally sickening quasi-socialist/naturalistic preaching do not a brilliant film make.

Like "Mulholland Drive," this film is open to much interpretation, but one overwhelming fact in both of them seems to be overlooked by most commentators: BOTH CENTRAL CHARACTERS ARE DEAD! We have seen their deaths, in the case of the young soul in "Waking Life," he is hit by a car very early in the film, whereas Lynch waits till the end to show his character's suicide. Both films are, from the opening frame, a visualization of what their bardo is, how they struggle to let go of their lives and personalities, and to face the fears they had in life. Wiley, or whatever his name was, obviously was more content with himself, happier to be sure, than Lynch's tormented actress, and his bardo is to learn the truth the way he learned it in life, by listening to his guides when they tell him how to let go. These may have been people he knew in his life, or spirit guides. At the end, he "wakes up" and is able to let go. The final scene is one of the most powerful and joyous I have ever seen: soul liberation...

reviews.review_title: Super perfundo on the early eve of your day
reviews.content: This is the interpretation that I choose, that many critics have overlooked. I propose that the theme of this movie is more about birth than death. "Waking Life", although based on the extremity of uncertainties, is in my eye, less than guaranteeing the prophecy of the end to our human spirit. It isn't even guessing that you'll die without knowing the grandness of our universe. It is quite simply telling you that you'll always be positive of your soul's origin, everything that will happen to you is a prescription of morality, with decreasing potency as distance increases, until the inevitably and infinitely mysterious unforeseeable end of action. The film, in my opinion, implies that we are witnessing the poetic birth of a soul into the sphere of life.All in all, Linklater has broken the mold of film production. His reminiscent air of nostalgia for the loss of time as golden as spent, does justice to the robbers of the human spirit, as the emotional outlook that captures us all when we look into the eyes of a photo album and feel the burden of a succession of guilt over the advancement of dreams.

The animation is unusual and worth seeing.  The background of the animated scenes is continually shifting and so may cause motion sickness in the sensitive viewer.  The monologues are well written but a bit long and the story line is minimal.  I think this is more of a seminar than a movie.

Along the same lines as a scanner darkly, however this time you are in a surreal dream, where all of your questions will be thought about and hopefully answered or at least clarified. The idea of this movie is not to "wow" the audience with special effects or a glamorous witty character. This movie gets right down to the nitty gritty of thinking. It portrays a teenage boy who travels throughout the expanses of his mind thinking and answering his own questions. These questions are posed by himself, and answered by many people that he has either met, thought about, or created. These men/women range from friends to professors. The questions range from why are we here, what is keeping us, to what the media has done, and is our government really the best. Some say this movie is boring, others say that it is amazing. Really I can't tell you either way, you will either hate it or find it one of the best movies to stimulate your neurons. However, what I can tell you, is that you and everyone else should at least watch this movie, whether it be for the revolutionary roto scoping, or for the questions that bore holes in your mind everyday.

This movie was terrible...who talks like this in real life?  I mean honestly?  The animation, although "unique," almost made me vomit.  The points raised were somewhat okay, but over all it was terrible.  I would never ever suggest this movie ever.  If you want to see a good Ethan Hawke movie, go watch Gattaca.

Maybe I'm just too old for this movie.  The drawing talent of the animators is obvious, but animation is more than pretty pictures.  I found the constant background motion annoying, even nauseating at times.  I suppose the movie was aiming for a younger audience, for I think the college age crowd would probably consider it deep and meaningful.  I found it dull and monotonous.  If you enjoy 90+ minutes of people doing little but spouting personal philosophy, and your equilibrium can stand the constantly churning scenery, you may enjoy it.  I didn't.

"Waking Life" works hard to prove that its animation is not a gimmick. For a long time I sat there wondering exactly why they bothered to draw over live footage to create images that, at many times, are just annoying. If they were going to animate it, why not go even farther and alter the images even more? Even backgrounds such as brick walls behind the actors are drawn as they are. Maybe they should have made it half animated, half live. The scene where the four guys, (with Nikki Katt and Adam Goldberg) encounter the old man hanging from the telephone pole would've been more interesting if it were live-action. For a time, I thought that the idea of the animation was to take otherwise boring 'talking head' scenes, of which there are many, and turn them into something more interesting.There's more to it than that, though. The animation has a clear purpose. If the above theory were true, it would be a gimmick. The animation isn't there to signal when we're in a dream. No, the film isn't all a dream. Much of it is real while the film is entirely animated. The film repeatedly touches on the mind's inability to distinguish between dreams and reality. Our minds create our reality for us. What we see is always a matter of interpretation. Dreams are created in our minds when we sleep. The world is merely a stimulus. So actually, there is no 'real' at all. There are as many realities as there are people on the planet.
So the premise of "Waking Life" is simple: Each person colors their own world differently. Figuratively speaking, we draw over it. Linklater gathers some animators and does this literally, almost as an experiment. Many different artists were given freedom to do whatever they wanted with the live images. They took what they saw in the scene and drew that over it. They interpreted it, the way each of us take physical reality and draw over it in our mind's eye. I didn't always enjoy the experience. There were times when I felt like I was watching "My Dinner With Andre: the animated version." This was a problem near the beginning of the film. As it moves on though, it gets more interesting, as Wiley Wiggins' character's problem becomes clear: He can't wake up from his dream. The film really does make you think. Linklater's point is to explore the importance of dreams and how they reveal the potential of the human mind. Grade: B

Just like listening to someone talk about their dreams, this movie bores to tears. In this we get to hear a bunch of random people talk about their dreams for like 90 minutes, spliced together in the stream-of-consciousness style Linklater used earlier in the movie "Slacker".I guess people think this is a brilliant movie because it's so blatant in its attempt to openly discuss contemplative and philosophical ideas. But this movie is not nearly as profound as reading a book that gives a basic overview of academic philosophy.See, the problem here is that the film has no story and has no message. It is only a launchpad for Linklater's self-congratulatory musings on dreams. By throwing this stuff at us so blatantly, the movie loses all of its charm, light-hearted qualities and potential for resonance with the audience's imagination. Maybe one could argue that these are things the movie purposefully eschews, but if so that's because the movie is obnoxiously self-important.Sure, the animation is kind of interesting, but it also becomes really annoying when you realize that it's useless and done only to trick us into thinking the movie has artistic credibility. Frankly, any film that shows Ethan Hawke talking about a dream about his brain's post-mortem functionality is annoying enough. But throw seizure-inducing animation over the scene and a river of vomit ensues.A total Indie-Rock, scenester flick that makes emo-kids pat themselves on the back for watching a movie that thinks about thinking.

reviews.review_title: If I had to pick a film to describe me...
reviews.content:
Brilliant film. I do feel like only certain people will enjoy it though. If you are a lucid dreamer or if you have contemplated the meaning of existence for some time, this may be for you.In my opinion the entire film is quoteworthy and also it is one of the few films that I'd easily watch directly again after just having watched it.
Technique, music, idea, narrators, filmography, all simply fits. This film is a masterpiece!

The only unifying theme throughout this movie is the dreamlike aspect of waking life, the need to at times perceive and observe in distinct fragments devoid of temporal foundation, and the feeling that anything is possible - "dream is destiny." The rest of the movie simply consists of theoretical conversations taking place in this dream setting. For anyone not aware of the theory taking place, the movie will be nearly incomprehensible. Even with an understanding of the idea, the speed of conversation and the use of a large vocabulary will be obstacles to others. Even the cartoonish presentation may distract during the dialogues, but for others I'd think that even if the ideas are lost, at least they could take pleasure in a truly unique way of movie making. This is especially so given that every scene is animated by a different person, so that the screenscapes change as quickly as the theory under debate. This is a great movie and Linklater sure did his homework. I'll have to go recheck to see if he is the only one credited with writing. Either way a tremendous amount of research went into this. It's all accurate representations of modern theories. Even updates of theories are spoken of like the synthesis of subatomic physics with free will and an existentialist critique of post modernism and new evolution and even some new age rubbish. Great movie and the most intellectually demanding of all time possibly. It'll not be liked by those without a history in the social sciences, or at least art. Personally, I look forward to getting the dvd and pausing it frequently for inter-scene discussions with my girlfriend.

You can tell a great film by its ability to deflate egos. With a tarnished self-image people will, full of emotion, vigorously attack or praise the work in question. So full of emotion, we can't blame them for leaving reason and justification on the wayside. interpretation, spoilers:Scene one: dream is destiny. Dreams give you your destiny - fate, future, purpose. If dreams can be controlled, then so can your destiny. A lucid dream is a controlled dream. Thus lucidity is the goal sought throughout the entire movie. Scene two: the musicians. Music is a metaphor for the idea of `living in the moment.' This idea is returned to many times throughout the film and is again accentuated in the end when the musicians return.
Scene three: the boat car. The most important part of this scene is the line, `I don't know either (where I'm dropping you off) but it's going to determine the rest of your life.' This is our first brush with determinism. It is not just any determinism, but a radical determinism: even trivial events determine who you are and how you act. This is an unpleasant thought  especially with regard to the existentialists who make up most of the remainder of the film. Determinism is summarized here and becomes the thesis to which the rest of the film will act as an antithesis towards.
Scene four: the first lecture. The professor is sympathetic to existentialism and disagrees with the post modernists. Essentially, this means that he believes in free will over determinism. Scene five: the evolutionary theorist.Scene six: the free will theorist. This scene gives us our theoretical attempt at destruction of the determinism already built up. However the destruction is far from complete. Instead of arguing for free will, he argues against determinism. A logical fallacy is used here: even if determinism is proven false, we still have no ground for believing that free will is true. The veracity of free will is pretty much assumed here. From this point on, the film attempts to argue for free will by describing it in a wide variety of existential situations. The unifying free will argument employed is this: look at all these situations, look at all the great possibilities  there's so many that free will must be true. Again, this is not a logically rationalistic argument, it's inductive instead of deductive and hence any conclusions cannot be given certitude. Nevertheless, let's examine the film's possibility-based solutions to determinism.Humans have expanded possibilities in these areas: political freedom (freedom from oppression); lack of barriers and consequent destruction (revenge, self-immolation, murder, nihilism); a collective unconscious (instinct); a collective unconscious (Jungian); a personal unconscious (dreams); creativity (music, art, writing, lucid dreaming); new biology (new evolution and neo-humanity); new technology (the linking of the analogue and digital, the organic with the machine); living in the moment/choosing eternity/the holy moment; immorality (dream time and dreaming from the land of the dead, the illusion of time); interpersonal connection (communication and understanding); submerse yourself in subjectivity; submerse yourself in objectivity; reach the One, the Mind, the subjective objectivity; the need for responsibility (by acting as if we're responsible we're acting as if we have free will); individualism (the need to create our Self); multiple selves (we're too complex and important); life affirmation/the mighty Yes; romanticism (choosing life, passion, the moment again); dreaming itself (anything is possible).    Another is the idea that we can attain freedom by thinking beyond determinism. If our pre-reflective action would have been this, I'll do this! `Super profundito in the early eve of your day.' I.e., with super/extra profundity/knowledge you can outthink determinism. However thinking here simply becomes another determinant and nothing is solved.
We also get another pleasant life-affirming view when the computer explains how he'd rather be human. This emotionalism does not give us free will either. The basic idea is that there are such a vast amount of intriguing and spiritual solutions/possibilities, we could never explain everything with a simple naturalistic deterministic theory. The main error in this thinking is the idea that our lack of knowing each determinant disproves determinism.
None of the `solutions' to determinism work. Each involves either irrationalism and/or denial. Luckily, the film agrees with this view: the main character in the end loses his lucidity (his freedom) and floats off into the abyssal sky. There is an important point to note however. The point of the film is not to affirm free will, but to examine existential necessity of a free will - or atleast our bad faith in believing in our personal freedom.

Loved it, loved it, loved it! So many thoughts that I have had regarding my philosophies of life, being, dreams (and controlling them), direction, death....never telling anyone about them for fear of being labelled a pretentious and oddball thinker...all in this wonderful movie! Anyone who "gets" this film will be blown away. I feel very lucky to be one of those people. The content is fantastic, and the creativity of the way the film was produced is dazzling. The decision to make this an animated film was brilliant: At the outset I couldn't really figure out why they chose to animate, but after having seen it, I'm sure that the movie wouldn't make as much sense if the characters were shown in real-life.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful animation, astonishing script, thorough delight
reviews.content: There were moments watching "Waking Life" that I could hardly contain the joy bubbling up inside me, and I wanted to shout for joy: the beautiful and subtle animation make seeing this film in a theater worthwhile in itself, but add to that the most mature and thought-provoking script I've heard in ages, maybe ever, one that could furnish food for thought for weeks, or for a lifetime: and the result is a film that easily makes its way into my top five.  I can hardly praise this movie enough.  It's a rarity in that it's highly moral without being preachy; it has some screamingly funny moments; it has a main character that if you have an ounce of compassion you'll find yourself getting teary-eyed over as his terrifying dilemma becomes increasingly clear.  As if all that were not enough, the music is gorgeous, too (this is one of the few movies I'd consider buying the sound-track album of).  "Waking Life" just might wake you up to life--even if you already thought you were awake.

This contains spoilers.I watched the film, and loved much of the artwork.  There was one or two segments that weren't visually appealing to me, but some others blew my mind.  The idea of drawing over digital film is a good one.Alright, so I've perused the first 50 or so reviews, and haven't found one that aligns with my perception of this film.  (Forgive me if a review is posted in the interim that blathers out the same ideas as mine!)  I saw it as a slowly layering film ending up with the realization that the main character is dead. This film wasn't about life, and the philosophies of life, but of finding out that you're dead.  At first, I thought that he died when he got hit in the road when reading the note.  However, I now think that he was dead from the time he got off the plane.  C'mon - the whole thing was unreal from the start: recurring characters (starting with the girl in the airport); bizarre yet unquestioned people, places, or things (the boat-car, etc.); unsteady periphery (stairs melted into one another, hedges danced in the background); and memories intermixed with current thoughts ('Hey, man, what are YOU doing here?').On that basis, I didn't really want the movie to end.  I wanted our friend to realize that he wasn't sleeping, but in fact was dead.I could be wrong, too, but if you watch it like I did it is much more enjoyable.

...that was my wife's comment about this movie.  I loved this quirky film, filled with intellectual diatribes.  The animation style was unique and added to the underlying question:  is this waking life, or a dream world? It was visually fascinating -- using primary colors, almost comic book style in portions, yet based entirely on a live-acted original, so the movements, voices, and sounds were completely realistic.  That just added to the surrealism when some elements in the frame became more and more dream-like. 9/10

If you look at the animation from a psychiatric point of view, it's excellent - a well-understood method of inducing a semi-hypnotic state in the viewers.If you look at the script, without the mind-numbing visuals, you get a wealth of impressive-seeming sound-bites from freshman philosophy, without any depth whatsoever.Put them together, and it'll impress the folks who can't see through it.Not only do I not recommend this film, I encourage people to avoid it. If you're really curious, at least pause the film every few minutes, get up to counter-act the hypnotic effect of the "animation", and think critically about what you've just heard. If it intrigues you, further study in philosophy will likely be entertaining, as well.

I thought I'd love this film but I found little to like.There's very little plot to this film. Basically the protagonist, who we quickly learn is dreaming, spends the whole film passively listening to a series of monologues.Some of the monologues touch on philsophical concepts, such as free will versus determinism. But only at a very basic level. So people familiar with the philosophy will gain nothing, while those new to it, will be put off philosophy, I suspect, by this film.Why? Because most of the monologues are never argued coherently. Someone new to philosophy watching this film might think philosophy is not about reasoned argument, it's just about talking quickly enough to sound clever, and never giving anyone a chance to dissect your ideas.The film also feels rather self-indulgent. One of the characters for example, mentions matter-of-factly that there is a bigger difference between Plato and the common man than between the common man and a chimpanzee. The implication being that the filmmakers and maybe others interested in philosophy are better than those who do not. And you can tell that the makers really think this from the tone of the film.There are a number of facts in the film which are incorrect; I wish I had brought a pad to jot them all down, I can remember two off the top of my head: the fact that we regenerate every 7 years and the fact that dreams are not experienced in real-time. So even where the characters bother to give arguments for their worldviews, those arguments are based on false premises.I have given the film 2/10 and that second star is simply for bravery; for attempting to do something original and thought-provoking (but failing).

reviews.review_title: don't try to judge this as a 'movie'
reviews.content: Possible Spoilers. If you go in to expect a 'normal', 'conventional' movie, you will be disappointed. There is no plot to be found. There is no continuity to be found. However, replacing it, we have some great dialogs, very imaginative way of presenting characters and believe it or not, it is emotionally appealing. This is the type of movie that will leave you thinking about it the next day. Thats what happened to me. Can we control a dream? Can we say in a dream that we are dreaming? Can we be another person from another perspective in a dream? So if a born-blind person dreams, they must dream of having sight? is there physical space time continuation in a dream? Surely we don't have a choice of doing something in a dream. But then again, do we have control in real life? This movie I found is pretty intense in philosophy, as the result, this movie is not for everyone. 7.1/10

This amazing movie has done what thousands of other movies have done, yet like no other.  An insightful variety of perspectives on defining life, motivations, and a mature perspective only available now in this time of imagination and research by advances in neurobiology.  Do not expect this movie to be as billed "an extravagant art masterpiece" because it is so much more than that.  The medium in which Richard Linklater has chosen to represent his world is perfect in form and function and you can only sit back in awe in the masterful storytelling skills of a distinctive voice. One last note, I hope this movie does not "open" your mind, rather crystallize those fragments of thought and creeping suspicions you have had about life in general in the most succinct, well-written dialogue in ages.

I rented the DVD of the film with a high expectation.However,right from the word go,my excitement turned into a big disappointment.Although I tried to watch the film I couldn't stand it more than first 30 minutes. It really sucked.This is the first movie of the director I have seen so far and I am not sure if I really want to see his other works!!

reviews.review_title: A computer enhanced Timothy Leary lecture?
reviews.content: This movie just didn't work for me. I felt like I was constantly being forced to "think", but there was really nothing to think about! Trying to experience it as a dream or "trip" didn't work for me either, since the movie felt so grounded and serious. Graphically, it is interesting, but after an hour, I got bored with the graphics as well.Some critics have compared Waking Life to "My Dinner with Andre" but I don't believe there is any comparison. ...Andre offered me interesting people and interesting discussion.I keep thinking that experiencing Waking Life is a taste of what sitting through a class with Professor Timothy Leary would have felt like. If so, I would have taken a different class.

reviews.review_title: The most important message movie to date
reviews.content: "Waking Life" is not a movie you see  only once. It is packed with so much information for those who have the ears to hear and the eyes to see that seeing it multiple times is the  only way to absorb all the messages. This is a movie about humanity and what is coming for us as we evolve...as the earth evolves and the universe evolves. It is a guide for the enlightened soul to see what's coming for all of is, as we are all going to go thru what the protagonist goes thru before we leave this earth plane. What an important time to be alive on the earth!! Some of us are already aware we are dreamers. Some of us will find out soon. I personally was so bombarded with stimuli that I left the theatre reminded that this is only a dream and we can all change our dreams at will.Personally, I am going to dream in more characters  in my life such as the cosmic teachers in the movie. I would love to be surrounded by teachers who  can explain lucid dreaming, time travel, quantum physics, reincarnation, spiritual evolution and the dream state as reality and I know that the beings on this earth who are imparting this information are highly evolved messengers. They are all around us. I saw this film as one  mans spiritual awakening as he is propelled through experiences of one teacher after another, till he finally gets it, or begins to understand, because there is no end to the growth. I know that this will happen to all of us. Better start listening now and paying attention. We are headed for some really transformational stuff in the next few years, ready or not.This movie fills you in and gives some direction. Brilliant.

Two hours of triple-entendre -- what a complete headtrip! We all spend a lot of energy drawing lines of demarcation between various states of being: awake, sleeping, life, death, holy, commonplace, now, not-now. This is a very persuasive examination of the motivations and repercussions involved in drawing those lines. Persuasive, yes, I've been persuaded! To what point of view, I cannot say. Clearly this bears additional viewings. Let me try the light switch ...

Utterly fascinating. Whether you enjoy it or not, this film will leave you pondering your views on existence... and you can't ask for more than that. I know of no film that resembles Waking Life in terms of animation techniques, story line and dialogue. Definitely worth a viewing.

Wow. I just watched Richard Linklater's Waking Life and I feel like vomiting. Are there actually people like these characters on this planet? If there are, I hope I never meet them. Ever. And I know that anyone who enjoyed this movie is going to say that I "just didn't get it", but, I assure you, I got it. And I hated it. Seriously, if I were the main character in this film, I might contemplate ending it all. His dream state involves him wandering around, bumping into random people and listening to their long, drawn-out diatribes about their "different" "philosophies". I put the word different in quotation marks because the writer of this script obviously was trying really, really hard to achieve that status with the ideas he tried to convey. I put the word philosophies in quotation marks because the arguments of the characters for the most part were weak, extremely left-wing and dripping with pretense. And no one, NO ONE talks the way these characters do. I'm not saying people don't discuss personal philosophies, etc, but if I shut my eyes and listened, I could swear they were just passing around a book by some drugged-out 1960's overly-liberal activist and reading passages aloud. I cannot say how much this movie disappointed me. It could have been great. Even if the message they were trying to convey was still there in another, much subtler form involving, oh, I don't know...a plot. The animation was wonderful and innovative and at first, I thought it would be worth watching just for that. By the end, though, I was so distracted by the preposterous nonsense they were force-feeding me that I was no longer impressed by the visual aspect of the movie. Honestly, if I knew anyone like the writer of this script, I do believe I'd slap them silly. The movie, as a whole, tried so hard to be moving and poignant and thought-provoking that it only ended up making a mockery of itself. Near the end, all I thought about (aside from constantly glancing at the clock to see how soon the movie would end) was which philosopher the next character was going to bastardize and pontificate on for fifteen minutes. It was almost funny when, like clockwork, the character would name drop their philosopher of choice usually within the first sentence out of their mouth. And by "funny", I mostly mean "really, really irritating", which are exactly the words I'd use to sum up this film.

I feel it's trivial to attempt to express the experience of waking life to anyone who has not experienced it themselves. it's like trying to express being in love to someone who's never been, or being drunk to someone who's never been.it is easily the most mentally and visually stimulating film that i have seen in recent memory, if not ever and automatically ranks among the greats of film history in my personal opinion.  at different times in the film, i felt pertubed, enlightened, excited, depressed, frightened, joyous, stoned, like i was having an acid flashback,in various other altered-consciousness states.  the extreme cathartic release of just immersing oneself in this piece of art and letting myself go in film has reinvigorated something both within my personal spirits and within the spirit of film itself by reinventing it as a medium for thought.most amazing of all, it didn't end as the current closed. i felt as if i should be interacting with everyone in the theater and connecting some way, because after all some day i won't be able to wake up. i left the theater literally afraid to turn a light switch or look at my digital watch.  I didn't want to lose grip of that potential for anything.even if mr. linklater's philosophy is diametrically opposed to your own or blotchingly similar, this film is still an enthralling experience and most definitely worthy of a view.  it is one for the ages that will be studied and riddled over for years to come.   It's beautiful and I'd like to send a personal thanks to mr. linklater and the crew of this movie for letting me be a part of it.

When I saw this film all I could picture was a bunch of stuck up yuppies with ponytails and those glasses that pseudo-intellectuals wear sitting around drinking snooty wine discussing this film and the hidden meaning behind it.It is one of those types of films. If you're a realistic person you'll see that this film was actually written by a hippie on drugs. In fact this film was recommended to me by someone that is the quintessential hippie and they said i'd love it. I'll say I understood every concept in it but I far from loved it.I don't need to understand this film to know I'm a smart person. However I'm not an intellectual as many like to think they are. I know the difference between pretentious nonsense and what is worth learning and experiencing.This film is pretentious nonsense. An intellectual would have you think this film is a must. I say if you're truly smart, you'll see through this films disjointed, surreal ideas and know that basically it's just a bunch of people blabbing about nothing hoping you'll think they have something important to say.

This movie is 4 years of college philosophy reconstituted into a 2 hour movie written in common language.. I loved this movie - and I'm amazed a movie like this made it past studio execs.  I knew Linklater had the potential for somthing this great when I saw "Slacker" and "subUrbia" but I never thought I'd do somthing this powerful. The movie is animated, but animated in a way which filmed the movie with real actors, then painted over them with computers. The result is dizzying at first, but it becomes very dreamlike, and lulls you into a different mood. It's not for everyone - but for some, it may be the ultimate movie.

reviews.review_title: Not really a film, a series of lectures and scenes
reviews.content: An odd watch that is best done alone; without distractions. Not going to blow you away but will hold your interest for its length while throwing out interesting ideas. Sadly doesn't have any focus or enough time to discuss any point, but that is clearly the fluid idea of dreams on display. An example of having a goal that is counter to the production of a film.

If you live in the U.S. you probably remember those annoying commercials for Earthlink where video of people talking about their online experiences was rotoscope-animated in an intentionally loose manner, with their features floating and sliding around independently of each other (with occasional liberties being taken like turning a guy's face into that of a rodent when he compares himself to a rat in a maze smelling cheese).  Well, picture one of these commercials being FEATURE-LENGTH.  You've got yourself "Waking Life".Yes, "Waking Life" animation director Bob Sabiston was also responsible for the Earthlink commercials.  While I think the technique has some artistic merit, I think it's best limited to short doses, like commercials or the music video for Zero 7's "Destiny" (directed by "Waking Life" producer Tommy Pallotta).  An entire film of the disconcertingly shifty images is really a bit much.  I suppose on the small screen it should be less seasickness-inducing than it was in theaters, though.

I go to a state school in Austin, and I saw this movie at a local indie movie theater.  I must say that I was very suprised.  I was expecting something (like any other movie) to just plug-in and enjoy.  This deep philosophical journey takes the viewer through various view points of people's "waking life" and how they each define them.  I really enjoyed this movie because it made me think, and I actually had to pay attention to the dialogue instead of relying solely on images to make connections.  I want to see this movie again so that I can soak in as much information as possible that I was caught off-guard the first time around.  Also the animation was amazing! Original and unique to this picture.

reviews.review_title: Totally brilliant and unforgettable - touched with genius
reviews.content: I recently read a comment from Sean Penn along the lines of "if you put more than two ideas in a film, you've committed a crime in Hollywood's eyes and nobody will see your film."  Here is a film that is nothing but ideas, so by Penn's jaundiced reckoner, Richard Linklater would be a serial killer.This could have gone either way; although I was well-disposed towards this film, having enjoyed Linklater's earlier films, much the same applied to Moulin Rouge - which I walked out of!I don't know how good a job I've been making of selling Waking Life to friends ("it's all about philosophy and existentialism!", "There's no plot!").  However, I've made it my goal for the next few weeks to get as many people as possible to see it.  Whoever funded the film deserves a medal, as it must be one of the least commercial films in living memory.I can't vouch for the faithfulness or otherwise of the rendering of existential theories into what passes for dialogue in the film, but it certainly sounds "kosher".  None of the pieces goes on too long - although it does begin with a few doozies, so if you're not completely alienated early on, but are finding it heavy going, DON'T GIVE UP: they get snappier, more varied, and even (on occasion) funnier as the film goes on.Visually, I've never seen anything like it.  I haven't read the other user comments on this site, but I imagine that the animation techniques have already been described, so I won't bother doing that.  What I will say is that I discovered something really extraordinary by accident: I am very short sighted, and NEVER take my glasses off in a film, as I'd see nothing more than a blur.  However, something prompted me to take them off in this film, and I found that when I did that (not all the time, just here and there), I could see more of the "real" film underneath the animation - how freaky is that??Another aspect which I can't praise highly enough is the music, most of it composed for the film by one Glover Gill.  It's simply wonderful, and made me want to go out and buy the soundtrack, which is not something I often do.For what it's worth, this is the first film I've given a "10" rating to - go and see it with an open mind, and willingness to be surprised, and I'm sure you won't regret it.  If nothing else, you can gawp at the beautiful images, looking like a series of lovely water colours.

A little slow getting into it. I started watching this on a recomendation from a friend, and was at first baffled by the cartoonness of this film. It took me a while to appreciate the philosophy behind this movie, the great and intricate things that it had to say. Overall I am very pleased with the surrealness and existentialism. Thanks to the directors, and everyone involved for a very enjoyable 1.5 hours. Or was it just a moment's dream?

Waking Life is a cosmic rumination on the nature of time, existence, reality, dream, the meaning and purpose of life, as well as the nature of cinema. Indeed, the animated reality of Richard Linklater's brilliantly conceived film lies somewhere between a dream and reality. It reflects both on life and death and on itself as a film. It continually brings us into to the kind of dream state that watching a movie inherently induces on its audience, a phenomenon that has been commented on by numerous theorists and filmmakers from psychologist Hugo Munsterberg in the 20's to Andre Bazin in the 50's. Waking Life has some wonderful Bazin references. In particular, the story lives in the form of a dream, or possibly the moment of death, of the central character, who is unable awake from his `dream' and return to `reality'. It is a world populated by a series of colorful and reflective characters whose wonderful and lively monologues ruminate on a range of metaphysical and epistemological ideas and possibilities. These cosmic ruminations play as a series of spirited conversations delivered with enthusiasm, conviction and great sincerity by the actors whose physical presence is uniquely transformed into a separate reality. This has the result of allowing the movie to exist verbally and aurally in grounded and far out conversations, while visually it becomes variously more abstracted, more liquid. The film doesn't allow the viewer to connect the actor's moment' of performance to a corresponding visual reading. The text' happens on one level while visually, it expresses on a separate level. Of course, this is the basic nature of animation. But here the words and voices are focused on language and the expression of ideas - not action - while the image expresses the actor's emotion in a creatively fluctuating graphic spectacle. At the same time, the nature of this particular animation technique allows for continual echoes of the actor's 'real' performance to come through.  It is a brilliantly conceived interplay of concrete ideas expressed through the use and performance of language, concurrent with an abstracted expressionistic performance of those ideas conceived through the visual art of rotoscope animation. This unique volley between the actor, language, ideas, philosophy, painting and animation has the heightened affect of dream, even of psychedelic or peak experience. It certainly qualifies as 'far out'! Waking Life is a bit like `My Dinner with Andre' meets `Yellow Submarine'. Like its main character we are thrust into a heightened world of image and idea, which is the best that dreaming and reality, not to mention cinema, has to offer.

This movie blows my mind - not because of it's context, but because it's out there!  I wish there were more like it!  I can't wait until the DVD release. I love the topics and ideas - totally up my alley!  Such a breath of fresh air to see a movie so mentally stimulating.  The technique used for the animation is one of a kind.

I have never seen a movie that I wanted so desperately to leave. I only stayed because I thought it would improve. I attended this movie with great anticipation, but left utterly disappointed. I can usually find at least some small redeeming quality to even the worst of movies, but not with this one. I found it more entertaining to play 'snakes' on my nokia for the second half.The actors drone on about nothing, and then more actors come on and more hot air is moving through their flapping pieces of meat. I felt like a student in a Peanuts cartoon listening to the unintelligible faceless teacher drone: "Wha wah wah waaah wa whaaah wu. Whah woh."I felt sick when I left the theatre, sick and angry. Sick that I had wasted so much time from my life (time that this movie is supposed to make you think is precious or something). Sick that there are people who found this movie entertaining and recommend it to others highly. Angry that I didn't just leave when I first felt the urge.Please do not see this movie, only that will make me feel better. "Perhaps it is that my only purpose in life is to serve as a warning to others..."
If you like philosophy and dreams, this movie is a mix of both. It's something completely different from what we're used to. A journey to the subconscious it feels like a dream.

reviews.review_title: Deftly made evisceration of ego intellectualism
reviews.content: Like an alcoholic must hit rock bottom usually to kick the habit. To escape your ego perhaps you have to see it at its most absurd? This film takes you on an exploration of the emptiness of the ego. Richard's art is in the space he allows all these seemingly disparate ideas to inhabit. A lessor director would have played favorites and mocked certain ideas. Not Richard all the views in the film inhabit their space in the film. Attacking ideas by grasping onto the opposite idea is a trap of the mind, a trick that allows the ego to regain control over you, and it is one thing that Richard never indulges in. It is conflicting ideas that divide us in camps that cause conflict. Showing these divisions at their most absurd cannot help but demand the viewer ask themselves what is the unifying force?A lot of people find the film pretentious and yes a lot of the ideas in the film are pretentious and overwrought but that doesn't make the film these things. A lot of people get hung up in the ideas in the film. But they're clearly and literally all cartoons. The film lays down the hammer on itself late in the game, telling the viewer to just snap out of it, wake up and embrace life. The whole thing, put the divisions aside and suck on the marrow of life. This is quite a revelatory twist and the deft way the film hides its intentions until late in the game is quite delicious.Lovely film.

The film starts out like a typical wandering airhead student film but eventually delivers beautifully on two insightful points:  (1) that everyone ponders the same serious issues about life and death and (2) that no two humans have exactly the same thoughts on these subjects.  It turns out to be a wonderful testament not only to the universality of life experience, but also to the uniqueness of the individual.
