And most importantly so, what they want to be in the future.The movie presents thousands of thoughts about the nature of life and human beings, all through the eyes of a newborn dreamer-guy. And all by means of an astonishing animated style which swings from dream to reality all at one time.Regardless of the accuracy of ideas presented, this movie is surely one which should make us think and analyse our inner self, deep inside. Something which unfortunately many of us haven't yet learned to do...

reviews.review_title: See this movie; you may find out more about yourself
reviews.content: Going in to this film, I was not prepared for the "heavy-ness" of the subject matter.  A seemingly plot-less film, "Waking Life" deals with a regular guy listening to others as they discuss philosophical and existential matters with him, bringing up interesting points on life and the human psyche.  A little hard to follow, but incredibly relevant; see it with someone you can discuss it with afterwards.  9/10.

reviews.review_title: If I can be serious for just one review...
reviews.content:
I have been known to be not very serious...and somewhat downright caustic in my reviews.  But when it comes to this work, I cannot be.  Waking life is a rare gem, pardon me for stretching this comparison, on par with The Wall. It is a film that studies the fraility of the human psyche, and the conflicts we see inherit in everything we see, hear, feel, and do.
There is obviously the people who will knock it being a animated movie, saying..."well you filmed all these people...why animate?".  Because the very animation gave it the fever dream like lucid qualities that make it what it is.  And being able to stretch and add to reality, further enhances its ideas.  It is the closest I have ever seen someone get to showing how a persons mind can wander and warp.I truly suggest this film, if for no other reason than to just expand your horizons, but I would suggest that it will do much more...JPD

The movie started a little slow, or was it the viewer that started a little slow :P  This is the kind of movie that prompts a statement like that.  It is not a movie that you can casually start up and half pay attention to. Or is it?  Let me clarify, I would not recommend a first viewing of this when any of the following are true:you are tiredyou are busy/preoccupied with something elseyou are unwilling to feel lostyou are unwilling to question life, the universe, and everythingyou are unable to suspend your disbeliefOn that note, let me say that this is a movie that begs to be watched several times.  You will only catch a glimpse of its wealth the first time you watch it.  It is a highly mentally interactive movie.  Do not watch this expecting mindless Hollywood entertainment.I would highly recommend it. Enjoy!

reviews.review_title: A philosophical slap in the face...
reviews.content: The film Waking Life was profound in it's motives to summarize the meaning of human existence. Not only did I find it to be a philosophical slap in the face, but it provoked the darker thoughts to come out from the crevices in our minds. It allowed me to become enlightened by the controversial views of the characters and even enabled me to establish my own opinion about life's meanings and motives. Its structure somehow "loses" you, but I believe that in essence this structure further develops the overall subject in the film; that life is an unpredictable, ever-changing mixture of fantasy and reality.

This is most likely one of the best films I have ever seen. I saw Wkaing Life after A Scanner Darkly. Originally, it was the animation that caught my eye; at first glance, it's style is very similar to that of A Scanner Darkly. The biggest difference is in story line depth. To follow the story line and understand what the main character is truly experiencing, you must watch this film several times. As the pieces slowly fit together, the main character begins to realize what is truly going on in his perpetual dream...In a way, this is a film about a mind trying to rationalize it's own demise. Don't think about that last statement to much, just go see it for yourself.Brilliant!

Very rarely does one leave the movie theater feeling smarter. By and large I exit the local cineplex feeling ashamed that i spent 8 dollars on something that actually reduced my intelligence. Such is not the case with Waking Life.This movie truly makes you think. Not in the sense that one thinks about an issue picture or a documentary, but in a whole other way. For me this movie awakened me to thoughts I had within me but had not fully expressed, or had never taken the time to express. The whole movie I felt cerebrally linked to the hero of our story, which I find to be an amazing thing.Many will tell you that this is a pseudo-intellectual picture, with mixed messages and a stoner's sensibility. I on the other hand feel that the only thing that separates an intellectual from the rest is passion. Passion of subject and passion of self. Waking Life had both of these things in spades. If you don't feel a renewed passion for life after seeing this movie than I personally will give you a full refund.

reviews.review_title: Yay, it's pretentious! Richard Linklater is, like, a total god!
reviews.content: The good thing: The animation. It's wonderful and innovative.The bad thing: Everything else.If Linklater's agenda was to make intellectually budding ninth graders start thinking about life, philosophy, film, and semiotics, then perhaps he didn't fall far from his mark. However, if you've ever attended the first day of any first-year humanities courses in a university, you should just save your money and not see the film.If you've ever sat in one of those trendy coffee shops where everyone has a soulpatch, passionately scribbles poetry, and discusses the meaning of life with their hipster friends, then you should also save your money and not see the film.However, if you're stoned out of your head and sitting in someone's living room and want to say, "Whoah, cosmic!" a lot, then I guess "Waking Life" wouldn't be a complete waste of time.Once again, Linklater wants his viewer to step back and comment on how amazingly brilliant the director is. Such astute dialogue! Such deep, meaningful subject matter! After all, it is about DREAMS, isn't it? People discuss, like, really meaningful stuff, don't they? And if you want a crash course in Bazinian film theory, elementary semiotics, and first-year philosophy, then this is probably cheaper than paying for tuition. But if hearing the phrase, "You know, it's weird that the letters C-A-T in no way represent what a cat is, meaning the essence of a cat. The letters are just arbitrary symbols which we've accepted as the representation of 'a cat'" isn't something completely alien to you, then you will be annoyed. Incredibly annoyed. So annoyed that you'll want to gnaw your arm off at the elbow.This film is unbearably pretentious. It's self-serving intellectual masturbation, and is therefore the cerebral equivalent of all Barbra Streisand movies, wherein she persistently tries to convince us that she's beautiful.The animation is brilliant. But the movie pushes its 'dreams in film' theme to the absolute limit, and comes up empty. And basically we're left with what sounds like a bunch of drunken philosophy students rehashing everything they learned from their inspiring first-day lecture.BOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: A fresh breath of enlightened screen writing.
reviews.content: I just watched this movie, and pretty early on I was a bit thrown... Seemed like it was just going to be some surrealistic interpretation of life or some wishy washiness.The person that this came to me by is one of those fellows who can stand around at a party and just tell you "Watch how this guy talks" while someone is going on one of their endless babbles about religion and politics, the two seemingly how-to-engage-conversation defaults our society seems to like. Just give you a keen observation of the world as we watch people walk through their spiritual journeys. I always sensed some form of power, the same way you find in people... where you can sense they have something to tell you of some import. These are the kinds of people who pass on a copy of Celestine Prophecy with the disclaimer: "It's badly written but worth reading." So along those channels comes this movie. It's not badly written, but it's every bit as worth watching, perhaps moreso because its fantasy is a fantasy we can all grip on to: Dreams.The conversations sound familiar. And the ones that I can't pin with a direct conversation I myself have had I find myself agreeing with. Almost like you're hearing dialogues transcribed out of Alan Watts lectures or getting stoned with a friend and babbling about how religions are merely chosen excuses for people to get together and commune...An important movie for any of the "memedancers" out there looking for the drive behind human interaction.

I don't know what to say.. or why I should say anything. If you want to see with your eyes closed, if you want to hear without your ears, if you want to feel without touching.. then watch this movie. Or better yet, stop browsing the internet looking for movies, and wake up. Just, wake up. Stop doing what you're supposed to do, stop being who you're supposed to be, and just be. Just do. Just think. Just dream. Just wake.I know this sounds ridiculous, and it is in some ways, but do you really think living out your life without being in control is any less ridiculous? This movie is not the answer, but it might help you ask yourself the question. All you have to do, is find the answer yourself.I know I have not been able to do so. I am going to study philosophy, and I'm going to change my world, partially because of this movie, but also because of the questions that are out there, just waiting to be answered. I want to answer the question, I want to wake up. Wake up with me.And, for the people who read this with their eyes open and minds closed: Yes, I thought this was a great movie, and I rate it with a 10/10 for it's uniqueness, creativity and "wow"-factor.

Once you get through the exceptionally wordy (even for Linklater it's wordy!) first thirty or forty minutes, you will find yourself swept away by this literally haunting movie.  Wiley Wiggins begins the movie as a barely believable walking shambles, but by the end, becomes a surprisingly rounded and real character.  The same is true for the writing, where what begins as a jumbled, metaphysical word soup coalesces into something frightening, touching, and wholly unique.  As far as patience goes, if you can get past the hallucinatory animation, and if you are mentally nimble enough to decipher the dialogue (as Henry Silva put it in Amazon Women on the Moon, "BullS***, Or Not?!?"), you will experience a movie unlike any other, and you might find some new things to think about along the way.

First, if you have heard the philosophy before, and are disgruntled by a lack of original experience, you're not really commenting on the film, are you? And I doubt anyone who has already commented will come back to read this, but it is rather late at night, and I feel like a ramble. I think that the culmination of this film is the important part, and no matter whether you had heard of P.K. Dick's dream and subsequent philosophy on time before or not, the visual image of the dreamer saying 'yes' to God and floating 'on up' gave me a moment's pause. There is no separation from this experience and our own! Jung loved film because it was a way to play out all the archetypes at once; this film succeeds in this goal quite admirably. I still feel a vague sinking fear when confronted with the prospect of a dream from which I will never awake, but all of us who are not yet part of the unity experience this, whether we would like to believe so or not (please, let me know if I'm wrong!). Cynicism and being overly critical are just guises for this spiritual discomfort. I remember my first acid trip, when I felt like I would never really feel 'comfortable' again, and I wonder whether wide-eyed experience of the Godhead is really to be desired, or rather acclimation to it. This all depends on the role of consciousness after death, and the mode of its dissolution. If the dissolution is a slow, entrapping-yet-freeing process as experienced by the main character, I kind of feel like ripping the skin off my face. But the other option seems to be oblivion. What a state of things. Ramble over, doubt this will be useful, but I suppose we're all in this together...

Wonderful movie. The media contents everywhere should be like this, full of useful opinions and information, and maybe we will be able to think more and come out of the social established trance. The contents of each scene inside the dream is accompanied by changes of colours and perspectives in the visual part, anger for example is expressed with a red or purple colour. Regarding some descriptions inside the movie made by characters I have to say that the viewer totally imaging's the situation, it's like reading a book. From the moment that it begins, the picture and words suck you in and you can't escape from it, it requires all your attention (good thing), it motivates you to think, more should follow this lead, great piece.

At first the visuals impressed me, they are really something new and I thought they were well made to transport a philosophical message, but I after half of the movie I realized that's it. This is the movie and it is nothing more than intellectual phrases and opinions, not a movie at all.And it's not like anything that was said is ground breaking new or has been put in great perspective or insight, no, nothing. It's a messy collection of basic philosophical statements and they go just as randomly as they come. They don't build up, tell a story or provoke a special thought. The director covers this mess up by suggesting that he might dream ... yeah wow ...I love philosophy but this movie was absolutely nothing new, it could be for someone who never got in touch with philosophy but in this case I doubt this is what such a person could like. But at least they could say they liked it to impress others. :) I'm giving it 3 stars just for the appreciation of the visuals and the approach of a philosophical genre. Hopefully there will be more such (better made) movies in future.

In order to fully appreciate this movie, you must let go and enjoy the experience. I spent the first half of the film trying to figure out what was going on, who the main characters were, and where the plot was headed. But once I realized that there's nothing to figure out, I began to actually enjoy it. The movie is a strange concoction of conversations and scenes with various real and interesting people, shot on video and then animated by different artists with Rotoshop. While it can be aimless at times, the best scenes and fascinating ideas make it worth watching. I'd recommend watching it more than once, as you'll discover more with each viewing.

This highly original, extremely entertaining piece is an experience completely unlike any other. Its imaginative, playful, delicious tone, delivery, and content is sure to entrance even the most pessimistic and resistant viewer and to delight anyone with whom it comes in contact. This film transcends its own occasionally awkward acting and delivers a cohesive yet adventurous and unpredictable journey.I wish more movies were like Waking Life, and I recommend it to anybody without hesitation. Simultaneously mind-spinning and eye-satiating, this work is not to be missed. Take the next opportunity you get to watch Waking Life. Your brain will never be quite the same, and it will thank you for it!

I LOVED this film, brilliantly challenging ideas, and wonderful visual presentation. A must see for ANYONE pursuing or completing a philosophy major. However, for this movies is not for dummies. If you are looking for a mind-numbing action film, go elsewhere. If you just want to zone out after thinking too hard, go elsewhere.  If you want to be intellectually stimulated and have good conversations after you film experience, watch this movie.  Excellent for the seduction of philosophers, not excellent for the seduction of idiots.  Anyway, if you are a thinker, or perhaps just want to stretch your brain, check it out, I think you will be pleased.

reviews.review_title: i admittedly, completely love this movie. it changed my life.
reviews.content: to appreciate it, you've got to watch it all the way through. i suggest watching it alone, so that you can listen intently and concentrate. this movie changed the way i see things and how i feel about being in touch with myself. good god, rent this. you won't regret it. oh, but the first 20 minutes i was thinking the same things as the other commenter..."ew. oh man i feel sea sick. what the heck IS this! animated freak-show?!" but trust me. it's now my favorite movie ever. it's very philosophical and full of wise lines/ideas/concepts.

WARNING: This film is amazing.  Watching it will spark neurons in your brain that you did not know existed.  You may have deep, meaningful conversations about life, death, dreams, and everything else.  It is not a cartoon.Waking Life is one of the greatest movies I've ever seen, and I have seen quite a few.  Calling it a movie does not do it justice though, because it does not have a plot in the conventional sense.  It is a lengthy film following the journey of a young man through dreams, or is it reality, or is it both?  Wiley Wiggins, our protagonist through this film, travels around to various situations, listening in on, and joining fascinating conversations that can best be described as philosophical.  This movie is surreal.  That is all there is to it.  It is 99 minutes of conversation, so do not come in expecting explosions, romance, or any other of the usual Hollywood standards.  And yes, the film is animated, but not a cartoon. The entire film was shot on DV (digital video format) and then animated over on computers but over 25 different animators.  This gives Waking Life a look like nothing else you've ever seen, with a constantly evolving animation style.  Don't let the fact that it is animated scare you off, you'll be upset that you did.Overall, Waking Life is truly an incredible work.  Calling this movie a "trip", is an understatement, this will leave your head spinning for days. It's full of ideas and beliefs that people are rarely exposed to, or even think about, on a day-by-day basis.  Make sure you watch it with someone else, because you're going to want to do a lot of discussion afterwards. So do yourself a favor, go buy this movie...now.

reviews.review_title: great film...(possible spoiler below, yet there is so much that you won't notice)
reviews.content: on the message board drugs was mentioned as missing in what the film dealt with and I'd just like to say that i agree that this was a film about the joys of dreaming and life and how to harness that beauty of life and being able to walk through it awake, or dreaming, and that drugs aren't necessary for this. the world is a multitude of stimuli that supercedes artificial pleasure and instant gratification such as TV, which was dealt with quite well i thought. didn't you feel disappointed everytime he sat down to watch the tube?  "no, go back out and talk to more poeple..don't get sucked into that thing...look! there isn't even anything on...you can't interact with it..." like the film said, you don't necessarily need to say anything while communicating, you are already communicating on so many levels...it might not be as strong or as apperent as the red faced driver yelling into the loud speaker but you are interacting...with the tv, no, with life yes...drugs? who needs them in such an already fantastic world, with dreams!

Interesting animation with time proven jerky-camera effect a la Homicide (Barry Levinson). Perhaps interesting for the under-30 (25) crowd who have only begun to discover existential thinking "why are we?". Tiring, trite &, ultimately all, said before.  Only new issue is the fashion by which it is presented. Ultimately, boring after the first 15 minutes.

reviews.review_title: Visually stunning, but the philosophizing is tiresome
reviews.content: Definitely a visually stunning, novel movie. Beyond that, though, it's a bit annoying. I have to concur with those folks who disliked the sophomoric, armchair philosophizing that makes up the bulk of the movie.None of the ideas are presented in any depth, and none are terribly insightful. As another post pointed out, its not unlike the sort of conversation you might have with a friend after a few (too many) drinks, but compressed into sound bites, and delivered with an unduly pedantic and bombastic tone.The first third or so of the movie consists of nothing but these abbreviated sententious pedagogical essays, one after another, and I got very antsy at the thought that the whole movie might offer nothing but this. Thankfully, it broadened its focus, and garnered a few laughs and went a few places in the last half.So, yeah, don't pay to see this in the theater. And if you do, don't expect anything other than your eyes to be entertained. And, although the urge may be strong, don't leave after 15 minutes like some folks did; it gets a bit better.

this is a very nice movie, not only because of great graphics, but also because of its content. the conversations flow from one to another, and there are clues as to what is happening to the boy all throughout the movie. it's not "deep", or "heavy", but it's definitely interesting and enjoyable.the best thing about it is that it's different from the usual hollywood recipes for a "successful movie", a fresh look at life and the people around us. i recommend it to everyone. oh, and the music is also good.

When I saw this film I couldn't believe what director Linklater was putting us through. You see 100 Minutes of people talking to each other. There is no plot at all in this movie, it tells no story whatsoever. Linklater wasted the style in which the movie is done, a truly hallucinogenic style of animation, for a piece of film that is just uninspired. He should have written a book to tell us his thoughts, instead he has 30 or so different characters tell them to us, non stop. After a short while it's simply too much info to take and you just tune out. Sure, there are moments and dialogues that are really great, but they are buried deep between huge piles of wasted time.See it for the trippy animations, but wear a walkman, hear some good music, i guess the film will improve instantly...

Radical filmmaking - concept, execution and philsophy. Richard Linklater and his courageous fellow travellers and created a moment in cinematic history as dramatic and groundbreaking as the Nouvelle Vague of the sixties and seventies.Technique and content combine to transport the viewer into new realms of thought and expression - a freedom to move within a realm of ideas, feelings and visual stimulation that combine to define a whole new realm of art. Here for the first time, film and multimedia combine to illustrate a thesis that is fundamental to the ongoing survival of our species as the accelerate through the new millennium.Go and see this film. As soon as the DVD comes out, go and own this film. This is a statement for our time - our moment in history. compulsory viewing.

A movie that doesn't have your typical structure visuals and dialogue, so it's not for everyone, and even if it is for you, you might need to be in the proper mood.
A curious (and pioneering at the time) visual format and plenty of philosophical dialogue is the recipe for this one and if you are in the mood for that, just sit down and enjoy the ride because the sea refuses no river.

reviews.review_title: My Sister Summed It Up Best
reviews.content: She called this, "Pretentious piece of crap."Most times she and I disagree, however I cannot this time. While the dialogue provided interesting fodder for intelligent conversation its constant embedded comments about the narrative's brilliance forces me to say that this movie is for the same people who go to the Hamptons, drink expensive schnapps and haven't a clue how the real world works.

I wish someone would have told me how incredibly BORING this movie was going to be before I watched it. If I wanted to hear philosophical babble about random parts of our lives in no order whatsoever I would've rented a bunch of philosophy books from the library. The animation is kind of cool, but the movie could have been made a lot better, and made from a different point of view. Lucid dreaming is a really interesting topic...and an even more interesting thing to explore for yourself. The title "Waking life" leads you to believe the movie is going to be about lucid dreaming, however, as it turns out its just about random philosophy.

reviews.review_title: Truly a film, not a movie.
reviews.content: A truly genius existential exploration. The jerky and varied styles of animation (and conversation) come together brilliantly. Without giving anything away, this is a film that explores self-exploration and the reality of dream-states. It is amusing, creepy, fascinating, brilliant, and deep all at the same time.

Richard Linklater has done something most of us can't do.  You know how when somebody starts to tell you this INCREDIBLE dream they had last night and you get bored before they even get going?  You know how when you have an INCREDIBLE dream and you want to tell someone and they start yawning and looking for an escape hatch before you even start?Well, this movie is about a guy stuck in a dream, only there's not a boring moment in it.  Linklater's staff of artists (that's artists, not animators) has made this a visual treat like no other.  His team of actors are convincing both as people you know and as dream characters.  The situations are intimately familiar in their comedy, their insanity, their intellect, their anger, and Tosca's music lends a bleak, eerie isolation to the whole palette.This is a film that stays with you long after you leave the theatre.

Jean-Luc Goddard's 1967 film ended with the title "Fin du Cinema".  And ever since then Goddard has been hanging around places like the Cannes Film Festival telling everybody that cinema is a dead art-form.What I wouldn't give to sit Goddard down in front of Richard Linklater's "Waking Life" and see if he truly believes that art in cinema is dead.This brilliant new film was shot on digital video and then a team of animators took years painstaking animating every frame.  The result is a film which is an assault of ideas on consciousness, our sub-conscious, life, death and our preceptions of the world we inhabit; punctuated with the most exuberantly exciting visuals that I have been seen in a film in a long time.The film centers around a philosophy student, (played by "Dazed and Confused"'s Wiley Wiggins.), who wanders around Austin, Texas encountering a lot of intellectuals, poets, philosophers and eccentrics.  As the main charcter wanders around, he notices there is something very bizarre about the world he is currently inhabiting.  His surroundings pulsate like a heartbeat, several existentialist philosophers morph into the very ideas that they are trying to communicate.  It soon becomes clear to our main character that he may in fact be dreaming.  Unfortunately for him, he seems to be trapped in his dream-state; waking up from one dream only to immediately enter into another one.  Amd then his plight appears to be even more drastic when it's suggested that he may in fact may be dead wandering around in some alternate state of consciousness.This is an incredible film jammed-packed with ideas and visuals.  The viewer is bombarded with ideas on how to live our lives and how to interpret our consciousness and sub-consciousness.  The film requires multiple viewings to even begin to process all these ideas.  I saw the film twice at the Toronto Film Festival and I know I have a long way to go before I can really grasp the depth of this film.  Linklater's past films, ("Slacker", "Before Sunrise"), discussed philosophical concepts, but this is the first time the director has directly tackled philosophical ideas head-on; discussing Kirkegard and St. Thomas Aquanis.  In the near-future, this movie will, most likely, be screened by just about every Philosophy professor in the english-speaking world.I have been saying for years that Richard Linklater is the most brilliant and gifted artist to emerge out of American cinema in the past decade; and with "Waking Life", he may finally get the respect he deserves.

reviews.review_title: One of the single most engaging movies you'll see in years.
reviews.content: Alright, as everyone else has pointed out, this movie has two levels (like most movies do) the story line and 'everything else'. When people say 'they filmed it then they animated it', don't think Bakshi. This isn't an attempt to enhance animation by basing it on the real world, it's an attempt to enhance film while acting as a plot device using animation. The effect is incredible. Some of it is silly, some of it is blatant, but in a movie as geared towards variety and exploration as this one is, these things should be expected, even applauded.As for the story line, well, there almost isn't one. This is definitely a case of 90% plot trying to support 10% actual story, a story you don't even really get a hint of (at least the first time through the movie) until you're already half way through. This, however, doesn't make it a bad story, just a different way of telling it. Unlike most films these days, which spoon feed you every possible relevant detail, Waking Life expects you to think and think hard.On a final note, I have heard a small minority, both in real life and on this message board, talk about how it's all cheap, pretentious philosophy. I assure you, this whining comes from people who took an entry level philosophy course, learned of the existence of all the basics like post-modernism and futurism and came to the conclusion that they understood them and that was that. What's pretentious is pretending you're intelligent by trashing a movie because it draws from sources you can associate with your 101 philosophy class. We're so sorry it didn't just focus on guns and breasts. Suffice to say, anyone calling this movie pretentious is simply being pretentious, trying to seem clever by saying "Well, it didn't make ME think."  Big surprise there. For future reference, philosophies don't just become 'old hat' once you've heard them once. They exist for you to explore consciously, not for you to say 'heard it, bring on the explosions.'Overall, Waking Life is appealing because it does explore, on the surface, ideas that rarely make it into popular film at all these days, and when they do usually have to be dredged from the depths. It uses devices on all fronts that break from the norm, and just generally proves that film can be true art without completely abandoning any sense of coherency.

reviews.review_title: Just Saw it For the First Time Tonight
reviews.content: I just saw this movie and I like it. I didn't think I would, but I did. It is almost a chore to watch just trying to keep up with the dialog. The most interesting thing about it is that the whole movie takes place in the main character's seemingly never ending dream. A dream he keeps waking up from, only to find out he's still in it. With a movie like that, it is easy to suspend one's disbelief infinitely, in other words, there can be no concept of time, no plot holes, nothing realistically has to make sense. This gives the movie a complete freedom. A string of characters, conversations and moments that have one thing in common: a seemingly deep philosophical meaning. This is definitely a movie that requires its viewer to have an open and curious mind. It may or may not make anybody happy, sad or angry. It may not make anybody feel anything. It simply gives you intriguing seeds of thought from a different point of view. Take from it what you will. I walked away somehow feeling a little bit smarter. I think I'll watch it again.

The first time I saw this movie on cable, it only lasted 2 minutes  in my screen: ¿what was the point of getting into the trouble of making  an animation movie only to show people talking fast and endlessly until making your stomach sick?Tonight I saw Walking Life again, in a more "receptive" mood, if you know what I mean, and I enjoyed the movie with this trick: when the phenomenal task of following the dialog was too hard, I only paid attention to the beautiful art of the movie, the intriguing way the faces of the people are drawn, with the expression in constant movement, more expressive than real faces.I must tell you (you already must know by my writing) that my mother language is Spanish, ant the subtitles are nearly impossible to follow in the most talkative picture I've seen in my life. Without reading the subtitles I missed something like 1 word in 20.But the talking is great most of the time, smart and creative ideas to stimulate the intellectual kind watching the movieIn conclusion, watch this movie 1. if you like a bombing of words with ideas to think about, some surprisingly powerful, some too twisted to follow 2. if you are a fan of animation art, and you can enjoy a movie even if you don't care what they are talking aboutAh, the tango music is great and I loved the tango scene with the orchestra of ladies!

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie I have ever seen!
reviews.content: The is the best movie I have ever seen! It takes the cake in so many different ways I can not even to begin to describe it.  Once you see this movie, you out take on life will be a whole lot different.

Indeed the "cartoon" element is there to remind it is all a dram, the movie that is. The constantly moving fragments of the background are not what one would call mentally-soothing, but then again they contribute to overall uniqueness of the film. The story is a gallery of many well-known and many unspoken theories regarding human existance. Naturally, most people would find them rather controversial. However, this should not the least deter you from seeing the movie. I recommend it to anyone who's heard of "I think, therefore I am."

As I watched this film, having avoided all reviews, I found the closest parallel to be reading the dialogs of Plato in Beg. Philosophy classes. In each of these, there is a backdrop setting that allows the characters to expound on their themes.Those dialogs are worthwhile to read, however, they are hardly page turners either. The same with this film.

reviews.review_title: Not Deep, don't understand why I like it, very entertaining
reviews.content:
*while there isn't much to spoil, you might not want to read this if you're going to get upset if I tell you something about the film.*I watched this film twice, and I don't fully understand (although I'm sure no one does).  The first thing I did after watching it the second time was to surf the web to see if anyone had written anything about it.  I wasn't looking for a review, but rather something that went beyond that and actually analyzed that film.  I think I'll have to wait longer than that for anything to come out about it.I don't think this film has anything too extremely deep to say rather I consider it much like films such as being john malkovich where the general public who is so dumbed down will think that any movie that says something that makes them think is deep.  I'm not a huge philosopher guy(my terminology there makes this aparent), but I've still heard the majority of stuff that took place in that in film before.  If left me with little to think about, but I still really enjoyed the way that it was all tied together.One of my pet peeves in a film is when it goes through and has an excellent narrative and then at the end messes everything up by going into complete wierdness.  I guess I enjoyed the other way around where there's an utterly wierd film and then all of the sudden like out of nowhere there's narrative.
As I go on here I just think that I really liked that movie in a way I can't explain. I enjoyed the dialouge, even though it didn't make me think much about anything, when I'd really thought most of that stuff before.  Maybe I'm a psuedo philosopher one thing I noticed upon studying descartes was that he was writing about ideas that I thought up and then these ideas proceeded to scare the crap out of me when I was ten and was having trouble falling asleep(I was a real amnesiac back in the day).  However, that would fall into the same crap that Ethan Hawk was saying in that movie about once an idea is out there you can somehow pick up on it.  I guess I just enjoy stuff like that.The other thing I'm thinking is that maybe intentional that this stuff is not meant to make you think to much, but rather just to show you how this guy discovered he was living in a dream state.The main thing about that movie that caused me to give it a rating of 9 out 10 is that I imensely enjoyed myself watching the film.  and while I can think of tons of reasons why not to like it and then as a consequence try to come up with justifications for liking it I can't really do either.  all I can say is there's something about it that caused it all to click.Synopsis - Not Deep, Don't understand why I like it, very entertaining.

There is no denying the beauty of the animation of Waking Life. It is gorgeous to look at. I just wish someone had had a chance to edit the script.Linklater reminds me of the kind of guy who was amazing to listen to when you were in your late teens, but as you grow older, so does what he has to say. If it doesn't bother you to have undeveloped characters appear out of nowhere to spew his lines, then it's worth the trip. But if you're looking for beauty and a story, look someplace else.

reviews.review_title: So much more than just a good cause
reviews.content: I just read a review posted on this site for the film "Waking Life" that compared it to "Mallrats" and "Dogma". First of all, I would like to state that I was appalled by this refrence, as well as the remark concerning the "ow, wow! highschool generation". I too see little hope in todays teens, however this film is quite out of reach of the general public.  The ideas in this film managed to maintain a quite dignity without being presumptuous and assuming that the viewer is able to understand the grand terms and psychological britter-bratter that some other films may use.  It is a great experience to watch the animated film illuminate your television screen with visual communication like an acid trip. I suggest this movie to anyone who wants to be introduced to philosophy and understand more clearly the subject of lucid dreaming. If you think the story goes nowhere about 20mins. or so into it than you are very wrong but probably a member of the "general public" and wouldn't like the ending anyway. But if you have the ability to appreciate creativity and artful cinematography than watch "Waking Life".

Waking Life has been hailed by critics and audiences alike as "brilliant", and while most of the dialogue, along with the theme of the movie, is rather gripping, to me the movie ultimately came through as a smoke and mirrors show.The movie is about a young man searching for an answer to the question: "Are we sleep walking through our waking life or wake walking through our sleeping life?". Throughout the movie, you witness various conversations between people pondering this question among other things that we would tie in with the meaning of life. The dialogue is great in the sense that it shows a higher level of thought than you encounter with most movies, however, this is also where the movie becomes rather transparent. While the theme of the movie should provide a rather gripping storyline, there really is no story. The movie erratically pulls you from one conversation to the next, and while it provides you with a reason for this at the end, it really just seems like an excuse for the movie trying too hard to sound intelligent. A movie like, let's say, Donnie Darko, provides you with engaging philosophical dialogue that also creates a bond between you and the character. Waking Life provides no such character development. Most movies that try to make the viewer think start with an idea and then the writers say "how can we make the characters interesting and also make the dialogue appealing to someone who is a deep thinker?". Waking Life seems like they came up with the dialogue and then said "well let's make up some characters to say all this stuff and then piece it into a film". This is why the movie ultimately fails in my mind. The characters are boring and one dimensional, with the only personality types really being thoughtful, caring, and philosophical with three or four more outlandish speakers. You don't care what happens to the characters, and while you want to hear what they have to say, they are just so incredibly boring that you feel restless. After about the third or forth conversation you think to yourself "is this all it is?". All these people seem to be looking for the meaning of life but they will obviously never find it because they appear not to have lives. They sit secluded from the rest of society spending all their time pondering the meaning of life without realizing that while it is important to ask the big questions, you will never even come close to finding out the meaning of life unless you go out and have real life experiences. This is ironic because it is apparent that the movie is trying to make you admire these characters through their thought provoking speeches, and trust me, they are less than admirable, in fact a better word would be pathetic. Some of the questions these people pose aren't even that deep. One woman tells her friend: "You know how our cells continuously regenerate? Well every seven years we are composed of completely new cells than we were before, but if I am composed of all new cells how can I be the same person?". Am I the only one who knows anything about cytology? It's simple honey, your cells divide through binary fission, and every cell is identical to its predecessor. A skin cell is going to be the same as every other skin cell you have had, same goes for a brain cell, and that's why you are the same. Somehow they even ruined the cinematography, which originally seemed brilliant. The animated characters always seem to be warping or twisting, and if they aren't the background is. I couldn't help but feeling though that if they had developed the characters more, they could have done more with this style of animation to dazzle the viewer.I can use one word to describe this movie: pretentious. It talks the talk but it really doesn't walk the walk. It's got great dialogue but the characters and story have no substance, and if all you've got is thought provoking dialogue, write a thesis and leave it at that. Don't even rent Waking Life, because you'll probably watch about 20 minutes of it before you see right through it.

This film touches on a lot of philosophical ideas, and it really makes the viewer think about his own consciousness and life in general.  Are we really just living a dream inside a dream, googles and googleplexes?There are some interesting conversations with interesting, university-type people, oddballs and casual observers alike, each new conversation very interesting and thought-provoking.  The animation was truly interesting and entertaining, too.  Sometimes it was a bit much for me, but mostly it was subtle enough to allow me to listen intently to the ideas expounded.  I'll certainly want to watch this film again and research some of the ideas and names mentioned.  Good flick.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful... Like stabbing out your eyeballs
reviews.content: Easily the worst film I have ever seen. Not only did you want to slap the stoned people depicted in the film, but you wanted to down an entire bottle of Advil over the way too crappy animations, which are not only out of focus, but leaning towards sea sickness. I would recommend stabbing out your eyeballs and jumping off a cliff before seeing this film. Not only a waste of time I'll never get back, but I believe it actually shortened my life watching it, and raised my chances of stroke. Pure college kids on a drug trip garbage, don't waste your time. Reading this review was too much time wasted on this film. I hope the creators of the film never make another in their lives, yes it was that bad.

reviews.review_title: Trippy philosophy class set to film
reviews.content: I was excited about this movie before entering the theater... and amazed when I left it.The conversations throughout this film are fascinating and thought-provoking.  I found myself either nodding in agreement or forced to think about what the assorted characters are conveying in their views. This is the kind of movie I wished I saw on videocassette, so I can liberally stop the movie to reflect on what was just said.Visually, this film is beautiful.  IMHO, it is purposefully detached to make the subject matter of the film seem less "heavy."I recommend this movie to everybody.  It will truly make you see things differently.

I saw this movie for the first time in my high school philosophy class. The movie was executed in a way I has not seen before, and the concise and in-depth discussion of various philosophies and their applications and ramifications on our day to day lives left me -my entire class- speechless and with a renewed sense of enthusiasm. Despite having been in a philosophy class, anyone who has even thought about why we are here, and how things work will at least be able to come away with an understanding and curiosity about the philosophy discussed in this film. However, Waking Life also deals with the subject matter of dreams, and how they relate to life. And while the plot may seem non-existent, its there, its just much more simple than most people would think to look for. All in all, I say for anyone who likes unconventional movies, with a lot of dialogue, this movie is top choice.

reviews.review_title: All cliches aside, "Waking Life" is a film who's dialogue and visuals compete for your attention, yet never loses focus.
reviews.content: It is very difficult to categorize this movie.  Simply put, the movie follows the spiritual journey of a young boy shifting from one conversation to another conversation.  The focus of the dialogues and monologues in the movie explore human ideologies which range from the concepts of man's role on the planet, revenge, human linguistical theory, lucid dreaming, and fundamental political commentary."Waking Life" is not going to appeal to everyone.  It demands a certain level of open-mindedness.  The visuals are unbelievable.  The creators filmed the movie with inexpensive camera equipment and finished the movie with this outstanding, and unexplainably unique rotoscoping technique that has to be seen to be believed.All cliches aside, "Waking Life" is a film who's dialogue and visuals compete for your attention, yet never loses focus.Its a shame that it didn't, at the very least, get nominated for "Best Animated Film" at this year's Academy Awards. Such an oversight on the Academy's part is going to insure that many people won't be made aware of this wonderful film.

This movie left me astonished. It was to me something like philosophy artwork, to say the least. This is something I could undeniably watch several times over. I absolutely love listening to the quote "lecture" pieces in this flick. I would watch over and over just to keep these philosophies on life, government, human thought, and over all lucid dreams for memorization. If are person who when listening to great thoughts gets that little spark in the back of your mind that begs for more to pour into your ears, than this is the flick for you.
Plus the animation is something I think is quite intriguing. And lastly the music complements each scene, which I think is really important for a movie to have. It's pretty terrible to see a movie where the music doesn't seem to match the shots.

Interesting, but not terrific... I'm not certain how a film who's script resembles a melange of philosophical dictaphone notes can really grab anyone's attention?  It sort-of works, but sadly, I must admit that I fell asleep in my chair before the end (perhaps a result of the gently swaying graphics.) I can't imagine I missed anything crucial.

reviews.review_title: Waking Life" is definitely not about dreaming (in the strict sense)
reviews.content: I feel like my transport should be an extension of my personality. And this is like my little window to the world...", says the boat car guy in the beginning of the movie. That little window to the world" is a metaphor for perspective, the transport" is a characterization of that perspective as mine". We all perceive the world through our own unique little windows, biased to our own perspective, to the way of seeing things from our point of view. Every crossway we find ourselves in as far as it goes determines the course of our life because, while we choose the way to go from there, we don't choose the crossway itself, that particular point of departure, or the possibilities which are confined to the human reality. Nevertheless that reality which we find ourselves in is the same for all of us but the way we perceive it (interpret it) can be radically different. The movie is practically about those different perspectives or, to be more precise, about exposing the bias of our interpretations of reality. It does not try to answer the question (at least directly) about which is the right way of seeing things but rather tries to show the absurdness of the question itself. The obvious contrarieties which appear among the views presented in the movie are meant not to present different, independent ideas so we could then choose which are the right ones but to shake us up, to question the question, to realize the playfulness of it all and therefore to comprehend that we should not take seriously any of it. It is a wake up call. And to wake up here means not to escape from the dream to somewhere else (we can not escape from this dream, same as the main character of movie, because the dream is our wakening life itself) but to realize our own freedom in constituting it.

I must say I was disappointed with this film.I thought that it came across as one of those films that was trying too hard to be intelligent and it didn't quite work out. The idea of the film was a great one, but I felt it was executed the wrong way.I liked the animation of the film, interesting how the camera swings yet it's almost like it's been painted over the top. Adds a surreal feeling which helps when it's main purpose is telling the story of dream life.Too much nonsense was thrown in with the important and interesting views on life from a lot of the characters, it just got too much.Perhaps just one of those films that people say they like, because in fact they didn't quite get it.

reviews.review_title: Unique and interesting, though rather pretentious and a little too long.
reviews.content: A decent movie, though a bit overrated. The animation is unique, and ranges from fascinating to rather ugly. The core of the movie is the conversations with people about life and dreams and such, and most of what they have to say is pretty interesting or amusing, and makes you think. The main downside is that they are rather pretentious and arrogant-sounding, and by the time you're half of the way through the movie that can get on your nerves, since it's pretty much constant chatter from one philosopher to the next. The ending isn't anything special either. I give it 7/10 because the dialogue is interesting and thought-provoking most of the time, and even when it isn't, the animation is still entertaining. Also, it at least tries to be deep and meaningful, unlike most of the movies being released today. Whether you love it or hate it, you can appreciate its uniqueness.

reviews.review_title: if life were like dreaming we'd never have to worry about waking up
reviews.content: everyone who thinks this movie is boring, too long...are you at all interested in philosophy? probably not. and if you're not, why did you watch this movie? the content is thought provoking and beautifully phrased, the animation is entrancing...it has the feeling of watching a beautiful swirling screen display while listening to the deepest, most personal song on your harddrive.

reviews.review_title: Excellent, thought-provoking and refreshing philosophical conversations & musings
reviews.content: Very thought-provoking, uplifting movie. It's true that it's not for all people - but that's true with ANY movie. There are those (like me & four of my friends) who have seen the movie and love it. Then there are others (1 of my friends, 2 family members) who don't "get it" or like it as much, if at all.I guess it really depends on how much the concepts the various characters discuss matter to you or are of personal interest. Have you had in-depth conversations rolling over in bed with your lover about the meaning of life, time, dreams, the universe, the soul?I'm sure there are better words to express how amazing a film Waking Life is, but I'm short of them. Just see the film and judge for yourself. Like the author of a previous comment said, "Different strokes for different folks."I love the sense of power for the individual in the search for meaning presented here. If my best friend and I are depressed, we can watch this and begin to feel better, realizing so much about the potential of the human spirit. Not many movies - independent or otherwise - can do that.

reviews.review_title: This is the last film intelligent people ever need to watch.
reviews.content: This film is a serious look at how modernity has had a catastrophic effect on the average human life. The main character Wiley Wiggins is a archetype of theaverage mediated person who is unable to make decision, create, or performheroic actions. He spends his life floating in a sea of opinions which run the gamet from superior to inferior yet is so poisoned from living in a society that promotes forced equality that he considers all opinions the same and tolerates them all. He is unable to make distinctions between what is real or unreal and in the end, having no real dreams of his own, is swept away into nothingness.Dream is Destiny.Like many, Wiggins has no real thoughts or ideas of his own and is a passivespectator of life who spends his waking life just killing time. Like the people who find this movie boring, Wiggins is the result of externalizing all things in life while avoiding any attempt at introspection or concluding thoughts with actions. It is exactly this type of "individual" that the movie is projecting. The film is not an attack nor is it delivered in a condescending way but is rendered in a eriedesperation of sorts where a film director really has no way of communicating effectively to the Wiggins of the world, or Wiggins in the theater, anythingmeaningful or truthful that they will understand. In one scene, Wiggens is yet again in a "one speaking to many" speech by a morphing humanist / evolutionist professor who is so entrenched with the modern bankrupt philosophy ofindividualism that he has overlooked the fact that he is part of a living species himself. In other words, this professor views human life and people like lab mice and hopes that the new neo-human might one day disply traits like truth andjustice naturally. The aware viewer will notice the numerous contradictionsmade by the speakers and not resign his or her thoughts to futility or paradox.Entertainment addicts will not like this film since it exposes them to themselves in a very honest and compelling way.

reviews.review_title: Great movie if you like'm slow
reviews.content: If you want a movie that takes you on a wild tale of adventure then watch The Never Ending story.  If you want to learn more ways to kill a man then watch Casino.  This movie is about the mind; what we experience every day. If your used to action packed movies with crazy special effects then this probably isn't for you.  This movie is for people who enjoy leaving the theater after 100 minutes of silence and still thinking about it when you go to sleep.  It doesn't have anything new to say, but you'll be hard pressed to find that in this world anyway.  This is a great way to experience an age old message.

I just watched this movie for the first time last night, a GREAT movie, very interesting on several accounts.First off, yes, it's animation, but it's VERY real animation, almost surreal in how lifelike some of the scenes are. This wonderful style of animation, along with the constant motion (walls floating around, tables jostling, etc) and the brilliant colors and images, makes this movie really memorable.The content though, wow. A LOT to see in one sitting, without taking notes or writing thoughts down. It's almost worth it to watch the movie in 5 minute segments (it's basically broken down into conversations between the main character and his dream characters, who present life to him), and fully understand and sort through all that you just saw and heard, and then go on, or rewatch each scene once or twice to get more out of it, both visually and intellectually.Don't be turned off by the animation, it's as true to life as can be, and the movie itself is great. A must see, with friends and family if possible, so you can have some soundboards to bounce ideas back and forth with, this is definitely not a single interpretation movie.

reviews.review_title: Thought provoking? If you are completely unsure of the world around you, yes.
reviews.content: For those who have experience and a knowledge for what is and isn't true, and what is and isn't important, this film is like a small minded person trying to show a deeper picture of the world, and failing by default: because the person has no idea of the deeper world. Hearing the dialogue for any period of time makes me feel cold and burnt. All actors in this movie have a quality of smallness of soul and a narrow horizon.When I see how many positive reviews this gets, I'm sorry, but only one word comes to mind. Fools. Generally, the only people who would like this movie are people like the ones who made it. And no, these people in question are not "thinkers and dreamers" though they definitely think they are. If you thought the Matrix was deep, increase your chances of liking this movie by 50%.I apologize for being negative in this review, but I get that way after I read a page of undeserved recognition (reader reviews). I also get that way when people claim that intelligent people will like this film and others "don't get it". For this piece, the trend seems to be the other way around.1/10

How anyone can dislike Waking Life is beyond me. The first time I saw it I left my friend's house on shaky legs, feeling as though my life had altered forever. It is a true experience, and I agree with another commentator on this page that it has to be seen several times to be fully appreciated. The plot is concerned with dreams and so the film is set in an intricate, frightening and yet strangely intriguing dream experienced by the dream character. Only the idea to create a movie set inside a dream is inspirational, and the way it's been done takes my breath away: the characters' speech and behaviour is so extremely dreamlike that i almost get the feeling that the director (Richard Linklater) has recorded one of my dreams and then recreated it.This is no ordinary movie but for anyone who tend to appreciate that, this is a real pearl. See it!

reviews.review_title: Featuring a negative review is a disservice to this film.
reviews.content: This hugely creative animated film mesmerized me, speaking to all the parts of me that wonder about "reality" and perception. I loved the flavor of the animation/dreamscape; characters morphed as they talked, creating caricatures of themselves as they did so. Some of the animation was nearly photographic, flowing into surrealistic images that spoke to underlying emotional charges. All the backgrounds were unstable, adding to the uncertainty of what was real and what was only preferred perception -- or even unconscious, socially-defined perception. Even tho this cinematic statement was about dreaming, I believe only those who are awake will be able to follow the message.When I searched out and found the film on this website, the featured review was quite negative. It does the film a disservice to feature, as the only one, a review by someone who obviously doesn't have any idea of what this film is about. If you are a seeker and a dreamer, this offbeat film is a must-see.

When an artist creates something, it is as if he has cut open the vein of his spirit and let it bleed into the world. That is the best way to describe a musician, an artist,a sculptor, and any other person that births a new idea into existence. This movie is all about awakening that part that resides in all of us. I could not help but be entranced by this movie. It may well be the greatest film I have ever seen in my entire life.It was as if the turbine in my brain just supercharged and I couldn't help but think about new things, old memories, and the theories and ideas discussed in the film. I urge anyone with a creative mind to watch this movie, and try not to be impressed

reviews.review_title: Linklater goes on expedition to his own colon.
reviews.content: Waking Life is a schizophrenic film, at least in terms of quality. On one hand the animation is excellent and entertaining, but on the other the dialogue is so in-cohesive and unnecessarily pretentious it becomes unbearable.The film tries to tackle many interesting subjects which could potentially make excellent themes if actually integrated into a plot. However this movie basically boils down to a loose collection of random conversations and monologues about existence, spoken mainly in a pointlessly heavy, pseudo-intellectual stream of consciousness.I watched this film very soon after watching A Scanner Darkly and was almost certain I would enjoy it, but unfortunately I was let down by what seems like a director merely trying to show how deep his philosophical knowledge is. Apparently this film was an attempt by Linklater to get across the experience of lucid dreaming, and while the stylisation and haphazard structure do mimic dreams very well he forgot the important factor of actually making a movie watchable.I was bitterly disappointed by Waking Life as I enjoy films which go beyond simple story driven plots and ask questions of the viewer and wanted to add this one to the criminally small list. Instead it comes across as a lazy piece of script writing that simply presents it's ideas directly in dialogue instead of working them into a plot, almost desperate to make sure people know how intellectual it is.If you want to watch a film that discusses existentialism intelligently but with enough subtlety to be entertaining then watch I Heart Huckabees. If you want to watch a film that gets across the intense confusion and visual distortion of an acid trip then watch A Scanner Darkly.Just don't watch this film.

reviews.review_title: Ayn Rand might as well have written this screenplay
reviews.content:
This movie is excruciating to watch.  It is virtually devoid of dialogue. Each scene consists of an (at least) five minute long monologue, where the character expounds on such and such issue about dreams, life and death. It was as tedious as Ayn Rand's work, where each chapter contains a ten-page diatribe, which one must wade through to get to the plot.  However, there IS no plot in this movie.  You get no reward for the eternal patience you must exhibit to sit through the entire film.  There is no humor, no suspense, no progress.  Just a series of overly pretentious thinkers who like to hear themselves talk.
It is not that i didn't find the philosophy behind this film interesting. On the contrary, i found it quite interesting.  But i still believe that the primary purpose of film is to entertain, before it educates.  Some movies (There's Something About Mary, for example) completely ignore the intellectual side of film media; this film not only ignores its humorous dictate, but actually kills it and leaves its body for the vultures.  I'm not saying that good film needs to be funny.  Plenty of dark-hearted dramas make my list of good movies, but they're are entertaining and engaging dramas; they have plot and character development.  They place the viewer inside of the film, where Waking Life alienates its viewers.  Each character pushes the audience away by being a two dimensional conduit for the screenwriter's philosophy.  Even the main character is rather flat, as he portrays the young man on a journey.  We learn nothing about his life or his personality; he is merely the wanderer, who meets many odd intellectuals during his eternal afterlife.  Basically, he is as flat as the film itself.I must say, however, that the film is visually stunning, and it was quite enjoyable to recognize the actors from their wobbly drawn caricatures. Unfortunately, the appearance of the film cannot salvage its seriously lacking plotline and characters.  Waking Life gets a 1 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: This film is a dream, one to go back to again!
reviews.content: This film is a dream.  It's funny and smart and utterly enchanting.  It is one to go back to, like one of those dreams that you hope you can find again when you fall back asleep, only this one is there, waiting. It made me think of watching American Beauty, you can't hold the whole thing together from one viewing, the images take your attention from the words and vice versa, so you have to go back. The music is also a treat!  Beautiful work!

reviews.review_title: the proof that film is a living art
reviews.content: i am overwhelmed. i am so overwhelmed that for the first time in three years as an registered user at the imdb i am writing down my point of view towards a movie. "waking life" is a philosophical but yet heart-grabbing tour the force. it has that much input to give, that you can hardly follow. it is right, as some users mentioned, that you somehow feel like meeting a stranger at a college-party, who is passionately telling you the meaning of life. except: you are meeting 20 strangers in 100 minutes, and they all fill you up. that can be very much and probably too much if you try to think about what they say DURING the movie. but if you just sit and listen and watch the passion it's a wonderful experience, which becomes really fantastic and groundbreaking with the visuals of the movie. when i heard about a movie being filmed with real people and than animated, i expected an more or less ordinary cartoon with a somehow pop-art-appeal. but the animators put much more into it than just overpainting the existing film, they brought it to life. i know you can't imagine what that means. one has to see to understand. and thats another point that makes this movie so special: a good movie is an experience which cannot or only unsatisfactory be told.it's a masterpiece.turn your heads on!

I saw this film at The Sundance Film Festival of 2001, and it was the very best thing I saw there this year.  It was funny how after coming out of the theater, I realized that this film satiated a hunger I'd had for a very long time.  The hunger was for dialogue that addresses all the difficult and interesting mysteries of life, and does so without seeming too pompous or overbearing.  The animation was superb as well.  Very dreamy, and mildly hallucinogenic.  I'd give this film high recommendations.

reviews.review_title: from what i saw good movie
reviews.content: I have only seen about the first 25 min of the movie "Waking Life." The first thing about this movie that caught my eye was the animation. The animation appeared to me to be real video that had been colored over using water paints or something wavy like that. At first I thought it might have been all animation, but the part with the boyfriend and girlfriend in the bed changed my mind. The boyfriend in that part appeared to be Ethan Hunt, just colored over. I am not sure if it was in deed Ethan Hunt but if not it sure looked a lot like him. The part that had the most impact on me was the same scene, the one with the boy and girl in the bed talking. The girl said sometimes she felt as though she was watching her life through the eyes of an old women. Sometimes it seems to me that I am watching my life through the eyes of another, not anyone in particular. Maybe not even that I'm watching my life, but that I think about what's going on in my life and it seems like I am thinking about another person's life and their struggles and problems. This movie I think was created in part because no one really knows the meaning of life and why were here, and this was one person's attempt at making sense of it all. I would like to view the entire movie sometime soon, it looked like a good movie with lots of originality and deep thought.

The movie was essentially a series of "deep" philosophical lectures. While the lectures cover valid tangential thoughts, they rarely move past what the average college student has discussed over coffee by the end of his/her junior year. The dialog in this movie would work better as a series of essays than as a movie. The animation seemed pointless and distracting, though to an altered mind would likely be engrossing. Random bits of color and light tend to flash across a camera-scape that flits about as if filmed by someone who had too much espresso. I wouldn't recommend this movie to an epileptic. If you are young, haven't been around very many college students, or have lived all your life in a rural area that eschews such things, this movie is a good primer on how to hold your own with the pseudo-intellectuals of the world without quite becoming one yourself...just don't forget to think beyond where the movie leaves off.

I thought that this was a very interesting movie the animation was unlike any I had seen before. It was almost as if it were a water painted picture. Realistic in a sense but at the same time it looked completely unreal. This seems to be a story of Wiley Wiggins but at times it veers of into stories that have no part of him. It talks in depth about different situations in life bringing them into different perspectives. It gets in depth on things in life, love, and about hate. When it switches into different scenes you never know what to expect next. Then the next scene comes up and you are drawn into the movie more and more not knowing what to expect. There is one point where a man was filling up a tank with gasoline and I couldn't even here the words after he asked for some matches because right away my mind was thinking they are going to blow up or is he going set something on fire (maybe a building or car...what?) and my mind could not even concentrate on the words being said anymore but just in curiosty of what he was going to do. Then finally he did what he did and it was something totally unexpected and my emotions did not know what to think or how to think about that situation. The scene that really caught my attention was the car scene where the guy does not know where he is going. Is this stating that he needs to find some sort of direction in his life or maybe to not do something that is expected of you but rather just release yourself and do anything you please and don't even worry about what will happen it will all work out in the end. Well that is some of the things that I thought about while watching this very original movie. There is nothing like it that I have ever seen and it opens your mind to weird situations.

As a non - native English speaker I really admire of a word dream. Cause it has two different meanings - dreams that you're following in your life to fulfill your destiny, and dreams that you experiencing when you're asleep.But after watching "Waking Life" I finally realised that our actual sleeping dreams it's not very different from the sober state of counsciousness which is so-called reality."Dreams are real only as long as they last, couldn't you say the same thing about life?"
And if you can do whatever you want in your dreams, maybe you can use the same principle in your life. Cause from the beginning it's just a series of events with your own decisions which lead you to... selling a life for minimum wage as most people do instead of realising that you're able to build this dream whichever way you want. Just feel it."The worst mistake that you can make is to think that you're alive" Are you alive or still dreaming? Do you know how to check it? Just switch the light off."Waking Life" is divided into different parts of Jessee's dreams and conversations with various of people and their thoughts about the life. I was pausing the movie everytime the part was dissolving into another. Just to think and reconsider all the things that i heard and ask myself:
What do you think about that?I like the feeling of interacting with a film, when you're completely into it, sitting together with a characters, whose sharing their ideas with you and contemplating the life the way they see it. All the scenes always brought new people and new thoughts, and that's the most exciting thing - to explore the world from different perspectives. A lot of questions and ideas that were discovered in this film (btw it's a various of them - biology, psychology, physics, philosophy and just arandom things)
sent me plenty of messages to think about:
"What is the most universal human characteristic? Fear or laziness?"We should never write ourselves off and see ourselves as a victims of various forces. It's always our decision who we are"
"The quest is to be liberated from the negative, which is really our own will to nothingless."Suicide carried off many. Drink and devil took care of the rest."
I think everyone can find something interesting during watching this movie and I definitely recommend it. Just make yourself a hot tea, free your mind of every thought and start to dream together with Jesse.And for me... next time I wake up I'll open my eyes, but will not close my soul.

reviews.review_title: Watch this movie if you've ever woken up in a dream.
reviews.content: I just watched Waking Life by Richard Linklater, it was one of the best films I have ever seen, it was on a subject I've always put a lot of thought into, are we awake or asleep, how do you know if you are in the real world now, or is this the dream and we are in a reality which is more real when we dream (from the conventional perspective of waking and dreaming). A must see for everyone who has realised they are dreaming and had to wake themselves up, I have, and as soon as I'd done it I regretted it, imagine the possibilities of being in a dream state whilst conscious and able to decide what to do next, where to go, being able to ask questions of the people you see.

I love Richard Linklater. But I though Waking Life was horrible;despite what some pseudo intellectuals purport. If you'd like to see a good film from him, choose from: Slacker, Before Sunset, Before Sunrise. Although, I did find the animation interesting; the movie was self contradictory. I would explain that, but I don't want to include any spoilers; and the dialogue and philosophical arguments sophomoric... and underdeveloped. The characters are just parroting common arguments without presenting any explanation for their beliefs. That was what bothered me most about the film. I must concede that there were a few quirky scenes in the movie. But... that was about it.

reviews.review_title: This is the kind of movie that people say they like so that others think they are really 'deep thinkers'
reviews.content: Disregarding the annoying animation, the concept had potential, but what really made me sick was the cliché life/death/society philosophies, I think we've all heard them a few thousand times before.  Philosophy really isn't profound if you already know what someone's going to say next.

reviews.review_title: this movie cannot escape my mind
reviews.content: (MINOR PLOT SPOILERS) I read the last review of it all being pretentious BS but...i don't see that at all. It has answered questions that have always plagued my mind, and whether or not the answers given to me by the movie are correct, the answer is comforting. I always have thought of the reason why we dream. One answer i always had was it was the mind's way of creating order from chaos. Chaos being everything we perceive as reality on day-to-day basis. Every sight, sound, touch, taste, smell and memory all rolled into tiny featurettes while we sleep...but that answer wasn't enough for me. This movie, like I said whether the answer(s) given is right or wrong who knows but, it has cleared up a lot of things I have always thought about and given me a positive outlook on life, death and dreaming. I recommend this movie to ANY person who criticizes EVERYTHING. To people who challenge the things and illusions that are very difficult to see through and even ask questions about.In short, this film was amazing. And although the animation is very odd and seasick-ish, I find it totally necessary and enjoyable...especially if your on some kind of hallucinogenic drug.

reviews.review_title: A surreal, beautiful meditation on life and dreams
reviews.content: Waking Life is a truly unique bit of filmmaking - more or less an animated, non-linear, organic dream state.  Not exactly a raucous Friday evening, to be sure, but it would be a shame if you ignored this film just because the premise is frightening.  Eschewing any real narrative, it manages to be genuinely funny, touching, and, above-all, thought-provoking.Something of a companion piece to Linklater's first movie, Slacker, the movie is Essentially a series of vignettes taking place in the mind of a dreaming Wiley Wiggins.  Many of the vignettes take the form of encounters between Wiggins and various characters apparently spun out of the recesses of his mind.  He more or less essentially listens as these characters present philosophies of life, dreams, and death - it is only late in the movie that his character really learns to interact or put perspective on events.The form of the movie definitely takes some getting used to - it was about 20 minutes until I really found a way to engage with the material.  The key for me was taking the slew of theory and information the movie throws at you and processing it not as objective lecture, but as subjective food-for-thought, a patchwork of thoughts and ideas not distinct in and of themselves but parts of a whole, watch of which can be accepted, rejected, or considered without doing the same to the whole movie.  My advice is to relax, and just sort of let the movie wash over you.Waking Life was filmed on DV and then rotoscoped, an animation technique of tracing live actors, and the effect is one of semi-constant movement - as Linklater described it, the whole movie "breaths."
