Its beautiful and wonderfully appropriate, a mesh of fantasy and realism that lends itself perfectly to the dream state content of the movie.There is lot lurking beneath the surface of this film, for anyone looking for a new and different movie experience, I highly recommend taking a look at Waking Life.

At no time during the movie was an idea or philosophy brought up that wouldn't be laughed out of a freshman philosophy class and immediately given sound rhetoric shredding any fragment of innovative thought involved in those ideas. The movie was clearly aimless throughout. Getting past the existentialist crap, which bombards us constantly, to enjoy any part of the movie is hard to do. This is even harder due to the completely non-cohesive plot - in other words, the mindless ramblings of the different characters in no way tie together; the movie just goes from one thought to the next with no transition. It's quite disappointing. You know what? I couldn't get past the ramblings. It is hard for me to imagine anyone but people high on LSD or some other hallucinogen enjoying this film - well other than those people who think any wordy movie that brings up conversations involving life or the hereafter is a good movie. Just because most films don't address these topics doesn't make a film that does a quality film. I really couldn't tell if the acting was any good. In this movie, how could you tell? The director obviously knew that the plot couldn't draw much attention so he used film editing. Now I know it was most likely meant to portray a dream like atmosphere, but one couldn't help thinking it was to draw attention away from the nauseating boredom of the scenes. I did enjoy the film editing, and the people I watched it with and talked to about the film said it was awesome because the editing was new, something they've never seen. Um - sorry - it's not new. It's called rotoscoping and has been around since the early 60's. All in all I would say this movie was mundane enough to be mind-numbing. I hated this film!

I really love this movie! The dialogs are great, and contain a lot of amazing sentences, like: "I don't exactly agree, which is to say i don't disagree completely".(Or something like that). It's a beautiful movie. It's shot with a digital camera and animations has been added on top of the real actors. And i think that it really brings out the characteristics of the people ínvolved. Even though there aren't many new ideas, it's a great introduction to the world of Philosophy and don't forget Lucid Dreaming. The first thing i did after seeing it for the first time was to see it again! It really got me wondering about a lot of interesting things. So i recommend it for everyone!P.S My English vocabulary is very limited, and my spelling and grammar is not exactly perfect! But I hope you go the point. D.S

It would have been just as effective as a book on tape as it was on film. It was an unsuccessful venture into visual media. For a filmmaker to make such a visually peculiar piece I believe that the deviations from the norms of cinema have to work very effectively as devices in the story; in this case the animation did not. In effect the animation was distracting and contrived. Just a thought.

reviews.review_title: Initial skepticism turned into final certainty
reviews.content: Initial I thought this movie didn't make any sense. I watched it in a classroom, and our teacher made us write about it. I really ended up loving this movie. I looked at life so differently after i saw it. I read about so many philosophers and how they viewed the world. It is funny what happens when someone just sits and starts thinking about why we exist, why things happen the way they do, why people act the way they do. i personally have learned to love philosophy, there is such an expression in it. Every time after I have finished talking about philosophy, i feel like something has been lifted out of me. I wonder if this is what these people who made this movie felt like after they finished it. My favorite part is at the end, the guy at the pin ball machine, i just had to write about it. Watch it! You'll learn to love it.

An interesting philosophical trip, but it really was too much for the time alloted. This film struck me as a poetic look at the idea behind the interpretations of the Orpheus and Eurydice myth by Gregory Orr. (One of his poem discusses Eurydice's want to remain "dead" and in the underworld.) The trip in this movie was for the main character to move from "no" to "yes" (objective to subjective), and understand that, once the dream-state is recognized, and even embraced, that anything (everything, in fact) is possible. An amusing approach to the classic premise.As a high school student still reeling in the novelty of reaching deeper into a piece of art, the format used in the movie struck me as having the potential to be incredibly powerful. Using several different artists changed each scene's point of view substantially, but the transitions were generally smooth. The entire concept was bursting with possibility, and I'd like to see it presented in other movies, although it seems to lend itself more to short films.Overall, I think there was far too much packed into this film to make sense of all its discussions in a single sitting. This movie could be amazing if presented over time as a series of semi-independent vingettes (i.e., on the Independent Film Channel, or an internet release.) See this movie. Its a trip, any way you take it.

reviews.review_title: Very close to the cutting edge!
reviews.content: Although this movie lags conversations I've had by six months, it is still very interesting.  One very small aspect is the conversation describing free will.  From the observer's point of view, it is essential.  But from the third person perspective it is completely defined by physics.  I would have hoped for a discussion of life extension and immortality, but this might even been a bit far out for this movie.  Oh well, I still HIGHLY recommend seeing this movie.

i am wondering how does the director which produce all the movie almost by himself, could understand so well the world of dreams? at the beginning of the movie i was wondering how come everybody know what they say and explain it so well? i mean it's getting boring pretty soon, to see ppls agree about lots of important meta-physically philosophical thing. the animation is unbelievable the chatting subjects are genius and all the movie done perfectly except that everybody know what they say so much unlike the real life or any other movie. but from the other hand i felt so identified with the main character... later i figured that this guy is actually dreaming this whole stuff while he is probably sleeping but somehow is awake. it seems to be that things in your dreams are so understood as the best as u could understand them. Linklater Richard is doing a wonderful job over this movie that never ends and live u just a one feeling at the end of the movie - to see it again. was i dreaming all that ?

After about five minutes of glaring with wide eyes into the hypnotic animation--my pupils swelling into the life of the animation--I found myself waving my arms and yelling at the screen in the full theater.  I couldn't distinguish this movie from reality; I just recently started thinking that characters in movies should speak like people in real life (not with rehearsed, perfectly-annunciated, direct lines).  But, even on top of the reality lay the meaning of the characters' interactions.Philosophy laced the plot, ideas of existentialism, and people (including myself) being a dream of Tao pulsed into my mind (with or without the directors intent).  The movie was very eloquent and clear, but with a poetry vagueness, which allowed me to expand and think about the concepts in more detail.Well done

reviews.review_title: Get over yourself to enjoy this movie
reviews.content: This is the first time I've ever written a comment on IMDb, mostly because this movie was so impressive, but also because of how misunderstood it seems to be. There is no doubt that this is a movie for people who like to think about and explore what lies behind our lives. But unfortunately some people just can't help but use a movie like this to pat themselves on the back, snub their noses and say things like, "Although this movie lags conversations I've had by six months, it is still very interesting Similarly, another criticism is that the philosophical meat of this movie was unoriginal. Yes, most of what was discussed has probably been said or thought many times before, but not by everyone. To criticize "Waking Life" for being unoriginal is to miss the point. This movie was meant to coalesce a broad range of provocative thoughts into a singular, rambling piece of impressionistic art. Just like many people initially looked at Monet's work and said it was rubbish that could have been painted by a bad child artist, so will people criticize this film for being devoid of plot and originality because it is a different kind of movie. People are used to being spoon-fed big heaping mouthfuls of sugar and vinegar; hence the popularity of  "Serendipity" and "13 Ghosts". In contrast, this is a movie that tosses out small jewels, some that you will not catch because you will linger over the one before, until the end gives you a vague vision of reality, the whole that is the true "plot". There are several levels of the film, some of which I know I didn't see. First, it is a stunningly beautiful vision. The animation technique does mirror and modify what is being said, but it can be enjoyed immensely by itself. Second, the film is a sampling of provocative thoughts about what it means to be alive and what it means to be awake (versus in a dream). Third, it is a catalyst for us all to personally explore these topics. It is a mark of any good film that when we leave we continue to talk and think about the topics that were raised, but this film brings us to the next level. Like a catalyst it acts to speed up our thoughts on the topic and allows us to explore in ways that previously we could not. Ultimately it is about inverses, and is itself an inverse. Characters espouse the value of guns and end up shooting each other. It is set on land that is in constant motion like the sea. Dead people think they are alive and live people think they are dead. It is about dreaming but is called "Waking Life".

reviews.review_title: A unique perspective by an artist who painted the canvas of death and life through a vision of dreams
reviews.content: Richard Linklater has out done himself on this one. Through a combination of Characters from his past films and his unique style of filming in the real, and changing it into a different series of animation types, hard to adapt a first then easily accepted, he has combined a number of philosophies of life into a film understood only through reflection.I am plagued with a new found desire to control my dreams. Through a series of abstract characters, a man finds himself listening to the ideas and thinking of brilliant minds. He finds himself in a dream he cannot wake up from, and through the words of one of the characters is an explanation why.The theories he is subject to slowly evolve into theories on dreams and eventually lead to theories and his understanding of why he is unable to wake up. A final acceptance of his situation, a higher learning.Such a film cannot be summed up in only one sentence, or many for that matter. A film, unique as this is can only be understood by the people who have seen in, one's comprehension of the film is likely differs from another's, yet in retrospect, they are same.So I now IMPLORE you to go out and see Waking Life, take your mind and understanding to a whole new level, discover a thought process you never use and..........discover yourself.

Whoa. I don't feel like words can do it justice. This film is an amazing creation by a brilliant film maker. It shot to near the top of my all time film favorites. I consider it a cinematic masterpiece. It captures the concept of our waking life versus our dreams so well. And for the creative artist in all of us it is a gourmet 9 course meal! See it and enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful and thought-provoking, but definitely not for everyone.
reviews.content: Richard Linklater's "Waking Life" is a colorful jaunt through the worlds of expressionism, philosophy, and existentialism.  The animation serves to more accurately accent the film's topics.  It has been said that his movie has no plot, but that is not the case at all.  The plot is there, it's just not the focal point of the movie, instead it is much like the animation in that it helps move the film's different parts along. Don't come into the theater merely expecting to observe a film, though.  If you do, then this movie will bore the hell out of you, as the animation alone can only hold it up for so long.  Instead view it as a chance to think about deeper things than your everyday cinematic regiment addresses.  View it as both a learning and a purging process. If you just sit back and watch, you'll completely miss the full effect of the movie.  Linklater is the kind of director that doesn't just write a happy little, easily understandable story and show it to you saying, "Look what I made!"  Instead, he makes you really think and work to comprehend what you're experiencing.  But in the end, it's a better movie for that, in that by the end of the film you feel a sense of achievement.  This movie will make you look at every other film you've ever seen and make them look like they lack substance. "Waking Life" takes you through Wiley Wiggins search for reality while he meets a cast of interesting, distinguishable characters who tell him the same thing, but from a different point of view everytime (IE- sociological, scientific, religious, artistic).  The film also makes insightful, and often humorous, social commentary (the scene with the two men at the bar about gun control is nothing short of genius). It's definitely one of those movies that makes you think, and you'll definitely find that you have the characters voices in your head for possibly days to come.  It's also a film that really requires multiple viewings to truly appreciate.  Some people have found and may find this film "boring", but to quote Harvey Danger "If you're bored, then you're boring."

If you've seen this movie, I think you'll see the irony in this IMDB review:"Have you ever overheard a conversation you wished you hadn't? Ever hear someone trying to make sense of their life in a coffee shop? Most of those of us for whom words come easily are all too aware of their shortcomings. Composed of letters that are themselves even more abstract than numbers, words can, at best, approximate truth. In the most skilled hands, and by these I refer to Shakespeare, Euripedes, Williams, and arguably less than a handful of others, and in conjunction with acting of the highest calibre, truth can be approached but never apprehended. The truth lives in places free of the constraints of words. Truth lives in the gut and heart, not the mind.Given this, Waking Life's pastiche of dialogue and diatribe quickly wears thin. I closed my eyes early on, closing out the fascinating and intricate "animation" on-screen, and heard the words. Shallow they were. Hollow, puffed up. Worth little. This, then, is a cartoon of the highest order. Fascinating visual affect overlaying the most pedestrian of stories. Our feeble attempt to work out with words the significance of life and our little lives."Yes, this reviewer is complaining about the way the characters speak, and he sounds very much like on of the characters in this movie.
"Waking Life" is an incredibly real movie. It's more real than any movie I've ever seen. This is not a film that I sat and watched in a theater, but it is something I experienced.I never try to write reviews for anything, because I'm not very elequent when it comes to discussing my own aesthetic perceptions. This movie is even more difficult to review because it's so good, so perfect, so important, so REAL that I can't even use any of those words to describe it.I was actually a little annoyed for the first 20 minutes, and felt like I couldn't get a word in. But eventually I gave up trying to get a word in, and as I paid attention to these people, I realized how confused they were. Notice how the most grating, difficult to follow monolouges are delivered by the most intense, confused people. They have all of these questions and answers (or answers and questions), but they certainly are not enlightened. The film doesn't give us any answers, but shows us an illegible digital clock that makes us realize that we're not really awake.
It is if the director took a little piece of the Truth (or God, or Tao, or whatever) and distilled it into movie form.

For those viewers with a certain interest in various philosophies or just an interest in deep thought provoking plots, this is the movie for you. After I first saw it, I went online and read the script. The first time you watch it it's going to be confusing, but in my personal opinion it's the movies that I leave still thinking about that remind me how truly beautiful cinema is. The art is visually stunning. It is different than any other animated feature. I look forward to Richard Linklater's A Scanner Darkly due for release on July 7, 2006. To describe the plot in one sentence, it is a movie that brings someone into the real world and the dream world simultaneously. You have to see it to understand it. "Super profound to the early eve of your day!"

Perfect for someone contemplating life. i have experimented with conscious dreams and having a whole movie about dreams, life and death was wonderful, it was a joy to watch. i loved all of the characters and it was amazing how the director could give the viewers such a great idea of what the characters were about, their lives, their personalities, while only spending a few minutes on each of them.

reviews.review_title: A visually stunning art house dream film.
reviews.content: This film portrays one man's seemingly never-ending, sometimes lucid dream. It actually inspired me to gain lucidity within my own dreams although it is a difficult task.  I went into this film with little expectation which I always find turns out in my favor.  Part of the fun of watching it is identifying different actors and actresses as their animated likes.  If you seek an alternative to blockbuster lineage and predictability, this is your boat.  Speaking of which I'm a particular fan of the car/boat scene.  How Fear and loathing?

Sheesh. Everybody's a philosopher these days. Roll anybody a few joints and plunk them in front of this movie, and all of the sudden they're pondering the mysteries of life and dreams as if they've just discovered the genius within. It's about existentialism, duuude. Whatever.Linklater has done some solid work in the past, and visually, it's an interesting film to watch. The animation varies from the real, to the surreal, to downright crude in places. But good looks can't save this film from being like talking to that creepy grad student at a party who uses similar monologues to try to score with you. 2/10

Being an anime fan, I've seen plenty of "cinema-quality" animation projects. "Waking Life", however, went far beyond those projects; at a technical level, it combined wonderful cinematic techniques (angles that only a master camera-person could pull off, but still intriguing) with plot depth that simply cannot be touched by anything else. The use of irony in the film (I am not sure what else it could be called without a loss of accuracy in meaning or melodrama) is beautifully-integrated: a man setting himself on fire in a relatively secluded street to demonstrate his lack of voice, a chimpanzee teaching a class regarding evolution (with a film showing humans), and a man denouncing propaganda from his vehicle through a loudspeaker, 1984-style.A wonderfully intricate movie; definitely recommended.

Waking Life was a big disappointment. The possibilities to explode the meaning of life and death are endless but instead of going deeper into any of these theoretical speeches, Linklater decides to keep lecturing us with more and more philosophical theory that gets nowhere. The animation format of the movie is clever but a little bit tiring as there are no foreground or background details to allow for the eyes to `rest' from time to time. You should see this movie if you are easily impressed with lectures taken from book quotes and articles, but prepare yourself for a long sometimes boring sermon.

reviews.review_title: great creative animation and vivid stories
reviews.content: this is an amazing and not-often seen style of film ala my dinner with andre and, to a lesser degree, smoke. the topical material is very similar to slacker. political and social commentary, philosophy and general conversation about intellectual topics. if you enjoyed the type of conversation in slacker, you will have some more food for thought. if not, you might lose interest. unless you are a fan of avant-garde and unique animation! then you could watch this movie on mute and still get a kick out of it! but alas not everyone has the attention span to appreciate this kind of thing, i saw no less than 4 people leave the theater (with relatively few attending) when i saw this movie. but don't let that deter you, if you are an artistic, creative, intellectual and philosophical person then this is the movie for you! highly recommended.

This is one of the most thought provoking movies I have seen in my entire life.  The entire format (live-action painted over as to make it look like animation) is something that would not work for most movies, but it fits Waking Life perfectly.  If you can find a way to see this movie, I was lucky enough to see it in the theater.

reviews.review_title: Good, if you need a philosophy lecture
reviews.content: I saw this movie at a local theatre and I must say that I was greatly disappointed.  I knew little about the movie before viewing it, as it was recommended by a friend.  Upon watching, I was instantly put off by how incredibly preachy it was.  Philosophical ideas are not discussed, rather they are thrown at you as snippets of some "greater truth."  Secondly, the ideas presented are hardly original.  They are simply rehashed versions of Buber, Nietzche and other beginner's level philosophers.  I could go to a coffee shop and overhear pseudo-intellectuals say what this movie is saying for free, and probably in greater detail.  On the positive side, the animation is outstanding, and really all that kept me there until the end. Waking Life is a must see if you've never heard of philosophy.  Otherwise, don't waste your money listening to the same things you've heard time and time again.

No, the theories weren't that original.Some were hopelessly out of date, disproven decades ago or just nonsensical.But the film, as a whole, was enjoyable.First, I'm thrilled to see a director attempting to manipulate the medium in a creative way.  Just for the record.  The film was shot on Digital Video and then animated by several different animators.  It was the actors/players themselves who were talking.  Some of the players were not actors, but friends of Linklater's voicing their own opinions or speaking on topics important to them.All of the well written criticism about this movie seems to be stemming from one of several observations.1.  The film doesn't take a stand.  It merely shows a bunch of people throwing around their ideas.Quite frankly, this is one of my main criticisms of American Films, that they feel they HAVE to take a stand.  I don't like being beaten over the head by some schmoe who only knows how to use a camera and feels that he has a point.  Watch some prewar (WWII) french films or Italian neorealist flicks, or anything by Jane Campion for that matter and see what I mean.2.  The film is Philosophy 101.When taken piece by piece, I would agree that none of the theories are particularly groundbreaking.  I happen to think that this film shows a snapshot of our collective experiences of "Waking Life" as a human.I'm not a philosopher, but this film seemed to me to be extrememly representative of many of Hoffstadter, Dawkins, and Dennett's current theories on Human Consciousness.
Definitely worth the ticket

I've been a fan since Dazed and Confused. I've known he was a genius since Before Sunrise. As far as I'm concerned, Waking Life earns Richard Linklater the title of best filmmaker working today. As the main character wanders through an animated dream world, he and the strange people he meets with question consciousness, the meaning of life, and the vagaries of human interaction. Every frame captures the essence of dreamlife, from its striking clarity to its unquestioned unreality to its unnameable wiggly bits. This is a masterpiece. Congratulations to Linklater, congratulations to his fans. If he keeps up the rate of growth he has exhibited so far, his next movie will be the celluloid equivalent of a thousand years in heaven.

reviews.review_title: the finest piece of brain candy ever made
reviews.content: A truly life-changing experience, one of the most mentally and visually stimulating films in existence, this work of art is thought-provoking on numerous levels to say the least.  Waking Life truly needs to be viewed numerous times in order to absorb and appreciate, the complex thoughts, philosophy, theory and humor it explores.  It's powerful and hopeful at once.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful and intelligent cinematic treat
reviews.content: This is one of the most intelligent and original films I've ever seen come out of American cinema.Visually its use of animation over live footage is striking. The mixture of artistic styles interprets the protagonist's moods and changing situations really well, without the change in aesthetic being too drastic or grating.It's essentially a non-narrative film and may alienate some viewers - I was in a screening with some twenty other people, four of whom left before it was half way through.  However, after the first few characters explain their own philosophical perspectives, which are rather heavy-duty, it gets going a bit and keeps you interested.Philosophical conversations on dreams, what it means to be human, the nature of cinema and on many other metaphysical, spiritual and social issues leave you with a mind full of ideas and thoughts.  It is brainfood with a beautifully visualized style.I watched Star Wars Episode 2, straight after this and the contrast could not be greater - this is a brilliantly written, intelligent and original film; Star Wars is a dull rehash of other films, painted over with special effects and including one of the all-time worst scripts.

wow, after watching this movie, I'am in awe and I have 1000 thoughts runnin through my mind....the bud ice is helping as well...anyways this movie, Gosford Park, ghost World, and mosters ball are my fav movies of 2001. peace mike
The movie in itself is just beautiful and for people who can remember their lucid dreams it is even more beautiful. Highly recommended if you want more of an experience than just killing time.

reviews.review_title: Incredible, but not necessarily as a movie
reviews.content: Waking Life is an incredible lesson in life, death, and dreaming; and beautifully done at that.  But it's hard to compare it to most movies, especially mainstream American ones.  To ignore what the characters are trying to say is close minded, to try to find a plot is futile, and to overstate its beauty is nearly impossible.

reviews.review_title: This film is incredible philosophical documentary
reviews.content: Waking Life make me awake. This film is masterpiece. Each dialog is a film. If you want to change your life you watch this movie. Film is between real screen and linear scene. Like dream. And it explains a person who tour among reality and dream. Like all of us.But sometimes the movie is like vehicle of propaganda. However at film opinions are explained very well. The film includes too much dimensions. Eachtime you watch film you win different vision of life.This movie touches freedom of conscious. People can be more free. Only they want this. The life is only raw material and we must shape it. We aren't part of life, life is part of us...

Linklater's latest work is definitely a movie for the few. The artistic surface of the constantly moving animations embedded in a calmly flowing plot of everyday life conversations and philosophical insights is simply to demanding for the masses. My first impression of the images was one of "sea sickness". There is (at first sight) no point to hold on to. Everything is moving and floating around. The patterns and colours are changing so rapidly that your eyes can hardly follow, yet it is hard to ignore the simple beauty of the "overcoloured" images. In contrast to that the plot suggests calmness and coolness of the ever searching characters that change from episode to episode... and slowly a fixed point (in the story) crystallises: the boy that can't let go, the "hero" to identify with, the dreamer in the dream, the one which the viewer will follow to the end of the story - the final awakening. The message (imho) of this movie is to see the world as it really is, to let go of fixed opinions, to stop dreaming and to wake up in every moment of your life and start living.

reviews.review_title: Very cerebral and poignant for our time, with wonderful 2-D animation.
reviews.content: I loved this movie.  For those seeking refuge from the average, obvious, and banal---this offers a discourse on higher issues.  Theories of living, anger, hate, existentialism and alienation are delivered through the unlikely and unique animation montages.Bottom line:  If your idea of entertainment starts with T&A and ends with an explosion sequence---definitely wrong movie.   If your idea of entertainment includes probing the popular understanding of life--- "Waking Life" attempts to explore a new, subversive aesthetic sensibility. Avant-pop drawing on the forms, slogans, characters, and narrative archetypes of our multidimensional, information-dense culture.

"Waking Life", while not a film for everyone, has to be one of best,most ground-breaking films of the past few years.It may drive some people away because of its lack of a coherentstory, but if you can put aside your expectations of what a film"should be", you may realize its complexity and depth. Yes, the filmis all talking, but the movie stays engaging because theconversations the characters have cover such a broad range ofhuman emotions and current world issues. From realism to theabsurdity, from politics to film theory, from the act of living to the actof dying - this film covers it all. And it will take many, many viewingsin order to absorb everything it has to say.What really makes the film an innovation is the style of animation.It is a technique called "rotoscoping", where they take videofootage and animate over it. Not only is this animation stylebeautiful to look at, but it has everything to do with the meaning ofthe film. The movie centers around a character who is never quitesure whether he is awake or dreaming. The animation accentuates this by creating a world which is both real (the real lifeactors and settings caught on video) and fantasy (the animationdrawn over them). The meshing of reality and fantasy complements the overall mission of the film, which is to explorethe interaction between the two."Waking Life" asks a lot of questions, but only scratches thesurface as to what the answers might be. This is what makes it sogreat. Most films try to hand you a moral on a silver platter. Butreally, life has no easy answers and this movie challenges you tofind your own."Waking Life" is a truly one-of-a-kind work of film art.

reviews.review_title: Profound, if your willing to listen.
reviews.content: Movies such as these are a rare thing indeed.When the most we can hope to find at the local Cineplex is the latest monster-budgeted spectacle or tear-wrenching, manipulative, "drama", a movie like this coming along is a reason to rejoice. When a movie has the simple intention of being art, in its purest form, it is a reason to celebrate.A meditative study on dreams, death, existence, reality, and life itself, it is a 100 minute philosophical cliff-note. While it doesn't have the time, nor the inclination, to delve into the depths of the subjects it introduces, the very fact that it introduces them into the consciousness of any audience member willing to listen, elevates this from being, "just another movie", to art, art as it should always strive to be; a means to elevate the mind of the viewer, and a means to comment on the very things that make us human.Wonderfully animated through a new computer-based rotoscoping process, it allows for the many animators involved to express themselves as artists, as well as pushing the movie forward. The process truly does a wonderful job of mimicking dream imagery as best as can be done in the waking world, what with the constantly shifting styles, and the floating, surreal feel of the "reality" of the movie. I was just as enthralled with the visual palette as I was with the spoken one.Like Linklater's "Slacker", it does not have a conventional narrative structure, which will turn some viewers off, but in a movie such as this, a conventional structure is unnecessary, and, honestly, would have cheapened the material. That isn't to say that it is without story, far from it, what we are watching is the main character's journey of discovery, his being prepared. Prepared for what? That's for the viewer to decide.I would recommend this whole heartedly to anyone with the patience and desire to be enlightened as well as entertained. It is not for everyone. It is not for the passive viewer who wants their entertainment laid out for them so that thinking is not required. You HAVE to pay attention. You HAVE to listen. If you just let the words being spoken flow past you without a thought, you will be cheating yourself. Open your mind, and give this one a chance.

reviews.review_title: A sweet dose of intellectual stimulation
reviews.content: Viewers beware: do not expect to find the traditional thread of a Hollywood narrative running holding together this film. "Waking Life" is not about story structure; it is about dreams. And this movie manages to expertly capture the feeling of a dream by putting together an assortment of seemingly random, surreal images. The technique of animation employed in this movie combines the artists' designs with a cast of real-life actors. The film was rotoscoped, which means that the scenes were shot in digital video and then colored over by various animators. This technique allowed the ideas of this film come alive in an entirely unique and charming manner. As the characters talk their words become fluid visuals, and somehow the concepts of existence, human connectivity, and lucidity become available for your intellectual and emotional consumption.Though some may find it boring, the movie is by no means dry. It asks us to think about the most important topics that will ever cross our minds. The film does not give us any easy answers. But neither do our dreams.

I enjoyed this film quite a bit, and would recommend it to any artist or philosopher. The themes were carried through the entire movie and made me feel like watching it over and over to make sure I caught everything. The animation added to the dreamlike quality with it's floaty feeling and constantly changing "hands" of the different artists who contributed. The movie was first filmed and edited, and then the animators went over the picture, frame by frame, and redrew everything. This gave it a more natural movement that most animated films miss out on without this technique. Each scene was drawn by a new artist. I disliked some of the artists' styles, but the way the movie jumped from scene to scene so quickly kept me interested. The fact that the movie was filmed by a hand-held camera kind of drove me crazy because the animation seemed a bit TOO floaty. Everything wiggled around so much it was hard to tell what was what after everything was drawn over. I understand they did this to keep the dreamy, surrealist feel, but it kind of made me sick. Despite this, I was satisfied overall with the film.

reviews.review_title: An interesting take on what dreaming is about

It's not meant to be pretentious or preachy, it just takes a bit of concentration and contemplation... weird but worth the work.

Actually, Waking Life is more than a cartoon, it is a unique form of animation called Rotoscoping. Rotoscoping is an old animation technique where the action is filmed and drawn over. The reason for the 'herky jerky' motion is because each frame is done by hand, and each 'vinette' is done by a different set of artists. As for plot, the story is deep. I'll admit openly that you have to pay attention to follow this story but it's worth it once it all clicks. As for rotoscoping, the most notable use of it I can site would be in Star Wars. How did they create glowing light sabres in the late 70's? Mark Hamill and David Prowse (Darth Vader) were filmed fighting with broomsticks and then the FILM was PAINTED OVER. Waking Life is a full length feature film done entirely in this technique. If you have any interest in cinema, watch this film. DEFINITELY worth watching without your finger on the fast forward button. What was ever wrong with cartoons anyway?

reviews.review_title: A movie for those who stay up pondering the meaning of life
reviews.content: Alright. First of all, yes it's a cartoon, but if you're into art at all, this movie's a visual delight, and quite inspirational as well. Apparently, the director had the scenes filmed on digital camera (so the characters are all real people), and then had it "painted over" with computer generated animation. So it's not just a "cartoon." It's just incredible.Basically, the movie consists of the main character's encounters with various people who all have something to say about their take on the idea of Life and existence. The idea of existentialism is heavy throughout, and there is some really great food for thought. It somehow manages this without being what some might call a "pretentious" movie.It's a little hard to really ingest everything that's brought to light the first time around. I mean the visuals are overwhelming, and so is the material. I've seen it a couple times now, and I still can't get over what pure genius this movie is. Kudos to Director Richard Linklater, and all the staff.. Beautiful.

In my English class, I recently viewed a portion of this film, Waking Life. The most obvious difference between it and other movies I noticed was the way it was animated. The lines and shapes were constantly changing and shifting. In one of the first couple of conversations, the girl that the main character talks to even has shifting hair. When the girl talks about geometric shapes (I think), the hair at the side of her head turns into geometric shapes. I'm not sure exactly what she talks about, but it's something like that. Anyway, I also noticed people's eyes changing color, and many other things. I think that this contributes to the over all feeling you get watching this movie, making it seem like a dream. Another thing that does this is the cross between animation and live action. I loved the fact that you couldn't tell sometimes whether it was animation or real. This gave it a huge feeling of the whole thing being a dream. I know that it wouldn't have been as good or interesting if there weren't this neat type of animation.Another thing I really enjoyed about this movie was the lack of plot. The whole portion of the movie I viewed was just a guy going around and listening to people talk about what they think. I thought this was a very interesting way to get these ideas across. This makes the whole movie very original (though it is definitely not the only thing that makes it unique). The one part that stands out in my mind is the conversation between the two people lying in bed. It is singled out to me because it was the only conversation I saw that the main character wasn't involved in. Well, he wasn't really involved in the other conversations, but he was present. I don't recall seeing him in this particular scene at all. It also stands out to me because of what they talk about. I just thought the concept of living a whole life that literally is a 10 second flash of life from an older person is neat. It made me think about our life being an infinitely long 10-second span. This is another thing that I like about this movie, is that it makes you think about what you hear. I don't like it when you can see a movie and forget about it a second later. To be good, it has to leave an impression on you, and make you think. This movie, even though I only saw a small portion of it, definitely did that.

The captain or driver talks and talks to the young man about society, directions in life, and the connections that one thing has to another. In following scenes, this young man then is found in a class room and then spends a great deal of time talking to an older man, possibly a professor, again about life, society, history and the future of the world. For my English class, we watched the first 20 or so minutes of Waking Life. This video was unlike anything I have ever seen. Even in the short time I had to view it, my attention was captivated. It has been mentioned by others, especially those who watched it at the same time that I did, that the graphics were very interesting and worthy of paying attention to. I loved how the movie was drawn like a cartoon, but everything seemed so life like. While watching it, one might forget: are the events that are happening real or made up? I realize that it is a stretch, but Waking Life reminds me a little of movies like Toy Story. Though the animation technique used was quite different, in both cases everything looked so lifelike and was modeled after real things unlike a cartoon such as the Flintstones. During the movie an idea was brought up that has always been so interesting to me. At one point the characters were discussing how words are just symbols. For example, what do love or frustration really mean? It is so cool to think that no one can really give them a definition. Whenever someone asks "what is love?" an answer is almost impossible to come up with. It means something so different to each person and, even if we do think we know what love is, finding words to describe it can seem like the hardest thing in the world to do. Questions like this have become even more compelling to me as I have seen them in the real world or learned about them in classes. For example, I have taken Spanish classes since my freshman year of high school. One of the difficulties I have come across in my quest to become bilingual is that certain words or phrases simply do not translate well between two languages. At times it can be frustrating because you want to be able to convey the correct meaning, but usually I think it is more fascinating to see the subtle changes between languages. One example of this that I think of right away is the Spanish phrase "buen provecho." When I went to Puerto Rico last year everyone would say this at meal times, but it is hard to explain to someone who only speaks English. I guess it would be close to the French phrase "bon appetite" but not exactly. Right now is an instance where it is frustrating to not be able to tell you exactly what I mean, but I wish I could because the phrase is so cool. Another time that I have seen this as I have tried to learn Spanish is with songs. Music is something that is full of emotions no matter what language one speaks. Whenever I have tried to explain to someone what the lyrics of a Spanish song mean, it just comes out not sounding as good as it did in its natural state. This is because so much is lost in translation.

Walking LifeAlthough I only saw part of this movie, I thought it was very interesting. This was a type of movie one could think of in many aspects. The animation was awesome. It looked so real. It really caught my attention and made me want to watch more. I would like to express my thoughts towards some of the sayings and/or images I thought were interesting enough to note: 1.Dream is destiny I looked up the term "destiny" in Microsoft Office Word 2003. There were three parts to defining this term. I believe one of these pertained to this thought more: "the inner purpose of a life that can be discovered and realized." I believe when one dreams, anything is possible. Dreaming of the impossible can lead to discoveries. Perhaps the main character of "Walking Life" is trying to find destiny by dreaming dream is destiny! 2.Crayons- it's what you do with the colors This saying is so true! It is not really how you use the crayon, but how you express yourself by the colors. I think this applies to the movie. The colors in this case are all of the little motions and expressive animation (both drawn and spoken).3."Your life is for you to create" professor Obviously This seems almost ridiculous in a way, but so many people seem to lead their lives in other's footsteps or in the "wants" of others. This ties in with the previous fragment about the crayons and the color. One creates their life by using their own colors and no one else's.4."words are dead" counselor (female) At times words are dead. When nothing else can be said or when too much has already been said, words can be considered dead. One thing this makes me think of are "sorrys" or apologies. Sometimes apologies are in a sense overdone and the words become gibberish or dead. This is also much like "why is writing (s)welles." Once one has gone on and on about a certain topic ((s)welle), the words begin to die and the reader eventually dies off too (is not interested).5."man needs chaos..." friend Without chaos, the world would be a great place. But without one thing, in this case that occurs almost everyday, everything could change. Chaos is a normal state. Confusion is normal. I think many things would never get done if it was not for chaos. Oh yeah, I definitely did not like the fire!6.Reincarnation/collective memory- couple in bed I was not too sure where this conversation was going, but it seemed interesting. I noticed myself trying to understand what these two were talking about. Their thoughts were intriguing. I think this may have been where we stopped watching it. We should watch the rest! ----- There were a couple parts of the animation where I noticed the character's looks changed, but was not sure of the reasoning1.The counselor's hair makes shapes while she talks While the woman counselor was talking, here hair would move certain ways. I'm assuming it was possibly to make it seem more realistic. Anyway, her hair made shapes. Every few seconds it would change and different geometric shapes would appear. I know this does not seem too important, but maybe there is meaning behind it.2.Other counselor (male) talking about evolution of individuals while he himself is changing Then, the other counselor was talking about evolution of individuals to the main character. I though it was a bit funny because he was changing; he was developing different characteristics. Development is much like evolution. I thought this could have been a form of symbolism. To tell you the truth though, I was too busy watching his head expand and then shrinkI really did not pay much attention to what he said; other than it was about evolution of individuals.

reviews.review_title: It's not the quantity, it's the quality!
reviews.content: In my English class we viewed a movie called "Waking Life." Although we didn't get to see all of it, a lot happened in the short 20-25 minutes that we did get to watch. First thing that really attracted me to this movie was the animation. Animated characters are always a good way to make people pay attention to the message that is being displayed along with simply being entertaining. However these different characters were so real that is seemed as if it were cartoons coming to life with real problems and ideology. My favorite part of the movie which is the same part that stuck out in my head the most is the part where a three guys were riding in the car and the driver goes on and on talking about random but meaningful things and then he says this phrase which really caught my attention. The phrase went something like, "I doesn't matter if you have a 8- count or 16- count of crayons, what matters is what you do with the colors." This statement is so true because it pertains to almost everything in life, in all that you do, wherever you are. So many people are interested in the quantity of things when it is the quality that counts. Like those who write papers for their classes and think that the teachers are interested in some long drawn out paper or answer. When what they really want is a simple answer that shows exactly how much you know without the complications of some long unnecessary explanation. Or those who go out and do a ton of volunteer work with little to no effort compared to the one who does one volunteer activity and throws all of his hard work, effort, and determination into it. What good is a raw steak dinner if you have a fully prepared juicy cheeseburger meal? I know it sounds funny but it's true. The world and especially America have been so overwhelmed with trying to get more and more of the quantity of things that forget about the quality of things, like LIFE! This example was a very good phrase for defending the title of the movie. Other quotes did the same as well. They displayed their intentions in showing what Waking Life actually means. The scenes in this movie took many different approaches to explaining the importance of life and what it means. This would be a very educational movie to recommend to others.

In class we only viewed about the first twenty-five minutes of the film Waking Life. I have never seen a film like this before. The picture looked like it was alter with a water color effect. The picture was often wobbly as if it might have been shot underwater. I thought it was kind of cool that some guy's car actually looked like a boat. I notice that there was a big focus on this kid just wandering around from place to place but they never really explained why he was doing this. I would how I would find out if I saw the rest of this film. Also, the people the kid went to see were always giving him a theory or some kind of explanation to something. I thought it was weird when the kid started floating. I did not really understand why this happened. I though it was also weird when some guy that was talking to the kid all the sudden pours gasoline all over himself and then lit a match and set himself on fire. Then the film changes from the kid to a couple lying in bed and talking about reincarnation.I think I would have liked to finish this film. I believe it would give me a better idea what the message of the film is. I liked the visual effects that were put into this film; it makes the film different from any other film that I have ever seen. In my opinion, I think that the visual effects in the movie will be significant throughout it. I would like to see then rest of the film to see if the kid actually has a purpose. I would like to see where he ends up in the end as well. I think it might be significant that the couples in bed were discussing life and they also could be just waking from a nap. (Waking Life) I was also wondering if the visual effects for this movie were made from a program like Photoshop. I did find a couple of setting that alters pictures to make them look like watercolors like in the movie. In conclusion, I feel I need to view the rest of this film so I can actually know if my opinions were accurate. I was also interested in seeing how the film played out and if the visual effects had something important to do with the plot.
